description:
Fabulous!
What a find!  The burrata salad was delightful, with a fine pepperonata under the cheese; delicious!  A great beginning.
Then, my wife had a pasta/shrimp dish which was very good, and I had what was listed on the menu as a petit filet.  What arrived was anything but petit!  A huge portion (yes, I understand that petit filet is from higher up on the loin).  And delicious - much more flavor that filet mignon, and accompanied by a corn preparation which was superb!
Dessert:  we had a toasted angel food cake with sweet corn ice cream which was simply marvelous!  What a fine finish to a lovely meal.  Highly recommend this place.  You might have to be persistent to get reservations, but it's worth whatever you have to do to dine there.
author: Peter S.

description:
We came with a reservation at around for 8:30pm, and I would highly recommend doing so to avoid excessive waits! The restaurant is located in a very quaint neighborhood, and the restaurant looks like the front of a home. I loved the ambiance of the candle-lit restaurant, and the homey feels. 

We decided to do the tasting menu, which I thought would be a great way to try a few items on their menu. We started off with the levain bread baked in house, and it was some of the best bread I have had! The crust was perfectly crunchy, crispy and smoky, and the bread itself was soft and pillowy. They also gave us these savory cream puffs ( I think?), but they were super light and a great way to start the meal. There were also a lot of salads involved with the tasting menu, and also a crudo that was most memorable. The entrees included a fish and a sliced steak plate, and both were very good. The fish was very tender, and the steak was cooked perfectly to a tender, medium rare. The desserts were a chocolate pudding and a pavlova. The pavlova wasn't as special, but the chocolate pudding was very good and very rich with chocolate flavor.

Overall a very cute place for a date or a birthday celebration! This was a rather light tasting menu, with most of the courses being heavy on the salads, but otherwise, beautiful presentations!
author: Sandra S.

description:
Shockingly reasonable pricing, excellent, top-notch service and tasty food. Took my friend here for her birthday, we each got a deviled egg, which is more like spiced sous vide egg...wasn't so great. However, the heirloom tomato salad with homemade cheese compensated for it, and it was one of the absolute best salads I've ever had. All the cheese and flavor falls into a layer of faro and it was phenomenal. We also got the house sourdough bread which was definiitely a 10/10 as far as breads go. 

For our main we shared a sliced, "Wagyu" steak, which was perfectly cooked and tasty, but nothing special. The dessert was ridiculous and nothing like I expected, withmeringuee, ice cream, roasted pears...great.

As noted, service was great, water glasses full, always around. Place had a nice ambiance, was full and nice. Would return. Spent around $100 for 2 with 1 drink.
author: Jordan C.

description:
YUM!

My boyfriend and I came here for my birthday dinner and had an incredible experience. We did the blind tasting menu (only $70 pp) and were blown away. Everything was absolutely delicious and we were STUFFED by the end.

Tasting menu dishes (varies):
-Bread & butter
-Deviled egg
-Heirloom tomato and burrata salad
-Halibut crudo
-Spinach summer salad
-Tonnarelli shrimp pasta
-Oregon King Salmon
-Wagyu beef
-Olive oil cake
-Chocolate tarte

Highlights: As I said above, we really loved everything, but a few things stood out. Wagyu beef (cooked to perfection), salmon (with amazing crispy skin), halibut crudo (had never had this before and it was so light and fresh), shrimp pasta (loved the little crunchies on top)

Lowlights: Eating too much bread at the beginning!! Probably contributed to being so full by the end of the meal. Also, the deviled egg was actually a boiled egg with a runny yolk. It was still delicious but not exactly what we were expecting, as we were really looking forward to a gourmet deviled egg.

The service was also excellent. Our waiter was very helpful, attentive, and friendly. Each person who brought a course out described it in detail. 

We both said we would love to come back to Octavia again - either to try another one of their blind tastings or to just get a taste of some of the other dishes their menu has to offer.
author: Jessie K.

description: Delicious food, unpretentious surroundings. Would definitely come back - though finding a reservation again has been difficult! Book in advance!
author: Ankita K.

description: Not impressed, although I have to admit that service glitch colored overall experience. We sat down and ordered drinks, 3 minutes passed, server took our dinner order. 2 minutes later first course arrived before cocktail. When I asked about drink I was told "Oh they make those downstairs. I'll check." Drink arrived end of first course.  Cold squid noodle appetizer was tasteless. Was supposed to have battarga but if it did I couldn't find it.  Brussels sprout appetizer was very good. Tagliatelle cooked very well, in a nice sauce but not enough sauce to cover pasta. Red snapper was over cooked--not horribly, but just enough. Profiteroles for dessert were very tasty and original--ginger and no chocolate. So food mixed. Prices on high side, particularly for quality.
author: Tommy F.

description:
3.5 stars

Came here today 6/10 for my date's birthday, and opted for the 4 course $70/pp tasting menu. I wanted to try this place as it's by the same chef who started Frances (Melissa Perello), and that's also on my short list!

FYI - There are about 50 seats, so I'd make sure to have a reservation. 

The tasting is blind so if you don't want any spoilers, stop reading here :)

The tasting was Californian, with a farm-to-market feel. There wasn't really a theme so I would say it's more of a sampling of their items than a purposeful tasting. 

We had the following:
HOUSE BREAD: 5/5
-levain bakery house bread with toasted seeds, purple barley

APPETIZER: 5/5
-deviled egg w/ chile relish/marash pepper
-kampachi crudo w/ marinated kohlrabi
-butter lettuce with avocado, mandarin, togarashi & crème fraîche ranch
-fettucine with squash, taggiasche, and parmesan cream

MAIN: 4/5
-king salmon with potatoes, hazelnut
-wagyu beef with broccolini

DESSERT: 3/5
-chocolate soufflé tart, with salted caramel ice cream
-apricot cake with ice cream

SERVICE: 3/5
pretty slow service and long wait time between dishes. Also, it was not our anniversary, but his birthday.

Verdict: My date and I had a pleasant experience. The food met expectations, and had a good portion size. The dishes had great attention to detail and top-notch ingredients, but nothing particularly stands out or makes me crave for more.

It's not a restaurant I'd be super excited to come back given all the other upscale American-Californian options in the city. Maybe I'd come back to try their menu a la carte, but not any time in the near future.
author: Alicia L.

description:
I mark every 100th review of mine here on Yelp with someplace special like a Michelin-starred restaurant. For my 3800th review, one-starred Octavia is well worth the honors.

I had the pleasure of dining with a fun group of folks, all of whom opted for the $70 tasting menu. This is an amazing deal given how much you're getting; the entrees alone, on an a la carte basis, are priced in the mid-$30s. It's all the more amazing given that it's not uncommon to spend twice as much on food alone at one-star Michelin establishments here in the Bay Area these days.

We started with Octavia's take on a deviled egg. Absolutely savory and delicious, and what a way to begin a meal on an already-filling note. We were also served helpings of their house-baked levain bread, complete with warm butter. Soooo fresh and sooo good. On a normal day when I'm not pigging out, this could be a meal in and of itself. Of course, we kept asking for more, please!

If this wasn't enough carbs already, we were also presented with a dish of gougeres (fancy cheese puffs for the uninitiated) to share. Cue up foodgasmic squeals of delight all around, Meg Ryan-style in "When Harry Met Sally."

Next came a series of dishes ranging from sashimi to salad to salmon to steak. Even if these were tasting-sized, as opposed to full entree-sized, we'd have already passed the $70 mark in value halfway through. So much substance and so much enjoyment throughout. And as if all this wasn't enough, we chose two desserts: the warm chocolate soufflé tart with salted caramel ice cream (ZOMG!!!) and some profiteroles. 

We were beyond floored with the value and variety we got by choosing the tasting menu. It was truly a Michelin-worthy dining experience and I'm all WTF at some of the middling reviews here. The service managed to be professional and casual at the same time, and the entire experience was an approachable family-style affair over quality dishes. So, folks, leave your sour grapes at the door and just enjoy an evening's worth of conversation with a good group of folks. A job well done, Octavia!
author: Vincent L.

description:
Octavia is a lovely corner restaurant that boasts large windows, which allow for plenty of light during the day and gives great visibility of the city lights at night. The interior features beige walls, with wooden tables, dark shelves and chairs, earthy decorations, and unique plants. I noticed that our courses came mostly on dark plates during the daylight, and on light plates after dark. Perhaps coincidence, but the contrast was great for pictures.

I came here for a belated birthday celebration in June 2017. The person I was seeing at the time let me pick the restaurant, and I realized I had this one bookmarked for over two years, ever since I watched a segment on Chef Melissa Perello.

I wasn't fully aware of their tasting menu until we arrived, and my date and I were both excited to try that.

The tasting menu is ~$80, and consists of ten courses. These include six light courses, two main courses, and two desserts. Warm, fresh bread is also served with salted butter, and it certainly makes you eye the '$8 loaf to-go' line on the menu.

Their deviled egg is the most unique I've ever had! After having a few drinks prior, I was glad to start the tasting menu with a little spice. 

The anchovies we were served here were the first I had ever tried. I don't know if I like anchovies in general or if they were just great here, but the latter they certainly were. The salty fish paired with the cream on crunchy chips provided a great blend of flavors and textures.

I must say the the dish that was most surprising, and thus my favorite, was the corn custard. It's incredibly unassuming, and after receiving the fresh, colorful dishes that preceded it, I felt a little let down. Corn custard? I won't spoil it...you'll know what I mean when you try it.

The main dishes were cooked well, and also had a good blend of powerful flavors. A couple weeks before we came here I had started eating red meat again after about 9 months of passing it up, so the flavors of meat were exciting again.

The desserts were delicious, and of course, my second favorite part of the meal. I love the combinations here, and I felt the same amount of guilt eating their ice cream and berries as I did their ice cream and cake--none.

The service was slow, but it was pleasant and our server was knowledgeable and kind. The ambiance was likewise pleasant, and nothing seemed out of place.

Octavia made my belated twenty-second birthday celebration special, and I will never forget that experience.
author: Colby D.

description:
Solid. 

Food: opted for the tasting menu which for the amount of food you get, it's priced really well ($70). Pro tip: this comes with the house bread so don't order one separately like we did. Highlights of the meal were the primavera pasta and wagyu dish. The rest we not as memorable. Dessert was good. 

Drinks: they are beer and wine only. Tried one of the wine cocktails which I wasn't a big fan of. The wine we ordered though was really good 

Service: probably the worst part of the meal our server just didn't seem like he wanted to be there. Pretty low energy :/

Maybe we'll come back for the a la carte menu
author: Laura D.

description:
If you are in San Francisco Octavia is the place to go. One of my favorite parts is that we never had one specific waiter. The staff was very well organized and customer service was their number one priority. Their job was to serve you when you need it. 

The food was out of this world. The bread was crisp on the outside, warm and fluffy on the inside. I would recommend trying the deviled egg. This was a new take and the egg was cooked so perfectly. The fat from the yolk mixed with the spices creates fireworks in your mouth. 

Desert was no and after thought. The angle food cake and sorbet was delicious. Each piece by it self was impressive but put together was a masterpiece.
author: Tyler S.

description:
On this chilly Wednesday night, it was a toss up between Octavia and Frances. Both I've heard are delicious and special in their own little ways. After combing through the menu online, many "ooh's" and "aah's" later (mostly from me), and taking into consideration location of post dinner plans, we decided to dine at Octavia. I also knew which three desserts I wanted prior to getting to dinner. 

We started off with bread (so good you have to get this! Get two!), the chilled squid ink noodles and much raved about "deviled egg". The quotes imply it's not really deviled (because deviled eggs have a hard yolk). The egg is actually beautifully yolky and was delicious nonetheless. If you order the bread, this is a good time to eat it, slathering butter all over it and sopping up the sunshine on your plate. 

Moving on to dinner, we ordered the Day boat scallops, and Sonoma duck breast & sausage. I loved everything about the scallop dish. Absolutely everything was perfect. The flavors were well balanced, it had enough texture variance, and of course it was delicious.   

Since I don't eat pork, I had a small bite of duck which was a tad gamey but still really good. 

Now on to dessert. I knew which three I wanted and when I asked the waiter for which his favorite was he mentioned they were all good (of course) which made it even harder to choose. He seemed a little judgey that I was going to order three desserts (eh, ain't no thang) so I went with two and decided to get a third if I still wanted it (of course I still want it but decided against the third later, lol). 

We went with the Wildflower Honey crumb pudding and Winter spice profiteroles. Of the two, we enjoyed the honey crumb pudding much more than the profiteroles. 

I probably would skip the profiteroles next time. I found the ice cream to profiterole ratio to be quite aggressive and didn't think there was enough miso caramel to balance the dessert. 

Food coma ensues. 

Post dinner plans you ask? Yeah about that...

Anyways, wonderful experience overall, delicious food, and cozy little restaurant totally deserving of a Michelin Star. 

It's very unassuming from the outside, don't pass it up!
author: Shereen A.

description: Cafe-like ambiance.  They have a family-style tasting menu and it was perfect for us since I went there with my family.  Their vegetables are noticeably good and fresh, and I like how they added them to all the dishes.  The steak at end was ok.
author: Mariko Y.

description:
3.5 stars
Really loved the decor and ambience of the restaurant as well as the presentation of the food. However, I gave Octavia a 3.5 stars because I wasn't super impressed with the food. The squid ink noodle was really salty and I felt like the halibut crudo needed a little more flavor/ sauce. Everyone raved about the deviled eggs but I didn't think it was that special either. With that said, I loved their bread and how crispy the crust is. I would definitely recommend getting the pork chop because it was perfectly seasoned and cooked and the salmon was pretty yummy as well!
author: Linh N.

description:
I wanted to fall in love with Octavia. I have had some really wonderful meals at her big sister Frances. I also had some really wonderful meals in the restaurant that occupied the space before her. 

The food is gorgeous. Everything comes out looking like a mini work of art. My favorite dish, just based on aesthetics, was the blueberry parfait. It looked like an Easter egg, with delicate, brightly colored flowers scattered above a cloud of house-made yogurt. It tasted good too. Not too sweet, but complex enough and satisfying enough to end the meal right. My favorite dish, just based on flavors, was the sweet onion soup. They served it in two stages. It comes with the morels,crème fraîche and other yummy things already in the bowl, then they slowly pour the warm soup over it all. This creamy rich soup is fragrant an soothing. It was definitely a good choice. Everything we had contained at least one kind of vegetable, even my oyster. They were all super fresh and very high quality. So much so, everything was bursting with flavor. They really know how to develop a flavor profile at Octavia.

Service was good. They take a team approach. Everyone who we had contact with (there were at least four) was pleasant and efficient). They also seemed to pace things really well. I never felt rushed.

Octavia is not large. It manages to be intimate and cozy without feeling too closed in. Even though other tables are close, you feel like you have your own space.

So why not five stars? I'm not being picky when I say this. Octavia didn't wow me. It was an all together a good experience. Everything was solid across the board. Octavia met all expectations, but I didn't leave wishing for more.

I can still remember the joy my first dining experience at Frances was. Once we finally snagged a reservation, we had heard all the hype, and it still far exceeded expectations. Everything was delicious. I thought about that meal for days.

I will probably make my way back to Octavia, most likely to try the tasting menu hoping for a transformational dining experience.
author: Nicole M.

description:
3.5 years
I had very high expectations. We made reservations for a sat night and were quickly seated upon arrival. The first thing I noticed unfortunately was a faint smell of burning oil. It wasn't extremely strong but also not pleasant especially for a restaurant of this calibre. This may have been a byproduct of a hot day, poor ventilation and the open kitchen concept. 

My first impression was how expensive their wine list was. It wasn't surprising that quite a few tables brought their own bottles. 

Homemade bread is probably the best I have ever tasted!! Definitely get this. 

Deviled egg is an og on the menu. As others have mentioned, it's not your traditional prep. You get a whole egg that's a bit runny and sprinkled with spices. It was good with a nice spicy kick! 

We also got a pasta dish that came highly recommended. The pasta was a bit over cooked but I loved the zucchini and other vegetables. 

We ended with a sharing a petite sirloin medium rare. It was very good with interesting texture that almost seemed more rubbery like duck. 

The service was friendly and helpful especially when choosing dishes from the menu but the timing of dishes is horrendous. We would sit for 20 min at a time between courses. Even before our last course came out, I was ready to go home and go to bed. It felt like we were there for hours when the meal could've been finished within 90 min max. 

Overall, it was a nice meal with good service but the food quality and variety wasn't what I would expect for a Michelin restaurant. I would love to see more inspiring options on the menu, for example subbing out salmon with another local fish, etc.
author: Yin H.

description:
A few years ago, Octavia took the place of a restaurant I adored called Baker & Banker. At the helm at Octavia is Melissa Perello, renowned for one of my most beloved places to eat -- Castro neighborhood restaurant Frances. I was predisposed to love Octavia. 

Tempting as it sounded, we declined their 9-course blind tasting menu in lieu of our own "tasting" menu of sorts. We shared the Eggplant Soup which was sufficiently smokey, & the Squash & Blossoms which uniquely showcased the vegetable. The Deviled Egg was spicy on the outside & soft on the inside from being cooked gently; & still whole rather than halved. I didn't try his Trout appetizer. 

For our mains, he chose a medium-rare Filet & I had Dumplings with a cremini mushroom sauce & plenty of veggies like bitter greens, onions, & peppers. 

Dessert was Angel Food Cake with blackberries & corn ice cream. The cake had a sugary, crunchy brûlée on top. 

Everything we tried was prepared in an unexpected way but never at the expense of taste; these unique twists made sense & wasn't done simply for the sake of being inventive. I think both meat & non-meat eaters would be happy here; my vegetarian dishes were brimming with exciting textures & wonderful flavors. 

The icing on the cake of an already 5-star experience was our delightful waitress who made great suggestions & made us feel at home. If you haven't already visited Octavia, make it a priority to do so!
author: Fancypants X.

description:
I had Octavia bookmarked for a long time already (Since it opened.) and after hearing they have received their Michelin Star this year, I thought it was about time I hauled my a** to this restaurant. This restaurant is one of those "silent yet brilliant" types which just passes under the radar. Not as well-known as HOPR (House Of Prime Rib) or as "instafamous" as Mr. Holmes Bakehouse, they still managed to snag a coveted Michelin Star. 

Octavia is located on.....where else? Octavia Street in the Lower Pacific Heights area of San Francisco. It's fairly close to Japantown. There's plenty of street parking around the area. It's also only a couple of blocks from Fillmore Street which is good for shopping with all its good boutique shops. 

Upon walking into the space, I was immediately impressed with the beauty and professionalism of the restaurant. (As one would expect from a Michelin Starred place.) The ambiance is dim and cozy. This seems like the perfect place for dates. The open kitchen adds a modern tone to the space as does their Nest thermostat! (That's the first time I've seen a restaurant with a Nest. The geek in me was highly impressed.) Our server was polite yet not overly suffocating. We ordered 3 dishes to try and opted out of dessert because we just gobbled up half a cheesecake earlier. (Oh the agony of saving space for even more gluttony to come.)

Grilled Monterey Squid : This was a really good appetizer to share. The amount was good enough to share between two people. It doesn't say in the description on the menu, but this dish is quite spicy. I drank two glasses of water while finishing this. I have to say the butter beans were the star of this dish. They were crispy on the outside while still soft on the inside. We totally inhaled those beans!

Wild Nettle Tagliatelle : This was a good pasta dish if you love tagliatelle. The egg yolk mixed with the green pasta was perfect. 

Petit Filet : This is a great meat dish for those of you who like Filet Mignon. Our server informed us that this is a bigger cut and not the actual Filet Mignon. The serving size is is quite big. We ordered it medium and it was the perfect cook.
author: Julie W.

description:
Had an amazing meal at Octavia. My family was seated at 5pm with a reservation and we ordered drinks first.

Drinks were fantastic!
My favorite was the one I ordered: Carpano Antica Italy. Perfectly sweet (but not too sweet).

Food came up next. I really would have eaten anything off the menu - everything sounded delicious!
* indicates a favorite dish

STARTERS
"Deviled Egg" - This is in quotes on the menu because it is not a typical deviled egg. It's actually a soft boiled egg served on a chile relish (tasted like harissa).
Chilled Squid Ink Noodles: This was the only dish of the night that disappointed a bit. I only picked up on a lemony taste when I expected more flavor.
Cornmeal-Crusted Eggplant: Yum! Crispy, flavorful and light.
* Halibut Crudo: Quite a different dish from the rest of the ones we chose. This one was very refreshing, halibut was delicate and delightful!

MAINS
Pasta Alla Benedetta: Perfectly cooked pasta, with a creamy but light sauce.
* Coulotte of Wagyu Beef: Best dish of the night! Meat was AMAZING. I don't even know what else to say other than this was possibly the tastiest beef I've ever had! 
* Semolina Dumplings: Second best dish of the night. The dumplings are crispy on the outside and creamy in the middle. Sauce is wonderful, we basically licked the bowl clean... The sauce had a bit of a balsamic flavor which was just amazing.
King Salmon: Delicious salmon! This dish was not as memorable as the beef and dumplings, but that's really only relative because those were hands down amazing.

DESSERT
Wildflower Honey Crumb Pudding: Warm & comforting mmm! "Mixed berries" were only blackberries, but there were also delicious figs. When this dish comes to the table, the waiter pours the creme fraiche around the whole thing and it is quite the sight to see *heart eyes*
* Warm Chocolate Souffle Tart: Souffle + Tart?! I haven't had anything like this before and this nearly blew my mind. If you even slightly like chocolate - get this.
author: Maayan C.

description:
I can't rave more about this place! Our server, Chris was beyond fantastic. You know when your server is pretty genuine with his recommendations:) 
We did however go with the full tasting and I absolutely recommend it to the first time goers.

**( they will accommodate gluten free on their tastings) 

The food: 

Deviled eggs: Great. I'm not a huge fan of the deviled eggs but this was was awesome! 

The duck mouse and the carrots: two incredible dishes that would go incredibly well together. Flavors were different but then again similar in taste. Loved them! 

The fennel soup and the salad: we are going back for these two! Creamy textures on both sides but ah, so good! I don't even like fennel but if fennel tasted so good, it would be this soup! 

By this time we were full!! But the menu has to go on .. 

We then had the fish and the steak. Both were cooked to perfection however we liked the steak better. It was more flavorful. The fish was also nice and crisp. The side lentils, carrots and celery was also very tasty! 

The dessert: coconut sorbet all the way! ( this item is GF and dairy free FYI) and it was fantastic! 

Can't wait to go back!
author: Ghazal P.

description:
This place has one of the most reasonably priced tasting menus for a Michelin-starred restaurant ($70). The meal started with deviled egg and the house baked bread, then proceeded to the kampachi crudo and duck liver mousse, then the Dungeness crab pappardelle and kale salad, then the king salmon and petit filet and ending with profiterole and creme fraiche. 

Every dish was flavorful and you can taste the freshness of the ingredients.  Highlights include the bread, duck liver mousse and the petit filet.  I really appreciate a restaurant that can really elevate bread!  Service was quick and attentive and the ambiance is perfect for special occasions.  Highly recommended.  I left the restaurant feeling happy and very satisfied.
author: Andrew S.

description: Excellent customer service, delicious food and a cozy environment. Our server was personable, attentive, and simply awesome. The oysters were delicious. The sauce highlighted the protein perfectly. The pasta was inventive with yogurt as an Alfredo like sauce. The salmon was good, needed a bit more acid. And the angel cake dessert was delicious except for the ice cream. The matcha didn't work with the cake and strawberries. It was a fight of flavors instead of harmony. The in house bread was amazing and addictive. I wish they wouldn't charge for the bread. All in all a great meal. I will definitely be back to try their other creations.
author: Allie P.

description: Had a wonderful dinner here with some amazing food. The wait staff were all super friendly since we were out of town and bugged them about where else to eat, very helpful! We split a few courses and we're stuffed! The calamari - fresh and delicious. The mushroom soup - wonderfully seasoned. The salmon - perfectly crisped. Had to try the deviled egg that everyone was asking about - spicy! But very good, and certainly a must-have. Honestly can't find anything to complain about. Prices are a little bit up there but the cute setting and tasty food more than makes up for it
author: Vladi Z.

description: We came here for our anniversary and were blown away by the entire experience. The setting is on the smaller side so it's all around a very personal experience. We chose the blind tasting menu (only $70/person) and they were able to create a fully pescatarian option. The food was delicious and their staff went above and beyond to fill up wine glasses, water, ask if we needed anything else, clean up plates, etc. If you are looking for a California-style dinner with great food and service in a non-stuffy environment, this is the place.
author: Elise M.

description:
Had the chef's tasting menu. Amongst the 4 of us, it was a lot of food (3 girls who eat like birds and 1 guy). Every course was lovely however salmon was on the salty side. Steak was a bit on the rare side but my friends loved it. The vibe there is great and service was good as well. I would definitely go back once the menu changes again or try other things on the al la cart menu. The following were served for the tasting menu:
-Unlimited serving of bread/butter 
-DEVILED EGG,
-heirloom TOMATO
-halibut CRUDO (raw fish)
-SPINACH SALAD
-TONNARELLI (LOVELY)
-KING SALMON
-WAGYU BEEF
-3 different desserts
author: Jenny H.

description:
I would highly recommend making a reservation to this place. When I tried making a res for 3, the only options were for super late dinners (think 10:30 pm). But if you make a res far enough in advance (over a week in advance), you should be fine. 

First off, this restaurant is gorgeous. I love that you can see into the kitchen, and see all the chefs working. The ambiance is really great, too. They have the perfect music selection. The whole look of this restaurant ties in with the food. Everything is modern and elegant. 

For starters, we had the levain with butter and deviled eggs. The deviled eggs are pretty much soft boiled eggs. The levain was really good, and the butter defied gravity. For my main entree, I had the petit filet, which came with green beans and a cauliflower purée. Everything was cooked perfectly, and the seasoning was just right. I was disappointed with the desserts, though. I tried the honey crumble pudding and the profiteroles. The desserts were on the dry side, and I like my desserts sweeter.
author: Rachel H.

description:
The tasting menu is absolutely exquisite! For $70 per person, we were served with their famous leaven bread, "deviled egg," a cheese filled puff pastry, kanpachi crudo, pickled beets, chicory salad, pappardelle carbonara, petit filet, king salmon, warm chocolate souffle tart and winter spice profiteroles - so so sooooo worth it!! 

The service is serious and the atmosphere is just lovely - cozy and warm, almost as if we were in someone's dining room. I keep thinking about the winter spice profiteroles...
author: Christina S.

description:
Arrived right before my 9 p.m. reservation and was seated immediately on Saturday, February 3rd. The gentlemen/server who sat us was extremely gracious and friendly. He made sure my fiancé (who was on crutches) felt comfortable and was happy to accommodate. 

From beginning to end, the service was A+. Attentive, helpful and friendly. Sometimes at these Michelin rated restaurants servers tend to be pushy but not at Octavia. We arrived hungry, so quickly placed an order for Squid Ink Pasta, Deviled Egg, Duck Liver Mouse and two Petit Filets.

My favorite starter was hands down the Duck Mousse. We couldn't get enough of it. We wanted more. So damn good. The Deviled Egg was spicier than anticipated but good. The Squid Ink Pasta didn't necessarily wow me, but it good nonetheless. Now the Petit Filets were perfectly cooked. I had zero complaints. I was surprised by the portion. Worth every penny. The filet literally melted in my mouth. Mmmm.

We topped off dinner with a tiny birthday cupcake, angel food cake, and some tea. Overall, our experience at Octavia was one to rave about. Amazing food and service, I'd recommend it to anyone. 

ProTip: Make reservations wayyy in advance!
author: Jessica A.

description: Excellent neighborhood spot with a fantastic vibe and food and service. Definitely try their apertifs- nicely done.
author: Sumit C.

description:
Made reservations for a Saturday date night. Very happy with the overall experience! Greeted and seated immediately upon arrival. Staff was friendly and our server was very attentive, checked-in with us every so often and personable. 

We did the $70 tasting menu which included the bread, deviled eggs, halibut crudo, tomato arugula salad, pappardelle pasta, salmon, filet mignon, a chocolate tarte with gelato and apricot (?) tarte with gelato.  Pretty much everything was perfectly cooked and tasted delicious! Portions were a good size too - we left full. 

Space was rustic, romantic and cozy. 

Definitely recommend and would come back! One of our best dining experiences in recent memory.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Wasn't completely jazzed about this restaurant everyone is talking about. Wanted to love it, but I felt like when you're paying on the upwards of 40$ for a chewy filet mignon, it's just ridiculous. 
Nothing really stood out to me which would make me wanna return. A real let down for all the hype. 
Baker and banker in my opinion should have never left this spot.
author: Kehaulani K.

description: My husband and I ordered their tasting menu and we both agreed it was one of the best meals we've ever eaten.  The cost of $70 pp was well worth it.  Their portions were generous, the presentation exquisite, and the flavors were amazing from the first course to the last.  I can't say what course was our favorite, since they were all so good.  Also, we loved the casual and relaxed, yet sophisticated ambience.  Plus, the service was excellent.  The entire staff seems to work in unison.  Truly a memorable experience!
author: Paula M.

description: Delicious! Fresh and seasonal ingredient. Simple recipes but rich flavors. Great service. Reasonable prices. Can't wait to be back!
author: Shannon T.

description:
Octavia presented interesting flavors in the smaller plates but the entrees weren't very memorable. We were seated immediately with a reservation for 2 on a Sunday. There was a tasting menu available for $70pp - the dishes would be completely up to the chef so we decided to go a la carte. 

The highlight of our night was the corn soup which was amazing! We also got the deviled egg (salty), squid ink noodles (pretty good, al dente), and anchovies (awesome, served on a chip). For our entrees we got the king salmon (small portion, not the melt-in-your-mouth kind) and petit filet (not a lot of flavor, plate was deep so it was also hard to cut the meat). We got the crumb pudding for dessert which was scrumptious and a tasty ending.
author: Dani T.

description:
My newest love, Octavia.

This is one of the few SF one Michelin restaurants that I've been to that has proven themselves fully worthy of the star.  Octavia met all of my expectations and then some!

I've had them bookmarked for ages and finally got the chance when my friend came in from out of town wanting to eat something fancy.  We were going through the menu picking out about 5 dishes to order when our server same to the table to tell us about the specials.  That night they had a 10 course tasting for only $70 so our previous order went right out the window.  All the food that came out was exactly what I had been planning to order plus some spectacular mains and desserts.

Our menu from 12/2/17:
-Baked Levain: daaaayum this bread was so good, a must-order!!
-Deviled Egg: not too impressed, a soft boiled egg with some hot cheeto dust would've tasted the same
-Chilled Squid Ink Noodles: super light and refreshing
-Dungeness Crab Toast: like high end crab and artichoke dip, my friend's favorite dish
-Chicory Salad: dressing was a little strong, but balanced by grilled persimmon
-Tagliatelle: great balance of flavors and textures
-Petit Filet: steak is never a bad idea
-Scallops: perfectly seared 
-Toasted Angel Food Cake: came with an amazing roasted squash ice cream, like pumpkin x10
-Mint & Cocoa Eton Mess: loved the crunch in this dish, both desserts were amazing

On top of the great food, our server was super attentive and gracious.  I love it when your server is just as excited about your meal as you are (maybe more, in this case).  The one thing that happened that might have put a damper on my night was they took the leftover bread I was planning to take home away from the table.  By the time I realized what happened (dramatic "Noooooo!" with an arm outstretched, many people staring), he'd already made it to the back kitchen and threw it away.  Distraught, I told another server about what had just transpired.  I didn't really hear anything back from either of them, so I sulked about bread all through dessert.  When the check came, our server casually slides a brown bag across the table, "And here's your extra bread."  Bless you my fine dining dinner night's savior!!

Tips and Tricks
-TL:DR eat here, it is delicious and worth every penny
-Get!! That!! Bread!!!!
-If you want a weekend table, you should book a couple weeks in advance
-Do not skip on dessert
-We found street parking on Octavia 1 block down
author: Jessica L.

description:
Honestly I can say every dish ordered was amazing. I went with a group of 4 and we ordered most of the items on the menu. We asked about a tasting menu but its not available all the time, which was okay because everything was delicious. If they do have one later, I'm first in line to come back. 

Totally forgot the name of our waiter but he was great. All my friends and I love to food and we also love to capture the best photo of our food too. He was super nice and understanding. Thank you! We got the table by the windows, perfect lighting. The interior is very warm and comforting. Love the wide open kitchen.

We started with the house made bread with cultured butterorligurian olive oil. Yum! The bread was warm and soft with a crust on the outside. The butter was really good. We also got a bottle of red wine. 

Deviled Egg - We had two orders. Cooked perfectly. It's rich, I think ordering one myself would have been too much. 
Smoked mushroom 'POZOLE,' hominy, maitake, lime crème fraîche, popcorn - This is a soup. My friends said the popcorn and wanted to order but not knowing it was soup. They were so nice to split the soup for us in 2 settings. Great service again. 
Grilled CALAMARI - Was my favorite small/appertizer dish. Flavors on full blast. I can eat that everyday. Made with green farro, pancetta, sugar snap pea, kimchi, cilantro & mint. Wow!! Might have been my favorite dish all around too. 
Kale Salad - Toasted in hazelnut, aged parmesan, pickled fennel, strawberry. - I'm the biggest fan of kale but the dressing and strawberries was a great touch. Refreshing. 
House Ricotta TORTELLINI. A lot of flavor. The cheese was sound but I think the top part of the tortellini was a little hard.

Petit Filet - YUM! The beef was cook perfectly. Very tender and not over seasoned.
Seared Alaskan Halibut. Cooked with artichoke, fava beans and greens. The smokey saffron broth was yummy. Great add to the halibut but this might have been my least favorite entree. 
Grilled Pork Chop might have been the WINNER of the entrees. I am not the biggest pork chip girl but the brooks cherry, caraway sauerkraut, cipollini, mustard seed mixed together, gives it the best pork chop. It was amazing.

We shared dessert. Got the Wildflower Honey CRUMB PUDDING. Goes great with the                          crème fraīche, brooks cherry, honey toffee. Not too sweet which was perfect for us. Also, we were celebrating my birthday along with another friend. Complementary mini cupcakes from Octavia.
author: Sandy B.

description:
Octavia certainly lives up to the high standard of the San Francisco food scene.  On a recent visit to SF, we made late dinner reservations at Octavia.  First, the menu looked interesting and adventurous.  Second, the ambiance seemed modern yet comfortable.  Third, the reviews and the chef both sounded great.

Our server was very nice and somewhat helpful with the wine.  I didn't love the wine selection, since there were quite a few drier red wines by the glass (and I wanted something a little fruitier).

The food was great overall.  The house baked bread was wonderful (they gave us butter instead of the olive oil we asked for) and worth getting if you are really hungry.  We also just had to try to Deviled Egg since it's so unique!  My bf cracked his open first and it just melted right out, but mine didn't do the same and was slightly overcooked (it was gooey and tasty, but the yolk didn't run).  Next we moved onto the Little Gem salad and the Tagliatelle.  Both are completely worth ordering and both had a little crunch on top for unique texture and flavor.  The steak was also delicious, as well as the ending of Chocolate Souffle Tart.

All around, a great dining experience if you're looking to taste unique chef creations.  One other thing I completely appreciate about this place is that the chef was in the kitchen.  Sometimes they are in the back or off doing something else, but she was literally overseeing every plate that went out of that kitchen.  To me, that's a sign that I can recommend this place to others and they will have the same great meal as I did.
author: Jeannine S.

description:
Some great things: the eggplant with cheese, the fettuccini, and the amaaaazing bread. 

I got the beef entree, which was very good too, but not as good as the appetizers. My boyfriend got the (giant) pork chop and said it was good, but also not as good as the rest. 

One not so great thing: found an olive pit in my plate, not attached to any olive (ugh), and almost broke my tooth thinking it was an almond. 

ANYWAY, pretty good overall, would go here again, will try not to think too much about the olive pit.
author: Marta F.

description: Great service and good dining experience. Food was good. Seating was very cramped, and we could hear everything that our two neighboring tables were saying, but par for the course for a popular SF restaurant doing the best they can with the space they have. Definitely do the blind tasting menu to get a taste of the restaurant's palette. Reasonable price for how absolutely stuffed you are by the time you finish your meal. the plates just keep on coming. Also, kudos on maintaining a lovely restroom.
author: Jan Z.

description:
Phenomenal meal with an old girlfriend at a familiar location once called Baker & Banker, a place we had been one too many times. When dining with old friends, we sometime wonder how we first met. For us, it was because we both dated the same boy. At the time, he lived around here with a fancy math undergraduate degree at Stanford followed by MIT Sloan. We were smitten initially but when he stopped being interesting, we ditched him and the two of us continued our tradition of eating good food.

Octavia is a Michelin that offered non prix fixe menu, which is fantastic. It offered small bites with the prettiest presentation. We went for the fish and the deviled soft boiled egg. Bread was delicious. Because I'm currently on a diet - sugar free and carb free, I was hesitant at first but was seduced by the beautiful dark bread it served up. I cheated. I had a slice smeared with butter. Squid pasta with more egg and kale salad followed. Unbelievable salad. She then ordered another pasta dish (just kill me now already - the diet at that point has gone out of the window). She then asked for the duck entree - which turns out to be a substantial portion. We doggie bagged it. Finally dessert. There are quite a few excellent ones to choose from. She ordered two without even consulting me. I think she just wanted dessert as where she is from there isn't any. She's now moved far and far away in Southern India running an orphanage, and only comes back every six months. Octavia has it all - everything on the menu was terrific.

This is a fabulous place to hang out. I think a reservation is always a good idea but you can walk in if you show up before 6. I'd like to think Baker & Banker was good, but Octavia really takes it up a notch.
author: Victoria E.

description: Thanks jose for recommending this place.  It's actually really good with great service. The only thing I wasn't a fan of is the dessert chocolate soufflé tart. It's too sweet and the crust was so hard. It's like stabbing the crust to get a bite lol. I think if they can make the tart crust more thin and soft sitting on top of vanilla creme anglaise topped with vanilla ice cream instead of caramel ice cream and drizzle caramel sauce over it will make this dish yummy. My fav was the devils egg cooked to perfection, liver pate and the steak. Would I come back? Yes. I want to try their other dishes plus service is great. 4 star!
author: Christy V.

description:
On the 2017 Michelin List- One Star. On the 2017 SF Chronicle's 100 Best Restaurants List.

With these accolades, I had high expectations for my recent dinner at Octavia. Sadly, both the food and service were disappointing. I made reservations a couple weeks in advance, and they only had a 9:00pm slot left for a Saturday night. It was still busy when we arrived, but there were a few other tables available at that time. There aren't a lot of tables in this restaurant, so reservations are highly recommended. We were seated right away, and I tried:

-Deviled Egg (Dolcini Farm Egg, Fresno Chili Relish, Marash Pepper, Spice, $5, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=uF3DbuzfyJ5FlBqoeo3zTA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=E2yNcLVPSA534-GzYBR72w&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Super bland, and only slightly reminiscent of a deviled egg. The egg was cooked perfectly for a soft boiled egg, but I didn't think the other components to this dish were flavorful- skip!
-Chilled Squid Ink Noodles (Cortez Bottarga, Fennel Vinaigrette, Lemon Argrumato, $7, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=iMKjDPyXSF-uO9DnfflAnQ&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): The texture of the noodles was great, and I loved the al dente chewiness and lemon flavor. However, this dish needed more salt, and the bottarga and fennel combination didn't do anything for me. I probably wouldn't get this again.
-Baby Eggplant (Cucumber, Watercress, Sesame Labneh, Toasted Seeds, Lime, Mint, $14, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=M39vQFdountfRfyMDHVPIQ&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Yum- this was one of my favorite dishes from the meal. The eggplant had an awesome char, and was cooked perfectly. I loved the way all the flavors in this dish worked together, and just wished they had more eggplant versus cucumber. Highly recommended!
-Wild Nettle Tagliatelle (Bacon, Egg Yolk, Green Peppercorn, Parmesan, Pangrattato, $18, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=kzCeNtMcI9LownoQzwLSkw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): The fresh tagliatelle was great, but tasted bland to me. I also didn't like the bacon bits and would have preferred larger pieces of bacon- skip!
-Sarah's House Baked Levain (Purple Barley, Black Sesame, Dark Rye, $2, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=0pR5iWQ4dEio0BjBIgPNTg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): I didn't like this- the grains/flavors didn't work for me. Skip!
-Bone In Ribeye (Served w/Daikon Pickled in Ponzu, Ponzu BBQ Sauce, Porcini Mushroom Butter, Red Pepper Aioli?, $100, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=LNe0gt4wgMgnaahwPF6qVw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=5jSNvVikF0V0aoFnJXMbmA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): We were all super excited to hear that the rib eye was available that night as an additional entree off the menu. We ordered this for an entree to split, and were looking forward to our steak. We waited, and waited, and waited. After finishing our other plates and sitting there for at least 20 minutes, we flagged down our server to follow up on our order. At that point, he explained that the steak takes 45 minutes to prepare since it's a thick cut. Uh, thanks for telling us that AFTER the fact- it was really lucky that for once we weren't rushing to get somewhere by a certain time. He went to check in the kitchen and assured us our steak was coming out next. 5 minutes later he brought us warm plates so that our cold plates wouldn't cool off the hot steak too quickly. 10 minutes after that, we finally get our steak, and our plates are cold. The most frustrating part about this whole situation is that our $100 steak was UNDERCOOKED. We ordered it medium rare, and the steak came out mostly rare. I don't mind my steak rare, but my friends had to send it back. There was no apology from our server, or acknowledgement that the steak was undercooked. The steak itself was really good, and we loved the flavorful crust as well as the great sear. However, we didn't care for the sauces since they were too salty. The butter didn't have much flavor, and the pickled daikon was so salty and tart that it was difficult to eat. 

I should have asked to speak to the manager about our steak, instead of leaving the meal unhappy and disappointed. I was just shocked that a restaurant of Octavia's caliber would have such a terrible server who doesn't know how to communicate a 45 minute cooking time, nor how to apologize for a long wait time for an entree, nor how to acknowledge/apologize for an undercooked steak. I will never be back to Octavia, and hope this review saves others from possibly missing any events due to waiting for their ribeye.
author: Amy D.

description:
It is not quite Frances, but it's pretty good. We went on a Tuesday night and had an early reservation at 5:30 p.m.--that was lucky. When we arrived, most of the tables were empty, but within half an hour the place filled up. I got the beef osso buco; it was fantastic. She got the duck breast and liked it but didn't love it. The bread and butter are both very good, and you should get as much as you can.

I've forgotten what we ordered for appetizers, although they were both pretty good. One was a salad, and it was good. The menu changes frequently, and the current menu doesn't have what we got then.

A note on the service: it was great at the beginning (when we were the only ones in the restaurant). When other people started showing up, the servers kept coming over to our table like they were trying to rush us. But when we took our time, they stopped coming over to our table for a while and seemed to forget about us. 

Lastly, I spilled an espresso all over the table. They were kind enough to give me another one for free.
author: Matt C.

description:
One of the best Michelin Stars for the price that you pay! I came here for Mother's Day with my parents. The portion sizes are reasonable larger than what you receive from most Michelin star restaurants and the décor is warm and cozy. The service here is also extremely friendly and make you feel very welcomed, not at all uppity like at some other fine dining places. Highly, HIGHLY recommend coming to Octavia before it gets even more popular!

[Dinner]
I ate so much and enjoyed every bite, where do I even begin! The menu is split into small bites, smaller plates for sharing, and then larger entrees. Our server recommended about 2 large entrees, three small plates, and three small bites for our group of three. I can't remember a few of the dishes given my stomach moves faster than my brain, but here are the ones that left an impression: 

Deviled Egg - Highly recommend - I don't normally like deviled eggs but this one had a very unique flavor. 
Chilled Squid Ink Noodles - My favorite small plate, great al dente noodles. Highly recommend!  
Avocado Salad - I really enjoyed this dish, the vegetables and flavor combination left my mouth feeling very fresh.
Grilled Calamari - This was ok. I didn't really like the texture of grilled calamari but wanted to give it a try. Would recommend picking a different dish. 
Tortellini Dish - Can't remember the exact name of this dish, but this one was my favorite of the group! Great flavors and extremely well made pasta. 
Alaskan Halibut - The fish was extremely well cooked but I didn't find anything super special with the dish. However, great alternative to the more meat heavy entrée options. 

[Desert]
I had the warm chocolate soufflé tart. TO DIE FOR! Definitely recommend ordering this amazing desert. 

[Wine]
I had a great pinot noir pairing that my server recommended.

[Service]
I'm so embarrassed that I probably had too much wine that night since my parents don't really drink so I had the whole carafe to myself and the next morning when I read my receipt I realized my mental math was wayyyyy off. However, I emailed the restaurant to try to retroactively fix my tip bill because my server was super awesome, but unfortunately they never called me to let me fix the bill. If anyone from Octavia sees this please respond to my email and give me a call! 

Great place to bring parents, dates, friends etc. Come support a restaurant also run by an awesome female head chef!
author: Alice Z.

description:
Mr. C and I went to Octavia for our new year eve celebration dinner because it's one of the hottest new restaurants in SF. 
We sampled the new year eve menu ($100 per person) with wine pairing ($60 per person) plus some oysters. The food was worth the money but I personally didn't think they did a good job with the wine pairing (hence -1 star). Service is polite and courteous. 
Our favorite dish is the wagyu petit fillet. It is probably the best fillet I've had (given I am usually a ribeye girl who loves tomahawk from Alexander's, bone in ribeye from Mastro's, Peter Luger and aged ribeye from cut), this is a pretty bold statement. It was tender, juicy and magical! 
Our second favorite is the Star Route little gem salad. It truly is a little gem. Very refreshing and light. We love it! Risotto and Tagliatelle were too salted... and dessert was nothing to mention about. 

Since i am so in love with the wagyu petit filet, I will definitely go back! Maybe I will stick with my little gem and petit filet and other items I have not tried next time. 

Ciao!
author: Sasha Z.

description: Had a most enjoyable evening in this restaurant. Great atmosphere with a very lively inner city vibe.  Everything we ordered came out terrific and there is an extremely efficient and friendly staff. We will be going back for their tasting menu that gives you a sampling of most everything on the menu.
author: Lorin S.

description:
We came to Octavia on the Saturday during the Thanksgiving weekend. We had a reservation but it was not very busy when we arrived early and got seated right away.

The menu is small-ish but switched up every few weeks. Between the time I made the reservation and the dining -- 3 weeks apart -- several items on the menu had changed. But you can still see the old favorites like Deviled egg, Squid ink noodles, and petite fillet on the menu.

We were lucky to find street parking, but would not count on it. The dining room is dimly lit and much darker than the kitchen in the back, intimate but you may need your cell phone flashlight to read the menu later into the evening.

We started with the old-fashioned house cocktail (vermouth and zesty orange peel). Husband loved it.

We had the following appetizers
- Levian bread: with fresh churned butter; bread has a slight sourdough taste, very spongey with a nice heavy crust
- Oysters: fresh, with very light Japanese-style seasoning
- Squid ink noodles: refreshing and lemon-y, not too memorable
- Grilled squid with butter beans and avocado: favorite dish of the night, spicy and crunchy and all sorts of deliciousness

and entrees:
- Ling cod: perfectly seared fish with very crispy skin, and the sweet red potatoes addition is, although not the best, at least interesting
- Ricotta remoulade: cheesey dumplings shaped like small matzoh ball, a very very heavy dish and I didn't enjoy the heavy flavor combination

Dessert menu looks great (especially that eton mess), and it has a very promising locally-sourced tea selection. We ended up skipping dessert as my "ricotta remoulade" was wayyyyy toooooo heavyyyyyyyyyy.

Overall food is delightful -- appetizers are outstanding, and some hit and miss with the entrees. I recommend coming here if you'd like to try simple dishes that may surprise you, and keep an open mind as some may work extremely well, and some not so much.

Service is good. Wish our server can better explain some of the items. Not everyone -- aka country bumpkin me --  knows what's a "remoulade" or "malfatti" or "rillette"...
author: Shijie F.

description: I have been to Octavia twice. The first time I absolutely loved it, especially with their vegetables. As a meat person, I don't usually like vegetables, but I finished every bit. The second time was not as impressive, it's majorly due to we have one people in the group can't eat steak (which was very good the first time) and we switched to pork chops, which none of us have finished. It made us full very easily and it honestly did not taste great. Definitely try their steak instead of pork chop in tasting menu.
author: Leo L.

description: The food and the service were really good.  We shared everything - deviled egg, chilled ink squid noodles, home baked bread ( amazing), eggplant soup that was absolutely delicious.  For the entree we had the pork loin, it was a good size for us to share given all the other dishes we had.  For dessert we had the angle food cake and the honey crumble. The cake was light and fluffy, served with sweet corn ice cream. The crumble had minimal sweetness. If you like sweet, the crumble is not for you. I love desserts that are not very sweet so I really enjoyed it. It was a great experience, we will definitely be back.
author: Gaurav P.

description: My coworkers hosted a dinner at the chef's table last week. They took our bags and held them in the back. Upon leaving they were unable to find one of my coworkers bags that had several dollars worth of items- and brushed us off. Upon us reaching out to get the bag back, we were ignored and redirected several times. Finally, we were put in touch with the director of operations who showed no remorse and said no coworkers had taken the bag that night (not true). I'm extremely disappointed in this experienced and feel violated. Not only were our items taken from us but the response from the restaurant staff was disgraceful. Really "classy" Octavia
author: Sydney M.

description: Maybe we just ordered the wrong things, but the tastes and flavors really weren't anything spectacular.  We weren't super hungry so didn't go for the tasting menu which may have been the difference, but with 4 dishes we shared and two dessert, I think that's enough to get an idea of what is going on.  The desserts were actually the stand outs.  Angel food cake was better than expected, and the chocolate molten cake was quite good.  That chocolate brittle really was something special.  If we only went for dessert than this might be 4 stars, but realistically if I were to think of the whole dinner, it was just an A -OK experience.
author: Anh N.

description: I've been meaning to try this sister restaurant to the acclaimed Frances for awhile now. Glad to say it was worth the wait, for the most part. Go for the tasting menu as it was just the right amount of food and we got to sample a good selection. My favorite was the deviled egg and king salmon. Service was friendly and efficient, though a tad on the "isn't our food great!" side. My only complaint is how crowded the place can feel. I dislike it when you are constantly aware that your neighbors can hear everything you are saying, and vice versa.
author: Edward L.

description:
I had this place bookmarked for a while now and when we were planning a dinner with a friend who lives right around from this place, I finally decided to check it out. I called the week before our dinner and right away got a reservation for three at 6pm. 

On the day I showed up way early, but the waitress sat me right away and I waited for the other folks in my party while sipping on a delicious Chenin Blanc. Once everyone was here, we were so busy catching up, that it took us quite a while (two rounds of delicious bread) to actually place our food order...there was so much to catch up on. But what I really appreciated - and which made all the difference - is that at no point in time did we feel rushed to place an order. (Usually, at places that are hard to get in, the restaurant is eager to get you in and out.)

The food was delicious (especially the deviled eggs), but what I really loved was the service. Our waitress was funny, entertaining and so engaging that we left the place feeling like kings. Seriously, I loved every moment of my stay here. Plus, the atmosphere is cozy and I really felt that they loved having us as their guests as well.
author: Uli B.

description:
The decor has significantly improved from the days of Baker& Banker but the service and food was a miss.

We decide to share all our food and ordered the salad, tagliatelle and petit filet.

The salad and pasta came out at the same time. I started with the salad as I wanted but the pasta got cold in the mean time, very annoying. Both dishes were good, nice flavor combinations, creative ingredients and good sharing portions.

The steak was a disappointment, it was cut up before being sever, not something I ever expect from a fillet, and it was chewy. We've made better steaks at home, in this case it was not the preparation but sub par cut of fillet. 

Loved the ambiance of the place, the service and main course isn't going to inspire me to go back.
author: Inga W.

description:
A great example of innovative American cuisine.  We took an early dinner before the theater and enjoyed our meal immensely.  We opted for the tasting menu gives you a range of their dishes.  We started out with the deviled egg, which is a six minute soft boiled egg spiced with Fresno chili.  Great juxtaposition on the tongue with the warm egg yolk and bright chili spice.  We also had a stuffed cauliflower which was filled with a mouse like stuffing.  The tasting also included a beef terrine bathed in beef consommé and crispy salmon with lentils. Our entree consisted of beef wagyu and paparadelle pasta.  Dessert provided a miso pound cake with black sesame seed ice cream.   All the dishes were memorable.

Nice selection of domestic and imported wines, many can be purchased as a carafe pour of about a 1/2 bottle.  Service was attentive and not rushed. Overall definitely worth a visit and a return.
author: Michael B.

description:
Octavia was not stuffy at all and everyone was welcoming and attentive. We had the tasting menu with the wine pairing. Every wine paired nicely with each course. 

To be brief, I won't describe each course. I enjoyed all of the food. I really appreciated the use of fresh vegetables in almost every course. The use of the vegetables and other ingredients prevented some of the items from being "one note" and provided textural contrast as well. I am one of the few people who do not like Salmon but theirs was delicious and the best I've had. 

I would return if in the area again and do recommend to others.
author: Richard B.

description:
Snag a reservation!

Love the little farmhouse feel of this place. Food is interesting, varied, and SO delicious. My husband and I shared everything and loved everything we ordered.

Great wine selection and I really enjoyed the ambiance. Not great for parties larger than 4 but perfect for a date night.

Looking forward to trying her other restaurants!
author: Sarah G.

description:
Great venue, awesome service, and decent food!  I can see why it has a star, but I think a change in the entrees would make it even better.  

Venue: My friend and I came here for a Saturday 5pm reservation- the place was pretty empty given the time, but it started filling up around 5:30.  Lot of sunlight in the restaurant, and the minimal decor with wood accents added a nice touch to the intimate setting without being too fancy.  

Service: very impressed with the attention the staff provided!  I noticed they would frequently walk by to see our food status so they would know when to clear the plates away or not / fill waters / refill wine glasses.  They were also kind enough to be mindful of our timing (we told them we had a show at 7pm and therefore needed to leave around 6:45)- they originally said that the tasting menu (see below) would take around 2 hours but they were very attentive to make sure the dishes came out relatively quickly without rushing or making us wait for a long time for dishes to come out.  Very thankful of them for that!

Food: we decided to do their tasting course ($70 per person), which consists of around 8-10 dishes, some available a la carte but also some exclusive to the tasting menu.  Overall, these dishes tended to pack a lot of flavor, though at times it came across as too spicy for my liking (still not used to strong spices like cumin, etc.).  However, btetter to be too flavorful than bland, I guess?  Some highlights include:
- Deviled Egg (fresno chili relish, dolcini egg, marash pepper and spices) ($5) - eats / looks more like a poached egg, but I found the flavor combo with the cumin and pepper to be a rather unique one.  Bit spicy for my taste, but thank god for the rich runny yolk to mitigate that.
- Anchovies on chickpea poppyseed sable cracker and creme fraiche ($6) - the nutty flavor of the cracker surprisingly went really well with the salty anchovy (which I love!).  I did have a few instances where I bit into the cracker and nearly dropped anchovy on myself because the whole topping slid off the cracker, but I can live with that.
- Tagliatelle (eggplant and sherry ragout, sundried tomato, fried caper, pangrattato) ($18) - one of my favorites!  Usually not a fan of eggplant but it added an earthiness to the pasta dish.  Also liked how it was a lighter pasta dish; most of the time it has a heavy sauce or something that leaves me in a food coma for the rest of the day.  Definitely would recommend as an a la carte option.
- Dark chocolate cake with salted caramel ice cream and drizzle (tasting menu only) - good dessert for chocolate lovers; the salted caramel and dark bitter chocolate go well together.  The dessert is a bit rich, so maybe not for those who want a heavy dessert to end the meal.  
- Summer Berry Eton Mess ($10) - another favorite dish!  If you want to end the meal on a light, refreshing note, go with the Eton Mess- the meringue gives a good crunch to the soft whipped cream and berries without adding anything too much sweetness, and the meyer lemon ice cream is always a great way to add acidity as a sort of palette cleanser.  Between the two desserts, we finished this one.

I'd say the two entrees we had (petit filet and wild king salmon) were good, but not as memorable as the other dishes listed above.  Nothing really wrong with them, and the proteins were cooked well, but I guess the flavors seemed a bit muted / muddled / weren't as impactful as the others; hence my review doesn't give Octavia a perfect score.  

Overall, loved the venue and service.  Foodwise, we favored the appetizers, smaller plates, and desserts over the entrees.  If the entrees were as flavorful and creative as the other dishes were, I might have given Octavia 5 stars.  But I can see how Octavia deserves a Michelin Star and would gladly come back again and again.
author: Audrey H.

description: We went to Octavia on our 4-year anniversary and thought the food was incredible. We did the prix fixe menu and I am so happy that we did. Now, this was a while ago, but I am still gawking at their deviled egg and their corn ice-cream. Fantastic menu all around and very kind and non-pretentious staff.
author: Jacob W.

description: First time at Octavia for my birthday. It was fantastic. We had the tasting menu which was 10 Dishes. They were by no means small and I was super full by #6.  Standouts were the deviled egg w Fresno Chile, cream puff w savory filling, tomato salad, flat Noodles w Parmesan, salmon belly, and the tri tip. The bread is fantastic. Great wine menu. It's a small intimate setting. Sure wish it was closer to San Jose
author: Farah A.

description:
I really enjoyed our dinner at Octavia. The food was great, and service was friendly/casual, yet refined.

The four of us opted for the tasting menu ($70) and wine pairing ($45), which did not disappoint. The menu is a "surprise" and includes various items off the à la carte menu as well as some daily specials. It was shared family style and portioned out very appropriately - all of us agreed that we had just the right amount of everything. The wines were delicious and pared well with the food. Food highlights: snap peas, pasta primavera, wagyu beef, salmon and dumplings, chocolate dessert. My only complaints were that the cream cheese puffs at the beginning seemed like they should be served hot, and the dressing on the spinach and strawberry salad was pretty sweet, but that's more of a matter of personal preference.

Service was fantastic. The waiters knew what they were serving and were fun to interact with. They went above and beyond their job of serving food and explaining the dishes. The restaurant ambiance is casual and comfortable, but it definitely does get loud. It was hard to hear each other at our table of four. 

Overall, it was a great experience and we will definitely return. Happy to have found a nice and casual restaurant to add to our go-to list!
author: L R.

description:
TL;DR - merely adding to the barrage of positive reviews.

Get the tasting menu and it'll be more than enough to fill up two people!

Th service was impeccable and even though they closed at 10:30, nobody ran over to kick us out
author: Crystal Z.

description: My boyfriend and I came across Octavia when we were on vacation in San Fransisco. We asked Siri for Michelin starred restaurants nearby and Octavia popped up. I know I know for these types of restaurants they are usually booked but we crossed our fingers and we got a dinner reservation at 9pm that day. We got the chef tasting menu which was $70 per person (awesome deal!!). We tried about 9-10 different items from their menu and each dish was explained to us when it arrived to our table. Wait times in between dishes were not that long which I was extremely happy about because I was super hungry that day from touring all of San Fransisco. From beginning to end food and service was spot on. We will definitely be back!
author: Kendra H.

description:
We had reservations for our anniversary, and we enjoyed a really excellent evening. 

The atmosphere was inviting and warm, the service excellent, course pacing perfect (we did the tasting menu - highly recommended, this is, in our opinion, where the best value and opportunity to explore the kitchen's creativity is at), and the food was so obviously prepared with care and thought that we couldn't help but be impressed beyond our already-high expectations. 

Thank you, Octavia!
author: Dan P.

description: We had the halibut crudo, duck liver mousse, and chicory salad to start and shared the duck breast for the larger entree. For dessert, I polished off the warm chocolate soufflé tart even though I was already so full. Everything was yummy but maaaan that bread and butter was to die for!! They bake their own bread, and the butter tastes European (churned by Larsen Creamery in Portland, they said). I would go back just for the bread alone!!
author: Amy Y.

description:
Unfortunately not even close to our expectations.
Got seated straight away, and after few minutes the waitress took our order. 
The table right next to us (keep in mind tables here are really close to each other), got seated and their waiter was taking the order from them. He mentioned that in addition to the regular menu there is a blind tasting menu! Wait...what?? Our waitress never mentioned that to us!!
We decided not to mention anything to our waitress, and see how the rest of the evening is going to go with service.
I am not going to go into details with the food, but after going to quite a few one Michelin star restaurants, this was truly disappointing.
Even though the food looked good on the plate, both starters were a bit too spicy for our taste and main courses were nothing memorable, actually, lamb dish was really bad. Chewy and a thick layer of fat around it.
The only great thing was dessert.
For all of you who get the option of ordering the blind tasting menu, it is actually mix of random things from the actual menu! 
Once the place is busy, it's really loud and hard to talk.
Beautiful restaurant, great decoration, but not the service or the food are anything that we would love to came back for.
Octavia you are going straight to the bottom of our one Michelin star restaurants that we visited so far.
author: Bianca G.

description:
If you asked me what I thought (which I guess you are at least wondering since you are reading this), I would answer with: "It's OK". Decent but didn't love it....

I started with a glass of dry vermouth as an aperitif - perfect and light to pair with anything and everything. Such as their lovely hearth-baked grain-y bread.  When they come by to ask if you'd like some more delicious grainy carbs, the answer is a resounding yes!

For the food:
+ chilled squid ink noodles - most interesting preparation I've had that I think really works flavor-wise, but again no wow factor or something I must have time and time again
+ duck - good portion cooked a perfect medium rare, though sliced too thick. My favorite of the night (duck is always a fan favorite in my books)
+ fish - pretty normal. cooked perfectly but bland so I had to eat this with bites of the rice mixed with various fillers and sauces
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Five-stars -- as long as they don't raise their prices...

Octavia is the new kid on the block when it comes to Michelin-starred restaurants in the SF Bay Area. My friend and I hopped on the Octavia train on a whim because it was the only Michelin starred restaurant which an available last-minute reservation that was not $300 per person.

AMBIANCE:

The Ambiance is great. Fancy casual, just as most of SF is. Most of the patrons skewed older with a few young professionals thrown into the mix. The restaurant is quite small with minimalistic decor. The dining room gets quite dark as the sun goes down, which makes it a bit romantic, but I was there with a guy friend and it didn't seem to make it too awkward. There's a soft buzz of chit chat but no boisterous storytellers which is probably because there is no bar at the restaurant, so it's just for dining with a side of wine. 

FOOD:

The food is amazing. What I really liked was that we were allowed to get the set menu AND order a la carte. Some places don't let you do that so it was nice that we were allowed to order a few oysters in addition to the rest of the meal. The meat was cooked well and the food was fresh. I was full by the end of the meal which is always a good sign (and sometimes doesn't happen...) I got the chocolate cake for dessert and it was just what I needed to close out my experience at Octavia.

DRINK:

The wine selection is alright. We got a bottle of red burgandy. It was okay. I think it was $78 or so, which is reasonable. I prefer a larger wine selection with exotic and fine wines. That's not what you'll get at Octavia but that's okay. I was still happy with the experience because the food was bomb and the prices weren't crazy.

SERVICE:
I was seated right away even though I was 20 minutes early. The server took my wine order and brought some bread and butter (costs extra) while I waited for my friend to arrive. The servers weren't chatty but were friendly, so I have no complaints about the service.

Great date place to celebrate something special or just because. Not too over the top and reasonably priced.
author: Maya G.

description:
What a truly fantastic experience. 

There is a chef's tasting menu for $70 but everyone at the table has to participate so I didn't get to do that. I would definitely come back for this, however. I can't imagine not liking anything served here after everything I tried on my first visit. It'd be worth it. 

What we ordered:

Oysters: the pickled green strawberry topping was interesting. not sure it was my favorite but it was still worth trying.  very meaty oysters too!

Deviled Egg: still having dreams about this egg... never knew I could love an egg so much. easily my favorite dish on the menu. I want to learn to make it!

Squid Ink Noodles: the lemon agrumato!! the flavors! also want to learn this recipe.

Red Gems: one of the most refreshing salads. that green goddess sauce...

Caramelle: one of the more rich and heavy dishes, but incredibly flavorful. the combination of ricotta, pistachio and brown butter felt almost sinful...

Alaskan Halibut: best cooked halibut ever. the turnip was perfect and the smoky saffron broth was something else. I could probably take a vat of this to go.

Grilled Lamb: I felt like I just ordered a massive turkey leg at a renaissance faire. It was kind of too meaty of a plate for me personally, but it was still fantastic. I even ate the meat off the bone because it was the best part (no shame). would probably order something different next time though...

Chandler Strawberry Float: the lime soda. A++ best float would float again

Toasted Angel Food Cake: the rose ice cream was lovely. the angel cake was crispy on the outside and fluffy inside, as it should be. very fruity, like a cobbler, but better.

I would actually come back here just to order all the desserts; I caught glimpses from the neighboring tables and everything looked incredible. I would also come back during the day just to take better photos of the dishes (but that's just me). 

Vibes were very hospitable. Felt spoiled. Making late-night reservations was a good way to go because it was quieter and we got seated immediately, served quickly, and pampered. Overall, it was very comfortable, homey, but still luxurious.

Thanks, Octavia.
author: Nikki I.

description: Surprisingly good food (you could not tell from the outside)! Loved the deviled egg, the spicy 'baby potatoes' appetizer (forgot what it's called!) and the filet the most. It's a small place and make a reservation well ahead of the date before you go.
author: Mendy H.

description: The service was perfect! It made me realize how much nicer dining out can be when the service is fantastic. The food was great.
