I was surprised by how amazingly good some of the simple seeming dishes were, like the soup, snap peas and potatoes. The ambiance is as described, elegant yet relaxed. My favorite kind of vibe. I'm looking forward to my next visit.
author: Anne P.

description:
Great location, in the Baker & Banker space. Very cozy and warmly decorated. Great service. Reservations made about a week in advance at 5pm for three.

MUST-HAVES: Their free sourdough! Petit Filet, Profiteroles.

* Free sourdough - 5 stars
Their bread is amazing. Spongy, yet the crust has a nice crunch. Love the fresh sourdough flavor too.

* "Deviled egg" ($5) - 3.5 stars
Soft boiled egg with very interesting spices. I'm not usually a big fan of deviled eggs so I actually liked this better!

* Beet salad ($12) - 3 stars
Fresh ingredients, but not a standout in terms of beet salads.

* "Pan con tomate," burrata ($13) - 4 stars
Loved the bread + tomato - gave it a zesty flavor. Salad wasn't too impressive.

* Petit filet ($38) - 4.5 stars
Delicious matsuke broth, tender meat. My favorite entrée.

* Pork loin ($35) - 3 stars
The pork was a bit dry, and the flavors didn't stand out to me.

* Eggplant ($25) - 4 stars
Tasty soft eggplant. Similar to the "Pan con tomate" in that it's served with bread, tomatoes and cheese.

DESSERT
* Crumb pudding ($10) - 2.5 stars
The cake is dry - I didn't love this.

* Profiteroles ($10) - 4 stars
Very tasty! The bread around the ice cream was a tad hard. Still a great dessert.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Made a reservation and came here with a coworker for a somewhat early weekday dinner. She chose the place, not me. 

We ordered:
1. Deviled Eggs
2. Chilled Squid Ink Noodles
3. Grilled Calamari
4. Black Cod
5. Duck
6. Bread

Let me just say, nothing blew me out of the water. Le bf had been here before and he warned me that it wasn't going to be good. He was totally right. I can't speak about the deviled eggs as I do not like and won't touch them. My coworker who does like deviled eggs said that they were good, but then again, she says everything is good. We were both really looking forward to the squid ink noodles. They came out basically flavorless. There wasn't a lot of seasoning on it, and everything tasted bland. The grilled calamari was good. It wasn't overcooked. The cod and the duck were both cooked well, but I didn't like any of those dishes enough to want to order them again. The bread is bread, and I always like bread, except for the super healthy kind. 

Overall, with the food quality/taste and the price that we paid, I wouldn't come back and I don't recommend people come here. Your money could be better spent elsewhere. I have to say that Octavia is another restaurant in SF that I don't think deserves a Michelin star.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
For whatever reason, I wasn't expecting much from Octavia. Maybe because it's one of those restaurants that's named after the street it's on, and that doesn't give me much confidence in management's vision. And on first glance, it seems pretty standard. It has a rustic farmhouse vibe that grew on me over time. "It sure is cozy in here," thought I, by the end of the meal. 

I started my meal with the "chilled squid ink noodles, cortez bottarga, fennel, lemon agrumato." It was certainly an interesting app, yet nothing that I would write home about. (I don't really write home about food, I just Yelp about it. I guess in some sense the internet is my home. I guess in some sense the internet is now EVERYONE's home. That's a strange thought.) 

My main course was the "roasted Savoy cabbage, sourdough dumplings, creme fraiche, toasted carraway." This dish knocked it out of the park. Serving cabbage as the focal point of an entree was bold, dangerous, potentially calamitous, but proved ingenious. The crunchy, salty cabb contrasted perfectly with the warm, pillowy dumps. This dish may be my top of 2018 so far.
author: Oliver S.

description:
We got seated right away because we had a reservation so that was nice.

The food was pretty good. We got the kampachi crudo, Dungeness crab papperdelle, the duck and the petit fillet entrees. In general the food was pretty good, there were a lot of interesting flavors, but was missing a little bit of umami. Not sure how else to pinpoint what was missing.

I love luxury and all, but it drove me crazy that they collected and replaced the plates and unused silverware after every single dish... I guess I'm more of an "eco-luxury" kind of gal. 

All in all a pretty good experience, but not enough to entice us to come back.
author: Maymie C.

description:
Amazing. Best food we've had in SF.
Everything was cooked perfectly. The wait staff was attentive and thoughtful. The presentation of the courses was beautiful. The flavors were surprising and refined. Beautiful wine list. And they went above and beyond to celebrate our anniversary. Do yourself a favor: save up and make a memorable evening here.
author: Mandie K.

description:
One of my go-tos. Soooooo good!
Last time I was there, they had a steak that was meant to share for two. My brother and I ordered it, and devoured it. The service is friendly with personality here. I like that. It is a simple, comfortable spot, with seasonally appropriate flavors. 
Everything I have ordered here has not disappointed. 

Tip: If you like deviled eggs, this is a treat, but you may think you'll get a bit more for the price. 
Tip: Parking is surprisingly not too bad if you are dining before 7pm.
author: Amy O.

description: I thought the food was okay. San Francisco sets a high bar, and unfortunately Octavia just wasn't that great. In comparison to higher end restaurants, it's relatively inexpensive and the food portions are huge, but it just failed to impress me. Sorry.
author: Lisa F.

description: Oh my, this place is heaven. Great atmosphere and Amazing service. The food and wine pearling delicious and original, fresh and tender. I only dream of going back soon.
author: Martine P.

description:
Every bite was fabulous - perfect experience: 
I was in San Francisco visiting my 25 year old son who lives a few blocks away from Octavia restaurant and works downtown. I made a reservation at Octavia because it is located nearby in Pacific Heights and is listed on the San Francisco Chronicle top 100 Bay Area restaurants. It was everything I was hoping for in a special dinner, we both loved everything we ordered. 

The service was fantastic and attentive throughout with multiple servers. The menu was explained to us as it was our first time there including that everything is intended for sharing, which is what we did. We weren't sure about the portions or how much to order so went with a few items to start which turned out to be more than enough even though the dishes appear delicate. 

We decided in the moment that we both were fine without drinking alcohol that evening. We shared the hearty bread, one deviled egg, crab salad, white bean and mushroom soup, duck breast entree, and chocolate soufflé desert. It was certainly more and enough for me but even my 6'2" age 25 son said it was completely filling for him in addition to being delicious. The price was only $103! I expected to pay more for this type of ambiance, service, and especially the delightful food. We appreciated the evening lighting which is just right.

Every item was a lovely surprise with depth of flavor and varied texture. I look forward to returning when I'm back in San Francisco and my son said he will be bringing a date to Octavia in the near future.
author: Tania A.

description:
This is a Michelin star restaurant. Keep that in mind. The service and decor were great, on par with restaurants in that tier. However, the food wasn't imo. We got squid ink, lamb tar tar, tuna salad (raw tuna), steak, lamb, salmon.

One thing you do see is they do take really fresh ingredients. The tuna had these plums in it and they were one of the sweetest plums I've had.

The only dish I thought that really stood out was the lamb tartar. The decision to make it ground lamb was very smart and the toast that you spread it on was delicious. Would highly recommend that. It's got some acidity to it, so the gamey taste really doesn't hit you.
author: Victor D.

description:
Have you ever had that restaurant you always pass by, but have been lazy to actually go inside and figure out what it was? That was me with Octavia. I have always passed by after driving home and thought it looked so cute, but never had the balls to actually try it out. After finally coming here, I was so glad I followed my intuition. Little did I know that it had amazing reviews on yelp, but it also earned 1 Michelin Star this year? :O 

Drinks: 
To start, they have a very extensive drink menu - I ordered the house cocktail (kind of tasted like a negroni) and the house wine (Cuvee No. 10) and both complimented the food very well from start to finish. They do have corkage though if you don't want to spend 10+ per drink.

Food: 
The food is kind of a la carte and can be shared in groups. The top and middle row of the menu are smaller bites, while the bottom is entrees. 

In terms of starters, the deviled egg, chilled squid ink noodle, little gems salad, and tagliatelle tonnato (tuna pasta) were good, but the little gems were the star. I had so much hopes for that deviled egg :( 

For main courses (which are huge and can be shared) - their steak was cooked very well and was so flavorful and their chicken hash also had distinct qualities to it--the corn consistency might be weird at first but its flavorful. The fish had great skin to it, but didn't match the star power of the other dishes. In terms of dessert, the short bread had an asian inspiration with it and the corn ice cream had a very distinctive but great flavor if you like corn that is. 

Pro Tips: 
-Reservations are highly recommended or you can try waiting. 
-It can get a bit chilly inside, so I suggest keeping a jacket with you! 
-The Bread service is endless and so tasty, don't feel nervous to ask for more bread. 
-They offer corkage for $25 
-The waiters are really tall yet super nice and kept the drinks pouring! 
-There's a lot of parking rules in the area, so be careful where you park!
author: Eric Joseph D.

description: Wonderful food!  We ordered the tasting menu and every dish exceeded our expectation!  It was an extraordinary experience!
author: David H.

description:
Another restaurant in the bay area to make it into my top ten! My friend recommended this restaurant to me a while ago and I finally decided to try it. I loved the décor and atmosphere of the restaurant. It kind of has a hipster mid-century vibe with a lot of wood accents. 

The food here really impressed me. Service was pretty good too. They switched waiters half way through the night when it became really busy. 

The chilled squid ink noodles- the portion was really small, but for the price it's worth trying it. I wish it had slightly more flavor but I liked the lemony taste.

Pan con tomate with burrata- mmmm I LOVE burrata cheese with a passion so naturally I liked this dish. It was refreshing and perfectly light in flavor.

Grilled petit filet- OMG this dish was mindblowing. The meat was tender and flavorful and the matsutake broth was magnificent. Loved the trumpet mushrooms too. They complemented the meat perfectly.

Bouillabaisse- included scallop, shellfish, and potatoes. Loved this dish too! Everything was cooked perfectly and the sauce was just amazing. 

Oysters- I'm not a huge fan of oysters, but they are growing on me slowly. These tasted fresh and loved the sauce on them.

Toasted Angel food cake- Don't leave without trying this dessert! It was sooo good. Slightly crisp on the outside and moist on the inside. It was to die for. 

The house white wine- I think this was the most disappointing out of everything we had here. I completely regretted ordering a bottle. It just wasn't good at all. 

Can't wait to come back and try some of their other dishes!
author: Mai Y.

description:
Perfect 30th bday dinner!  We did the tasting menu, which was very reasonably priced for such a well-renowned restaurant ($70), brought a bottle of local wine & enjoyed every bite!  Beautiful setting, relaxed ambiance & ideal noise volume for a private dining experience.  Our waitstaff was knowledgable, friendly, timed the course deliveries perfectly & never detailed our table too quickly.  All the little extra bits felt above & beyond; they had a special Happy Birthday card on our table waiting for us & brought a candle on our dessert too!  

The homemade bread & butter was so warm & wonderful!  

We loved their light, deconstructed take on the deviled egg.

The duck mousse was expertly done, not to rich, perfectly tasty!

The carrots were sweet & hearty.

The Dungeness crab pappardelle was rich & flavorful.

The salmon with greens was DELICIOUS!

The Escarole, Radicchio, Frisée salad was bitter, but the creamy dressing curbed the harshness a bit.  

Then the king salmon & petit filet were out of this world.  

The desserts rocked -I don't even know what they were besides everything I wanted. (:
author: Lindsey D.

description:
My husband surprised me with dinner here on Tuesday night for our anniversary.  We arrived about 30 min before our reservation and they seated us right away.  They had a sign on our table wishing us a "Happy Anniversary", that was a nice touch. 

There is no bar but the restaurant had a lively energy...felt like a relaxed but slightly upscale happy hour vibe. No music, just the sounds of people chatting it up.  It wasn't even packed, there were still several empty tables when we arrived.

We ordered the tasting menu for $70/person.  They were able to accommodate my list of food allergies which was a bonus.

We really liked the food... Everything tasted fresh, was perfectly cooked, with attention to detail on the plating...

Actually, on second thought dessert was kind of meh.  We appreciated the candles to make our anniversary feel special and we ate it but nothing to get excited about... 

So aside from the mediocre dessert everything else was above average tasty.

We felt they were creative with ingredients and seasonings, but also that there was no flow between the dishes. It's more of a random sampling of the menu than a "tasting menu" where you kind of expect the dishes to be presented in an order with a purpose.

I probably would have given this meal 4 stars but I had to take away a star based on the service so I'll go over my reasons for that...

Service was great at the beginning and started going downhill by the end. At that point the restaurant was full and at times people were standing along a side wall awkwardly waiting to be seated.

The tables are tiny so they cleared the bread when they served our entrees but I only ate one slice and would have liked to eat more of what they claimed to be their "famous bread" with my entree.  (I can't be the only one that waits to eat the bread with the delicious sauces on my plate...)
But then I felt awkward asking for more as they just intentionally took it off the table.  I almost asked if they could put a couple slices in a to-go box but I figured they would charge us for a whole loaf so I just kept my mouth shut. 

Also, they had our wine in a decanter by the kitchen and at some point just stopped filling our wine glasses. I finally asked for more wine, and our server straight up told me that we had already finished it.  I'm definitely thinking, "hmmmm, I see it...it's right over there..."  So again, I felt awkward, but I didn't want to argue with him...

Eventually he found it and brought it back and refilled our glasses but at that point we are eating desserts so that was terrible timing. They should know that the 1994 Cab we saved for this special occasion was meant to be drank with the wagyu beef course, not the dessert!!  

I thought this was a pretty big mistake for a restaurant at this level.  At that point they should have apologized and maybe even offered to comp a dessert wine... Just my opinion.

Overall great meal. It was really fun, enjoyed the night out, and we both walked out saying, that was great but we'll probably never go back. We would rather try something different next time. Or go back to one of our favorites...

Total cost was just under $250 with 2 glasses of bubbles, corkage and all those city taxes.
author: Tami G.

description:
Octavia is new and upcoming. We were lucky to get a reservation for dinner. Glad that I got to try this place before swarms of people knowing about it and trying it. Lucky me! There is street parking and the restaurant is on the corner of Octavia. The restaurant is quite cozy and I had good warm vibes of this place. It's beautiful as well. Keep in mind, this restaurant is small, so reservations are recommended. Service was excellent and the food was so good. The ingredients are fresh, farm to table...even more of a plus. We had a bottle of Cab. Surprisingly, the bottles that we chose, they were out of. The recommended bottle still went well with our food. We had the:

Oysters from Morro Bay with white mayo sauce
Halibut crudo - fresh fish with some greens - refreshing
beef tartare - Can't go wrong with this...with bread
Duck breast - medium rare -cooked nicely with corn and other greens. Healthy and nutritious.
Steak - cooked nicely
Lavender ice cream with profiteroles - you can smell the lavender ice cream. So calming!

I can't wait to come here again! YUM!
author: Jennifer G.H. W.

description:
Mediocre food for steep prices.

For appetizer, we got the squid ink pasta and kale salad. Overall would skip the appetizer and go for the mains. 

The squid ink pasta had no flavor. Literally was just a black colored noodle with some olive oil. Was expecting some form of seafood in it but there was none to be found. 

The Kale Salad was also overdressed and quickly became uninteresting in flavor. Perhaps adding tomatoes or some citrus would mix it up a bit. 

Main: 
Kabocha squash- the squash was good but the "green" curry was nothing more than coconut milk/ cream
Duck leg- Duck was overcooked and they outdid it with the carrots 

Dessert:
Honey crumb pudding - a misnomer. Was more like a big unsweetened cupcake with preserved fruits. Not worth $10.
Black sesame Eaton Mess- was a mess... the meringue was too heavy on the heavy cream and had no added value to the meal(but calories). The toffee was too sweet and overpowered any sesame flavor.  The only good part was the ice cream.. so I basically had a table spoon of ice cream worth $10.

Overall hugely disappointing for the $$$, but will give them credit for the entree's presentation.
author: Linda K.

description: I went with a group from Nomnery and we all ordered the tasting menu. The food was absolutely great and the service was wonderful. I especially liked the pasta dish and the egg that was one of the appetizers. Main courses of beef and salmon were just terrific. The salmon was cooked perfectly, which is so hard to do with fish. Also their homemade bread is wonderful and they serve it with soft butter ( I always hate when restaurants serve bread with cold butter and you can't spread it).  Our group stayed a long time and talked, and the staff was very chill about us staying so long, especially after we had waited half an hour for someone who never showed up. All in all, we agreed that it was a fabulous evening dining experience!
author: Ruth L.

description: Absolutely one of the best food experiences I've had. The tasting menu was spectacular, well paced and flawless.
author: David M.

description:
Lots of ups and downs, 3.5 stars. Had the tasting menu. First, it's not a tasting menu. For two, it was full-size portions of 9 dishes, most on the menu. An outrageous amount of food for $70 per person. 

Highlights: pimiento cheese gougeres, the "deviled" egg, fantastic bread, hamachi crudo, salmon collars with perfect snap peas, a spinach salad with amazing roasted strawberries. We felt done at this point, but the food kept coming. A heavy portion of creamy pasta. A 20-minute pause, then two full (and dull, flavor-wise) entrees, filet and more salmon. Twenty minutes more, and then two ok desserts. 

Pacing was the big problem. Tasting menu didn't feel composed, waiter didn't know what was coming, which made it feel like it was what they needed to use up in the moment.

Waiter apologized for the long pauses and interruptions with a loaf of bread to take home. Odd as we said we were traveling multiple times. 

Enjoyed several dishes, but too many great places in SF to try to go back
author: Lisa B.

description: My husband and I dined at Octavia last August for our anniversary.  To start we had their bread, Squid Ink Noodles and their Deviled Egg.  The deviled egg surprised me, it was presented nicely however I was expecting it served traditionally and not half boiled?  For dinner we ordered their King Salmon and Petite Filet. Our dinner was delicious however wasn't memorable.  Not a first choice restaurant I would recommend.
author: Jann B.

description:
I have a long list of places I want to go to with friends in the City. Since I bought my friend some Hamilton tickets (not for free), he treated me out to dinner as a sort of thank you present. I know my friend isn't the most into food like I am so we didn't go all out on the food end of things. 

We started with the chilled squid noodles and the deviled egg. The chilled squid noodles was interesting - i've never really like noodles cold before except for in Chinese food. The thick noodles were good, but not a love. The deviled egg was great too - the spices were great! The duck breast was great - well made and juicy. Love my veggies with it. We ended with the warm chocolate souffle tart which if you know me, I love chocolate. Definitely a great ending to the meal. 

Protip: reservation!
author: Nina Y.

description:
One of the best meals I have had in a long time. From the butter to the main it was amazing. 

Get the calamari and salmon.
author: M C.

description:
Without a doubt, my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. The environment is perfect, you can see the chefs at work, and the service is always impeccable. Also, always fun to frequent a restaurant that is owned by a female chef. Make sure to grab reservations ahead of time!

Must try: deviled egg, squid ink pasta, oysters. + complimentary house made bread

Octavia has innovative, down to earth dishes. The menu is seasonal, and I always have a hard time deciding what to order. If there is duck on the menu, I recommend ordering that as your entree. 

For two people, I would split a small plate, a salad, an entree, and a dessert, so that you can try one of every course. 

Great for: date night, visitors, celebrations. If you are looking for a fancy night with a group of people, book the chef's table.
author: Lauren A.

description:
One of my really good friends took me here for my birthday (thank you Gary!).  He's so silly though.  He made reservations through Open Table and when we got there, they didn't have it on file.  Gary then realized he booked it for the wrong day.

Anyhow, the restaurant took us in.  The host said I was too cute to let be disappointed.  Joke! We sat down and ordered almost everything on the menu.  Okay! Before I forget, our waiter was sooooo hot and well mannered, but I think he's into men.  My kind of luck, right?  He was super nice! We asked for drink recommendations and he kept coming back and making sure we were okay. 

My favorite dish- squid ink.  Do it!!!

I love that it's a Michelin rated so we got to say we tried it.  Am I dying to go back?  No, I think I'm okay for right now.
author: Thuy V.

description:
As a recent one-Michelin Star restaurant I was excited to experience Octavia. We made a reservation ahead of time and arrived pretty early. The restaurant doesn't really have a space to wait so we ended up going to a bar around the corner and returning. The atmosphere is sophisticated yet casual and I appreciated the minimal and cozy interior.

The wine menu is pretty extensive and we got one bottle. As for the food, we went with the chilled squid ink noodles, braised beef osso buco and star route beets. 

The portions are small so I think sharing three items between two people is good. I love squid ink so the chilled squid ink noodles sounded interesting but were EXTREMELY salty. It tasted like salt pasta with a hint of lemon zest. We sent it back because we couldn't finish it and even the replacement one was a too salty.

Not sure if something was wrong that night but while the presentation looked great, most of our food was on the saltier side. We kept drinking wine and bread and didn't want to keep sending back our dishes, but at this price and stature, I definitely expected more. 

The most decent dish was the beef osso buco and the only thing I fell in love with here is their bread which was warm, crunchy, and delicious.

As for the service, it was good and they were attentive and knowledgeable. Not sure if I'll ever be back though.
author: Amanda K.

description:
We were a party of four, walk-ins for an early dinner on the day after Thanksgiving.  The food was excellent (Dungeness crab appetizer, "deviled egg," ling cod, kale salad, tagliatelle) and the service superb.  Every staff member we encountered (and there were quite a few!) was unfailingly responsive and pleasant.  

What a lovely atmosphere too, with exposed brick, hardwood floors, golden candlelight-like lighting, and Frank Sinatra on the speakers.  

Not expecting to get a table, we were underdressed. This is one of the (few) places in SF where a puffer and jeans look a little too casual.  The pricier menu should have tipped me off about that. But no matter, we were welcome anyway! :)
author: Erika S.

description:
On those rare occasions where I find myself dining at a place with potential delicious food, yet, I find it underwhelming. 

FOOD
-"DEVILED EGG," was more like a poached egg with chili flakes. I can make this myself. Disappointed and I don't see what is the hype. 

- Chilled squid ink noodles was probably the best dish of the night. Great combination of savory and tangy.

- Kale salad with avocado was a great starter. Simple and light. 

- Atlantic Scallops was salty that it ruined the whole entree. 

- Early grey tea profiteroles tasted quite refreshing after all that heavy salt from the scallop entree. 

While the food did not shine as much as the open kitchen and spacious floor plan. I do however dig the sophistication and elegance décor at Octavia.

One thing that annoyed us during dinner was the staff. They were not helpful when we asked about the menu nor were they knowledgeable. On top of that, you could be a little friendlier toward my Bestest! 

Overall, I will give this place a second try, but not anytime soon.

3.5 stars!
author: Owie N.

description:
Melissa does it again....I live a block from Frances, but decided to venture out to try her other restaurant.  The food execution was spot on.  Flavors blended well and discerningly.  I actually like the menu at Octavia better than Frances.  Staff at Octavia is much more accommodating anf friendlier.  The restaurant is roomier, and view of the kitchen and staff working is fun to watch. 

For visitors, parking is really tough in neighborhood, so walk, take public transport or Lyft over would be best.
author: Cookie D.

description: I just went on a weeklong trip to California and this was my favorite place. The food was interesting, colorful, and fresh. I opted to try 4 small plates as opposed to an entree because I couldn't just pick one dish. The "Deviled" Egg was perfectly cooked with a silky runny yolk and the chili lended some spice but not a scorching heat. The Squid Ink Noodles were dressed with fennel and lemon which took them to another level. The Crudo dish was beautiful I didn't want to eat it...but I did. Very fresh and clean. The Charred Snap Peas was favorite dish. I've never been more excited about a vegetarian dish before. The peas were tender bursting with sweetness and I could've eaten a whole bowl of the house ricotta. I usually skip dessert but I tried the Sassafras float - a fun play on a root beer float. This one had a sorbet, ice cream, gingersnap cookie and sassafras soda. It was wonderful - different textures and the ice cream and soda weren't too sweet. Very well balanced. Also, you can't skip on the house bread and butter. It's he cheapest thing on the menu and it's delicious. The staff was very friendly and were knowledgeable about each dish. The vibes inside are very chill. Plenty of rustic wood and metals, and they play indie music. If you're in San Fran this place is a must.
author: Joe U.

description:
We ordered 2 oysters, chilled squid ink noodles, smoked bodega bay black cod, saffron tonnarelli, the duck and the petit filet. 

There's a huge wine list! BF chose a pinot and we just shared it between the 2 of us since I only wanted a few sips. The pours here are quite generous!  

We started off with Octavia's complementary bread and butter which is delicious. It came out nice and warm. 

The oysters were good, but nothing exceptional. 

We both enjoyed the chilled squid ink noodles! The portion is tiny but packs a lot of flavor! 

The smoked black cod was our least favorite. It was our first time having smoked black cod and it was good, but out of all the dishes, this one lacked depth and flavors and the portion was small for the price. 

The saffron tonnarelli with dungeness crab, fennel bouillabaisse, and espelette aioli was rich with an amazing seafood flavor!! 

If there's one thing you have to get from Octavia, it's the DUCK. IT'S AN ABSOLUTE MUST. I ordered it medium (medium rare always tends to be a bit too under for me) and this was perfect. Loved the butter beans and salsa verde that came with the dish as well. Best dish by far!! 

BF said the filet was ok, but not amazing. One thing that was annoying was that our steak knives weren't that sharp, so it was difficult for him to cut his steak. 

For dessert we had the toasted angel food cake with elderflower ice cream. AMAZING. The perfect ending for a terrific dinner!

Service was on point as well. 

Reservations were easy to make on OpenTable. Great restaurant for a date night!
author: Noelle H.

description: Came here for a corporate event. Upon arrival was greeted by the waiter who took my bags. After our meal, they couldn't find one of my bags and the waiter brushed me off. When I followed up the next day I found out they never answer their phone. After reaching out to the person via email who coordinated the event I was again brushed off until I followed up again. Finally the Director of Operations reached out to me saying there was no proof they had my bag and that all the employees denied seeing it in the first place. I am extremely disappointed at how this was handled and it caused me to lose over $300 worth of clothes and shoes.
author: Zach D.

description:
A wonderful place to enjoy your dinner with great food and the cozy atmosphere.

We ordered Little Gem and Mushroom soup as appetizers. (By the way, the bread is not complimentary. And we were not that hungry, so we didn't try it.) The soup is so great that we couldn't stop our spoons. It's creamy and rich of variation. The salad is a great mix of fresh lettuce and baby broccoli with anchovy. Both of them are really appetizing.   

The entrée were Duck Breast and Trout. Both are tasty, especially the Duck Breast. Highly recommend! The delicious sauce combined with sweet grilled baby carrots and the soft duck breast...mmm...And there was even some sour flavor of little mandarins as a great stimulator for refreshing.

Last but not least, we had a great dessert--Crumb Pudding--as a perfect ending. (Oh, I also had an Italian Amaro as well.) The bread itself is with a little bit salty that really surprised us because it created a great balance with the sugaring fruits (on the top) and the warm liquid crème fraiche. 

Besides the food, the open kitchen makes the whole space more dynamic. And their service is very friendly and considerate. Waiters and waitresses always do something for you just right. Love this restaurant. Definitely worthwhile to giving it a try.
author: Anne C.

description:
Made last minute dinner reservations for 10pm on a Saturday night. When we arrived, I was so shocked at how full this place was. Every table was taken. Good sign.

Ordered:
x "DEVILED EGG," fresno chile relish, dolcini egg, marash pepper & spice - Super delicious! Really, really enjoyed this poached egg. 
x chilled SQUID INK NOODLES, bottarga, fennel vinaigrette, lemon agrumato - I was a little hesitant to order this because the lack of ingredients, but I was pleasantly surprised with the flavor. Though, a little dry, I liked this dish.
x HALIBUT CRUDO, green olive, pickled fennel, blood orange & toasted grains - Probably my least favorite of the night. I'm use the thing slices of fish for crude, but this was more poke style which I didn't like too much. The sauce was pretty meh as well. I'd skip this.
x Trout (can't remember all the ingredients since they changed the menu) - Trout is usually a hit or miss. It either tastes like plain salmon or it tastes amazing. This place knows how to cook their fish.

Service was just so-so. I felt like the server was more annoyed than anything that she had to serve us. She barely checked up on us...

I did like Octavia, but not sure if it's enough to come back. The experience just wasn't that memorable. For a michelin rated restaurant, I expected a lot more.
author: Anna M.

description:
Review Title: "Don't make a fuss and just eat your god damned thrice cooked fish!" or "Sous vide misuse, and other crimes against fish and pork"

Summary: Octavia probably has good nights and bad nights, but for me this the was the worst restaurant experience I have had in San Francisco in 20 years. 

The details: 

I ate at Octavia last night with my wife and two old friends we had not seen in years. It was shaping up to be a great night, until the main courses arrived. 

My pork loin had been sous vided and arrived soft, bland and tepid. It had a weird kind of space food quality that gave it the consistency of firm tofu. While I was not thrilled by this, the surrounding vegetable and mushrooms -- which were also tepid -- were pretty tasty. I didn't say anything because I did not want to derail our evening and eating some room temperature pork is not the worst thing in the world. 

My wife's salmon also came out at the neglected bathtub temperature that I assume they sous vided it at. Luke wark salmon is kind of gross and when she sent it back we all assumed that the kitchen would quickly cook up a fresh one. But instead they came back a couple minutes later having reheated the old peice. Stop and think about this for a moment: this fish had now been for a bath (sous vide), fried, cooled down to room temp and then refried. Gross. When my wife suggested that was not really up to standard for a restaurant that takes it self so seriously, the server (not our original waiter) said it would take 20 minutes to remake in a clear effort to say "don't make a fuss and just eat your god damned thrice cooked fish!" 

When my wife said not to bother and that she would just skip the rest of the meal, our original waiter said he would have it out in 8 minutes. Our meal was already disrupted at that point. But when the new fish arrived it was indeed hot -- it had been baked at the core of the sun for those 8 minutes and was totally overcooked. 

We tried to salvage what we could from the meal, but we were really shocked when the manager insisted that we pay for the drowned, neglected, thrice-cooked salmon. Moreover, he or she did so without even having the courtesy to come and speak to us. 

To be fair, our waiter was very nice and I actually felt sorry for him but if there was a zero star rating on Yelp, Octavia would definitely deserve it. I hope someone there has a long tepid bath in their sous vide and comes out with a better attitude towards food and customer service.
author: matthew S.

description:
Despite Octavia having one Michelin star, the food was unimpressive and way too overpriced (I paid about $75 per person). The dishes I ordered tasted average but was twice the price of what I would typically pay. Hence, I gave this restaurant such a low star rating because it just isn't worth the money at all. Servers were very nice, but it doesn't make up for the food. I would NOT recommend this restaurant. 

The following was what I ordered:

Deviled Eggs: not the traditional deviled eggs. It's simply a boiled egg with spices sprinkled on layered on top of crushed red peppers. Very salty but was decent

Cold Squid Ink Noodles: kind of bland and nothing special

Smoked Mushroom Pozole: was more of a soup dish that was more for show than taste

Grilled Pork Chop: very generous portion of pork chop but it was very expensive. It didn't taste anything special so I wasn't impressed at all
author: Derek L.

description:
Been here a few times now and each time has been a wonderful experience. The service and the food are always impeccable. The decor is modern yet cozy. A nice, casual atmosphere for high end service and food that can be enjoyed on any day or for special occasions.

The waiters are friendly and knowledgeable about the dishes and the wines to pair with. My drinks are always filled and there is never a dirty plate, silverware, or crumb left on the table. 

The food...OMG the food is AMAZING!!! Beautiful, creative, and flavors are out of this world! Definitely deserves a 2nd Michelin Star!
author: Kitta K.

description: I had high hopes for this place because we love France, but it was pretty average. We got the squid ink noodles, deviled egg, the petit filet, and the gem salad. Surprisingly, the dish we liked the most was the gem salad, the rest were pretty meh and very pricey for the portions.
author: Shabnam E.

description: Had a lovely experience at Octavia. Our servers were helpful and succinct and gave us some nice recommendations. The pappardelle and artichoke appetizers were great and my salmon entree was delicious. Bonus points for ambience. Will definitely go back!
author: DeAnna C.

description:
Fancy, fancy! I love the aesthetic and vibe of Octavia!

The husband and I came here for our 6 monthiversary. I usually dislike dimly lit restaurants (how unromantic, I know), but I was okay with Octavia! Actual restaurant space is pretty small and each party probably stays ~2 hours from start to finish of their dinner. There was about a 15 minute wait in-between each course for us. Service was great but they forgot to give us bread! I figured they didn't do that anymore until we were a few courses into our meal and I saw The Bread Guy walking around for empty tables to put bread & butter on. Not a huge loss but I was curious to try it! 

MENU (from last week)
-chilled squid ink noodles - Not terrible but not worth the hype. It's pretty much what you'd think cold noodles would taste like with a bit of lemon juice. The husband was hoping that the noodles would have a nice chewy texture but they did not. 

-burrata salad - I love burrata! Definitely recommend this salad if you do too. 

-sunchoke soup - our favorite dish this evening! It was creamy and full of a roasted but sweet flavor. I especially liked the yogurt. 

-potato gnocchi - nothing in particular stood out to me about the gnocchi, but I love potatoes so I would say it was a good staple to have. 

-"Osso Buco" - I had no idea what this was so I googled it. It's basically a stew made of veal shank. It was very hearty but a little too much on the salty side for my taste. The sweetness of the squash helped but it wasn't enough to balance everything. The kale also adds a sour taste but I wasn't won over. 

-Pork Loin - meat was surprisingly juicy, unlike most of the other Yelp reviews I saw. This dish had a good balance of sweetness and saltiness.
author: Grace J.

description:
Definitely a 5/5 and one of the best restaurants I've had the pleasure of going to in San Francisco. Everything we got, whether it was the Deviled Egg, squid ink pasta, fettuccini or black cod was absolutely spot on. I feel like these higher end restaurants typically get too hyped for me a lot of times and I feel let down, but this was not one of those places.

Not only was the food awesome, but the service matched it as well. Our server was attentive, funny and helpful for recommendations on the menu. In the end, I really loved everything about this place. Atmosphere was spot on, food was excellent and service was top end as well. I'll be coming back for future special occasions!
author: Matt B.

description:
Loved everything about this place! The ambiance, decor, lighting, friendly staff but most of all, the food! We had the Black ink Pasta, deviled egg, Salmon collar, steak and Pork Loin. Everything was amazing! The pork Loin came with some smokey veggie, I think it was smoked mashed aubergine. So different! 
For dessert I we had the chocolate cake (Which tasted a bit burnt) and some marenge, creme fraiche mess. It was very good! 
It was my bday celebration and the staff was nice enough to give me a little card, and of course a yummy complimentary pastry for dessert!

Only drawback, as usual, restaurants are too god damn noisy in this city. Why are people so loud?!

Will be back!
author: Jo L.

description:
Octavia had some very nice highs a couple little lows.  Our group did not arrive at the same time, but they were nice enough to seat the first two in our party.  Unfortunately,  after we were able to join we were given menus and water but no one came back to take our drink orders, and I really needed a drink after fighting BART delays and all the Gay Pride folks in tutus (they were super cute just not in a hurry).  We finally had to flag someone down to get a glass of wine (but this was the only time we experienced a lack of service). 

The server will ask casually if you would like bread, do not skip the bread, it is some of the best bread I have ever tasted, and it would be tragedy to miss this warm morsel with its side of salted butter.  

All of the apps were tasty, although I thought $3 for each oyster was little on the high side.  The hard boiled egg was nice with it's spicy sauce, the calamari was beautiful and complex, the squid ink noodles were okay although I may have preferred them more saucy since I found them a little dry all on their own.

From the apps we went right to the mains.  I am not normally a red meat gal, but the petit fillet with its roasted cabbage and faro lured me in.  It was a beautiful plate, the steak was butter tender, and every bite was succulent and roasty. The duck, although cooked to a nice temperature, suffered from not fully rendering the fat, which is always a drag.

Similar to my comment about the bread do not skip dessert, it is a can't miss course even if you don't normally order sweets.  The Honey crumb pudding with honey toffee was perfect and not too sweet.  The Rocky road Eton Mess was a mess of yummy with great texture.

We steered away from the very specific cocktails and it is pretty easy to select a wine to pair, but the wine menu did not blow me away, which is no big deal.
author: Heather D.

description: I almost cried while eating my beef !That was super "raffiné" not expensive for the quality. A must do in SF!
author: Colin B.

description:
Always wanted to try this place ever since they took over when it was Baker and Banker and before that Quince.  Neighborhood restaurant that was everything I expected.  Local sustainable source menu that's creative and delicious!  

Ambiance and decor is just right and congruent with the food.  Makes me want to try her sister restaurant Frances.
author: Naty D.

description: My girlfriend and I really loved the food and service at Octavia. We started with Deviled Eggs, Squid Ink Noodles, and Crisp New Potatoes. Then we had Fettuccine and Semolina Dumplings. Oh and can't forget the house baked Levain. The service was top notch. Friendly and very attentive. We can't wait to go back.
author: Jay T.

description:
Hands down my favorite dinner experience in San Francisco over the last 4 years.  I was invited to dinner without knowing much about Octavia and was just blown away.  To echo many of the other reviews here, the tasting menu is fantastic, not to mention pretty reasonable.  

It has now been several weeks since we ate here and the seasonal menu has changed since, so I won't detail specific menu items as they may not be featured any longer.  Suffice it to say that between the food, the terrific service (Chris, in particular), and the cozy ambience, you will love experience at Octavia.
author: Chris N.

description:
Dinner review.

Deviled egg - 4/5
Petit filet - 3/5
Ricotta dumplings - 4/5
Snapper - 3/5
Duck breast - 4/5
Angel food cake - 4/5
Crumb pudding - 3/5

Overall, "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description: The house wine was really good and the place has a cozy feeling atmosphere. I expected more from the squid ink noodles, but overall all the food was pretty good!
author: Erica C.

description: Our friends were running late and the staff kindly seated us on time. They just told us they needed the table by a certain time, which gave us about 3 hours, which was plenty of time. The ambiance is beautiful. The bread, which can be purchased by the loaf to take home ($8/loaf) was served a slice at a time. It was exceptionally moist in the middle and crispy on the outside. The "leaves of grass" tea was good. Oysters were fantastic, deviled egg was good - slightly spicy, burrata was excellent, squash and persimmon salad was great, pappardelle was tasty but the noodles were thicker than expected, pork was perfectly cooked,  cassoulet was not my favorite but my fiance loved it, profiteroles were forgettable, toasted angel food cake was fantastic! Great ambiance, good service, great food!
author: Christina G.

description:
Octavia--the unsuspecting Michelin star restaurant.

I decided to check this place out after it was announced that they had earned their first Michelin star this year. Corner location w/ a wood interior & not too many tables created a cozy atmosphere.

Every course is served family style, so from smallest to largest we ordered:
-"DEVILED EGG": Nice presentation, beautiful to cut into and make yolk porn with, but I could skip this next time. As much as I love soft-boiled eggs, this was not much more than just that. Still yummy though.
-Chilled SQUID INK NOODLES: Delicious. Squid ink noodles and bottarga are a match made in heaven, and this dish showcased that wonderfully. Each forkful was a refreshing bite of lemon upon chilled noodles. Definitely a must order.
-LITTLE GEM LETTUCE, roasted bing cherry, toasted pistachio, blu del granduca: Awesome salad! My family and I were practically fighting over pieces. Next time we should probably just get 2 orders lol
-TAGLIATELLE TONNATO: Great pasta dish and the albacore tuna is what made it unique. They change their pasta offerings regularly but you can be sure they know how to do it right.
-Grilled PETIT FILET: The star of the dinner, at least for me. Each piece was so BEAUTIFULLY PINK and perfectly cooked. I was practically drooling as it arrived at our table. The roasted cabbage, cherry tomato, charred eggplant, and creme fraiche added a savory freshness to the dish
-CHICKEN confit "hash": Juicy chicken! The corn made for an interesting flavor profile that I kept eating more of.
-King SALMON: Super crispy skin made this salmon amazing. As with the other larges dishes, the vegetables complemented the meal perfectly.
-Angel food cake w/ corn ice cream: Perfect end to our meal. The cake was so fluffy and the corn ice cream was so good! I wish I could have more!

I had a nice dining experience; friendly/funny staff, good portions, & great value. Though had I not read that this was now a Michelin restaurant, I would not have been able to tell. Nonetheless, it's still an excellent restaurant and I will probably be back for my mom's birthday because she loved the meal so much.
author: Stephanie Joyce D.

description: My favorite place to go in all of San Francisco! Try as many things as you can, the tasting menu is fabulous. Their bread is my #1. Customer service is excellent.
author: Jordan E.

description:
09.29.16

Boyfriend's birthday calls for a search on Zagat's Top 50 in SF. After eliminating all of the restaurants that we've been to together and separately, I was left with a few choices. Octavia was among the top.

I had a soft spot for Baker & Banker, having spent a birthday celebration there and a double date with one of my favorite couples. Octavia had huge shoes to fill, but did not disappoint.

We, of course, started with a bottle of wine. Then went on to share a pair of sweetwater oysters with caramelized citrus and espelette chili jam. This jam is my jam. I'm feeling it. Or maybe I'm feeling the wine.

We then had the "deviled egg", which comes whole and has no mayo. The fresno chili relish is bomb. I'm feeling this too, or, just maybe, the wine again.

My absolute favorite was the chilled squid ink noodles. I can probably have four servings by myself and call it a day. But I didn't because there was more on the menu to explore.

I ended up with the red snapper and he had the petit filet. Both were cooked and seasoned wonderfully, and even though I was getting full, we soldiered on and finished our plates clean.

A decaf and an espresso and we called it a night there.

https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/octavia-san-francisco?select=FoI9iTU-5G3uHtIen_SKZQ&userid=tGgTIueZy1JNTzQD9rkZLQ

Total damage for two: $219
author: Jenny L.

description: Probably the best dinner I've had in the city. Made a reservation for a birthday dinner, this place is incredible. Service was great! Got wine, deviled eggs, crudo, bread and butter, parpadelle, and steak. And the best chocolate suffle dessert I cried when I tried. I will take everyone I know here!!
author: Ryan W.

description: Everything about this place is perfect! The waitstaff are warm and friendly (but in a good way) and knowledgeable; the decor is lovely; and the food is just wonderful. We got the tasting menu for two, which is very reasonably priced given the quality of the food (~$70pp, I think?). The cocktails were delicious. The only negative thing I might have to say would be about the wine, which was just...meh. The food was delicious and copious, and the presentation was beautiful but not fussy. We had a great time, and will definitely be going back.
author: Koyel B.

description:
AMAZEBALLS.

Went here for a celebration dinner & was blown away by almost everything we tried.  Highlights included the squid in an amazing sauce, deviled egg, tagliatelle, king salmon, and THE BREAD (seriously, get it).  The anchovies were ok (but I generally don't like anchovies to begin with).

Dessert were profiteroles with a roasted strawberry ice cream & poppy/lemon sauce...so good!!
author: Natalie K.

description:
I have to agree with other reviewers. Really great service but food was average, portions small and expensive.
The signature deviled egg was ok- the crushed red pepper seasoning is good but it washes out the taste of the egg and Fresno Chiles.

Calamari- this was the best dish of the night. Calamari was tender and the small bits of bacon with rice added another element of flavor.

Pork chop- good taste but was kind of tough.

Peruvian polenta- It was more of a paste than polenta. Green peas were fresh but overall bland dish. I should have ordered the steak main instead.

Chocolate torte with salted caramel ice cream. This was the reason we came here. We enjoyed it at the sister restaurant Frances but they took it off the menu there. Octavia's version isn't as good. The soufflé tart top and bottom were so hard we had to crack and scrape to get it off the plate.

Lastly you would think a Michelin starred restaurant charging high prices for small portions would be able to pay for their staff's health insurance instead of sticking it to their patrons.
author: Russell H.

description:
We often visit this area as we have a friend who lives a few doors down from Ocatvia, but we'd never been able to land a reservation before. This time we marked our calendar for 30 days before the visit (when the reservations became available for that day)  and managed to score a precious reservation!

Walking by earlier in the day we saw their loaves of bread in the window with an $8 price tag, which seemed a little steep, but after trying the bread before the meal we thought again--it's dense and moist with a chewy fresh crust--just dangerous in every way!

I ordered the winter squash cassoulet, which was a hearty blend of vegetables with crispy walnuts. Two people in our party ordered the Osso Buco, which is a beef rather than (cruel) veal dish here, and tender/delicious. Another person ordered the pork loin, which was also very good. Also enjoyed the burrata and dandelion salad.

We ordered wine by the carafe, and didn't love the first one we ordered. Our waitress, who was professional in every other way as well, offered another variety of wine, allowed us to taste it first, then replaced the carafe. She also kept us on schedule as we were headed to a show after dinner.

It's a pricey night out, but every morsel was delicious and we were treated like royalty--well worth it (IF you can somehow snag a reservation!)
author: Tara C.

description:
Every party needs a pooper and in this case, it's me. Sorry guys!

I love runny egg yolks and I had high hopes for the Deviled Egg. The egg was cooked really well but the spices just didn't work. I felt like I was eating a Chinese Yang Rou Chuanr (Mutton  Kebab) while I was biting into the egg.

Our next dish, the Halibut Crudo, was refreshing, delicious, but super duper tiny.

My friend liked the beef tongue appetizer and it was very tender. Unfortunately, it was not very flavorful.

After 3 ok starters, I was not feeling too great. Luckily, the ribeye redeemed the meal. The steak was a winner because of the lovely tomato-based sauce on top of it. Honestly, I prefer my steaks without a lot of extras because I want to taste the flavor of the meat but I was just happy to finally like a dish.

The meal ended on a positive note with with the rich, decadent Chocolate Souffle. The caramel ice cream that came with the souffle was excellent.

Without any standouts, I can't see myself wanting to come back again.
author: Yi Z.

description: I came here expecting too much. The customer service was very good, but the food wasn't. I had the hard boiled egg and squid ink pasta to start both were good but our other starters weren't. I had the Duck for main course. It was undercooked so I didn't end up finishing it. Dessert was bland. This restaurant is so disappointing I don't even want to continue this review.
author: Chris H.

description:
One of my favorite things about going out to new restaurants is when a restaurant can convert me into loving something I previously was skeptical of or didn't like.  Having read so much about Octavia in the SF press, my friend and I committed ourselves to going awhile back since reservations are fairly hard to come by for a reasonable dining hour during the week. Aside from the beautiful pasta and protein plates that are all over the Internet, the one thing my friend wanted to get was the breaded eggplant.  My experience with eggplant has always been neutral to general distaste; I certainly avoided it if it were presented to me in its raw and unadulterated form.  That being said, and trying to open myself to trying new things, I had one bite of that eggplant dish and was an immediate fan.  Here's a rundown of what we shared that night:

"Deviled Egg," Fresno Chile Relish, Marash Pepper & Spice: We each got our own egg, which was a good idea since sharing this would have been awkward.  While the presentation of the egg was beautiful, there was a little too much of the chili pepper and spices on the egg.  The egg was cooked perfectly, but I was only so-so on this.

Crisp Eggplant, Miso Butter & Charred Sungold Tomato: As previously mentioned, this was probably my favorite dish of the evening.  The breading and miso butter on the eggplant was what made this an absolute home run of a dish for me.

Saffron Tonnarelli, Fino Sherry, Tomato, Toasted Garlic & Fennel: The pasta itself was cooked perfectly and I loved the fresh tomatoes that came with the pasta.  The saffron wasn't overwhelming, but it seemed to play second fiddle to the garlic on the dish.  This was the perfect amount of pasta to share between two people!

Local King Salmon, Anson Mills Farro Verde, Green Olive, Purslane, Avocado: After some mulling over on whether or not we share an entree or get our own, we decided on sharing the salmon.  I'm pretty glad we did too since this was a generous serving of salmon! I loved loved loved the purslane and avocado that came with this.  While salmon isn't always my first choice of protein, I'm glad that I decided to get a little adventurous and step outside of the land animal box too.  

With all of the items we ordered, we had to pass on dessert and called it quits before getting to the "too full, can't talk" realm.  Service wise, our server was an absolute gem and was great in his recommendations and his advice on how to approach the menu. Everything came out at a fairly leisurely pace, and while we were by the kitchen, it never got overwhelmingly loud or uncomfortable.  I definitely think that Octavia lives up to the deliciousness that everyone talks about, I would definitely like to come back here if given the chance!
author: Lisa I.

description: We enjoyed the tasting menu as well as the very create wine pairings. I could eat the black sesame ice create for every meal. :)
author: Jason C.

description:
Delicious (unique) food + great service = 5 stars!

Highly recommend for a nice date night.
author: Rachel T.

description:
My boyfriend and I celebrated our 2nd anniversary at Octavia.  Awesome dining experience! 

Morro Bay, Grassy Bar OYSTER, "Gazpacho" Mignonette ($3.50) - We ordered 2 oysters. This was very fresh! Ingredients was on point with the oysters. 

DEVILED EGG," Fresno Chile Relish, Marash Pepper & Spice ($5.00) Ordered just one for my boyfriend because he can take the spice. He liked it and definitely recommends it to people who appreciates spicy dishes. 

Chilled Squid Ink NOODLES, Cortez Bottarga, Fennel, Lemon Oil ($7.00) - My second time having squid ink noodles. This was definitely an appetizer dish because it was so little. It was good and wished it was more.

Grilled BEEF TONGUE "Picadillo," Crispy Potato, Sultana Raisin, Spiced Jus ($8.00) - MY FAVORITE! !! I loved this dish! I'm starting to like beef tongue, thanks to Liholiho Yacht Club. This was so tender and flavorful. All of the ingredients just blends together. I will order this item again!

Brandt Farms Beef RIB-EYE, Roasted Cauliflower, Pickled Chile, Gremolata ($38)- My boyfriend ordered this dish. This was just okay for him. He actually preferred my entree lol When I tried it, it was decent. I mean it wasn't overcooked so that's always good. 

Grilled Long & Baily PORK CHOP, Braised Escarole and Chanterelle Mushrooms ($32)- I ordered this dish. My boyfriend loved the pork chop. By this time, I was getting a bit full and they give you plenty of meat. I was surprised when our server came to our table with our entrées. I was like, "OMG, that is a lot of meat!" At that time, I wasn't digging it. I mean I was super full. I ate 25% of it and ordered it to go. I ate my leftover pork chop the following day and  that was the time when I appreciated the flavor. It was really good! Loved the vegetables, especially the grilled mushrooms!

Warm Chocolate Soufflé TART cocoa nib brittle, salted caramel ice cream ($9) - Octavia customized our dessert. It was delicious! Loved the chocolate soufflé with salted caramel ice cream. Few of my favorite sweets in one plate! I will definitely order this dessert again.

Overall, I had an amazing time at Octavia. I would like to thank the entire staff for making it a great experience for my boyfriend and me.

I recently had a shitty service at House of Prime Rib. I informed them that it was a surprise birthday celebration and the lady who does reservation guaranteed that they will give him a cake with a candle, sing to him, and take a souvenir photo. None of that happened. No one greeted the birthday boy, no cake with a candle, and no souvenir photo. I was sooo disappointed with my experience with them so I was soooooooOo pleased that Octavia takes care of thier customers especially with their personal requests.

Food was delicious and customer service was outstanding! From the reservation, Samantha, the host, our server, and many servers that assisted us, thank you so much!

I will come here again and I will definitely recommend Octavia to others!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Outstanding! Been wanting to come here after our great experience at Frances. I was in need of a date night, and found an open prime time reservation at Octavia.  Best dishes were definitely the filet and the souffle tart.  The tart is probably on my list of favorite desserts ever!  The favors are there, but what really makes it for me are the differences in texture.  Love the addition of whatever toffee tasting garnish that's on the dish.

We also had the deviled egg, which isn't a dish I'm typically fond of.  This was was a bit different and more like a poached egg, seasoned with deviled egg spices.  We also got the panade, which to me was a bit too rich, but good nevertheless.  

As with Frances, my favorite entree was the steak, as they cook their meat perfectly.  Goes great with a nice glass of wine!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Food so great and a restaurant so great that they still get five stars from me despite a couple things I didn't love. We wanted to try it all and the setup of the menu is such that you can parcel out a couple appetizers each and share an entree (but we couldn't decided and ended up getting two). You can't go wrong with anything you go for, but the deviled egg was amazing and the other small bite we had that night was beyond amazing. The bouillabaisse I had was really great, too. All inventive and creative spins artfully presented. 

So, my beef is our server. I hadn't been here before and I clearly wanted some guidance. I started by asking about the vermouth drinks they serve and I clearly was confused how it worked and needed a little guidance, and he just wasn't having it. He also started by coming over and just saying "do you know what you want?" instead of a how are you, been here before, have questions...it was clear he didn't want to be there and didn't want to be helping us. The fact that I can overlook that and give this place five stars is a testament to the quality of the food and the lovely space. 

Also, a great wine list and he steered us toward some interesting choices, but again I would have liked to hear a bit more about what my options were and had some further guidance. For $250 for two people it only seems fair!
author: Charlie B.

description:
Tonight 2/24/18 was our third and last meal at Octavia. The attitude of the host was what made this experience so negative. He had no notion of customer service or customer relations. While we had arrived on time (8:00pm) we waited 20 minutes to be seated. Having to wait wasn't the main issue as I understand it happens sometimes. What I couldn't understand was the attitude of the host. He never offered an explanation or even a simple apology for the wait until I went up to him to inquire. Even then, his attitude and body language was "it is what it is." He didn't even greet the rest of our party as they showed up. He avoided us completely without acknowledgement of our situation or making any eye contact as we were waiting where there was no waiting area and as a party of 6 we had to constantly get out of the way of waiters and try not to fall over on the people who were seated.

Finally when our table was ready he tried to make up for it and offered us champagne, but before I could take a sip, I realized he was taking us downstairs to the restaurant's kitchen. He said we got the special chef's table. We never asked to be seated in the kitchen surrounded with the busy hard working staff. Some ask for that, but we clearly didn't. (I am a chef myself and did not wish to be seated in the kitchen when dining out with friends.) The setting felt like the dungeons and a far far cry from the beautiful main dining area we had reserved for like our previous visits.

If you have a party of 6 and do not wish to have your meal in the restaurant's kitchen make sure to ask NOT to get the "chef's table." It seems like if the tables in the main dining area don't clear in time, they will seat you down in the kitchen. 

Even though the food was excellent, as it has always been, it's a shame the host couldn't practice the basics of customer relations; communication, kindness/sympathy, and an apology.
author: P Y.

description:
I have to admit it's been a long while since I've been to Frances. Id been meaning to hit Octavia since they opened but time has not been on my side. Recently there was a special dinner that a friend organized so I went to check it out. We split a ton of dishes amongst a group to get a good idea of the spread. We ended up with:


-Chilled Squid Ink NOODLES, Cortez Bottarga, Fennel, Lemon Oil
-Mushrooms "A LA GRECQUE" with Grilled Levain 
-BEEF TONGUE, Piracicaba Broccoli, Toasted Garlic, Marrow Broth
-Chilled Early Girl TOMATO SOUP, Burrata Cheese & Garlic Toast
-Brandt Farms Beef RIB-EYE, Eggplant Caponata, Nardello Pepper, Confit Tomato
-Marin Coast King SALMON, Farro Verde, Green Olive, Purslane, Avocado 
-Arbuckle GRITS, Sweet Corn, Ricotta, King Trumpet Mushroom, Blistered Padróns
-Long & Baily PORK CHOP, Grilled Zucchini, Creamed Corn, Roasted Mission Fig

All delicious across the boad. Id argue that I like Frances a bit more as it's a more focused menu (that I remember) whereas Octavia has a much more global influence. The other thing would be price/portion size/performance. of the entrees are pretty high. but then Im willing to pay more for quality, which Octavia has in droves. The staff are super friendly and that's a good draw for your dining experience. I remember the Baker and Banker space looking more formal and definitely more brightly lit. Definitely more candidate for date night than large groups unless you plan on taking over the PDR downstairs. 4.3 stars
author: Kim N.

description:
Written by my husband, Matthew:

We found Octavia on a ten best list somewhere and they did not disappoint.

The chef is really putting out some great flavor combinations in an artful manner. We had the tasting menu - not noted on the printed or online menu so it was a nice, welcome surprise. 

There were some very unusual flavor combinations that worked out really well. The surprising umami flavors for me were in the spicy deviled egg, the Pickled Anchovies with chickpea poppyseed sable, and I loved the Duck Gizzard with citrus dish. There were a couple artful veggie dishes, a Black Cod, a Filet, delicious Polenta Bread, Shrimp with Plum.

We enjoyed everything and were served more food than we could eat. The desserts were incredible : Warm Chocolate Soufflé TART cocoa nib brittle, salted caramel ice cream AND Pistachio PROFITEROLES summer berries, fennel pollen, meyer lemon ice cream.

This was a great experience and we recommend it to adventurous eaters.
author: Kelly C.

description: Enjoyed a birthday gourmet evening at Octavia. The service is absolutely top notch from start to finish. The space is clean and modern with enough nick backs to look at but mostly people watching. It is actually a smallish place so probably best to reserve on a busy day (we did). We tried several of the small plates. Each was characterized by nuanced tastes. The oysters were fresh and accompanied by some subtle tastes that elevated them. The melon appetizer was a surprising sweet savory contrast. The squid ink noodles were like a pop quiz of flavors. Finally the desserts were absolutely worth trying.
author: William R.

description:
4 stars for the food 
Extra half star for the dessert
Extra half star for the knowledge of the waiter (will explain)

We shared a handful of plates
- 2 of the deviled egg. Fun dish, flavorful, simple but nice
- Squid ink noodles. Good, not amazing, probably wouldn't order this again
- Asparagus salad. Really good and flavorful
- Squash lemongross green curry. Star of the night. Surprisingly flavorful and refreshing. Huge fan of this one. 
- Angel food cake. 

OK, serioulsly people, the freaking angel food cake! It was PERFECTION and the rose ice cream was superb, literally perfect. I have never had angel food cake like this.

I almost forget - the $2 for bread and olive oil. When I ate this, my brain went WHATTTT? This was THE best bread I have ever had, period (even a little better than the amazing bread that Belinda of B Patisserie makes for Nico). The olive oil was of the utmost quality and delicious. 

We will be back and for sure will get the break and angel food cake again. 

Our server was super knowledgeable. He didn't just memorize and speak about the food from memory. He explained the flavors so perfectly. When we asked him to help us choose between 2 dishes, he didnt just say which he likes more, but rather explained the flavors and complexity of the dishes. And that too with a great demeanor. I have had excellent service, but to feel like every decision was well informed thanks to the server - that's rare. Well done.

Awesome meal and experience all around (love the space too). 5 stars.
author: Sai S.

description:
This is Frances' sister restaurant. The atmosphere is a bit less intimate but still pleasant. The serving utensils and the menu will look familiar though. Overall a notch below Frances both in quality and in service.

Had a variety of appetizers and salads. The artichoke mushroom soup was exceptional. The rest was good but not exceptional - and overly salty.

The service was attentive but the food came very slowly and we were waiting for over 20min in between dishes. The staff didn't seem to notice or if they did they didn't think to apologize or compensate us for the experience. I usually don't care too much about the service but couldn't help notice that it was a bit sub par for this price level.
author: Ruben K.

description: Visited on Monday 8:30pm with no reservation. Service was very good( there was about 7 staff members on a floor helping around!). Place has 1 Michelin  star. My BF loves this restaurant. Sou vide medium rare fillet steak was great with light marrow broth. I love calamari/kimchi dish with mint for appetizer. Raw fresh Porchini mushrooms on my tagliatelle pasta were delicious.
author: Svetlana K.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. I love Frances so much and Octavia is a gift from heaven. Mellisa Perello and her staff have created a vision that is everything right and good on earth. I could go on about the inspiring, beautifully crafted genius and extreme care that composes the cuisine but, its the whole experience of Octavia that is so special, from the service to the beauty of the space. Thank you for existing Octavia, I love you!
author: Hillary E.

description:
Octavia is that quaint neighborhood spot that you might just walk passed. It's so unassuming...but do stop in! Rather, make a reservation- it will not disappoint. As fellow Yelper, Brittany F noted...the menu is short and sweet...but every dish was thoughtful and delicious. We ordered a variety of dishes to share and I am so glad we did. We ordered the deviled egg: not ideal for sharing, but this one is one of their signature items so it was worth ordering. It's not your traditional deviled egg....but worth a try! Next, we had the halibut crudo served over an avocado crema/mousse. This was delicious. Definitely a petite portion, but lovely and delicate. Next, we indulged in the Tagliatelle in a pesto sauce. This dish did not really stand out to me as much as the others, but it was still a-ok. Next, we had salmon  served with in  a brown butter fig sauce. This dish had the wow factor for sure. The butter sauce was rich but not over powering. We ordered an extra side of the sauce just to dip our bread in. It was lovely. For dessert, we ordered the Eton Mess...and this was my first time trying this dessert. Per my dining buddy it was one of the best she's ever had...even though it was not a totally traditional take on the classic old school dessert. All I know is that it was beautifully plated and equally delicious. Our other dessert was a fruit cake....I believe it was shortcake. This was light but definitely more on the spectrum of a sweet I'd have with my morning coffee. 

To sum it up- Octavia delivers on good food and excellent customer service. It's understated elegance won me over. I'd definitely return.
author: Isabella J.

description:
Another great addition to the SF restaurant scene. The chef came from Frances and didn't disappoint. 

Deviled egg - fantastic. Not super English but has Californian notes with tomato and the freshest herb/ingredients. Nicely done. Visually appealing. 

Pasta with corn and cucumber - nice and light. I think it's on their special menu. Liked this a lot. 

Rib-eye: expertly cooked and I actually like the fact that they retained a ring of fat on one side of the ribeye to give more flavor. 

Ricotta dumping: I was never a big fan of balls of mozzarella and this one reminded of that. This is only for die-hard cheese fans. The tomato was just not enough to overcome somewhat bland ricotta dumpling. 

I tried the Octavia signature Pinot Noir blended from three different vineyards in Sonoma coast and it was very good. Wide selection of wine by glass or wine by carafe (500ml).
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Food-wise I'd give this a solid 4.5
Service was a 3.5
You can call me a fan
but with reservations.

Speaking of, grab a reservation. Maybe earlier in the evening before it's so dim you're straining to see your food. I'm 29. I don't have problems seeing. It was very dark in here; so dark I saw similarly-aged humans using their phone to navigate the menu. You could say the lighting was maybe... too sexy.

Arrival
We dropped in here a little earlier than our 8:15 reservation.
They were perfectly accommodating and seated me and my husband immediately.
I had mentioned in the reservation that we were celebrating getting hitched that morning at City Hall and were looking to spoil ourselves a little bit.
They promptly served us a sparkling rosé something on the house. Nice! Right?
Trouble is, my very thoughtful friend had called ahead ordered us two glasses of champagne that we never saw. She was very disappointed and after finding out she was charged and we were none the wiser. And man I was bummed. Not because I didn't have champagne but because having to tell someone about the surprise afterwards takes the wind out of your sails if you know what I mean. So maybe give a little ring a half hour ahead if you have any little special something you wanted to make sure happened.

Food
We started with the "deviled" egg and chilled squid ink noodles.
Both were balanced dishes. I preferred the noodles,
as the deviled egg was a little bland. 
Though perfectly soft-boiled, generally it's flowing into something well-seasoned. I just wanted more from a $5 dollar egg.
The noodles had an amazingly clean, refreshing, savory flavor with just the tiniest bit of gumminess to the noodle. Which is impressive. They're hard to explain but also unforgettable. 
I think the bread showed up around this time. I had been slowly losing my mind that it wasn't the first thing to come out. It also wasn't refilled at any point, which is the opposite of what I had been told by other patrons. I would have been happy to pay for another portion, but it was never offered, it was just swept off the table. 
We shared the butternut squash soup, which was well-presented and they brought us two bowls to portion between us, which I appreciated! It was deliciously creamy and a great compromise between the usual (and unfortunately) sweet profile and was cut with a savory lentil. I was really impressed because generally I am not a bs soup fan. But yes to this. 
By the time we got to the malfatti, I was worried I wouldn't be able to eat anymore. But we charged on. Butter. I tasted mostly butter, but my husband ate anything left with a reckless abandon. These porcini mushrooms were no joke.
We finished up with the Angel Food Cake, which honestly was a little forgettable. 
Dessert is often generally my favorite course, but the pumpkin ice cream was really lacking impressionable flavor and I wouldn't say "subtle" was the aim. It was fully overpowered by the coconut and brown butter; I had my doubts when I read it on the menu. Pumpkin is a little difficult to pull flavor out of and you'll definitely find that's true with this dish. The presentation was fun, but it took the angel food cake to a heavier place and it lost it's airy-ness for me.

Drinks
I got The Relief, which was amazing -- really fantastic. Floral but bright but not at all syrupy or heavy. I would definitely recommend.
My husband got the house cocktail, it was a little too dark for me. I tend to avoid dark liquors in life, but it was still a smoky little treat. 

Service
Whomever was the host was fantastic. The few times we got to interact with him I felt like a damn kwane. But we mostly had a server who I would describe as a mixture between a sleepy koala and a dismissive cat. Maybe that's the vibe they want but I would say his attitude was inconsistent with the rest of the service we received. He was still attentive, but he wasn't having any of our chatty nonsense.

The experience was enjoyable
and sure, I'd recommend it
but I probably would only visit for squid ink noodles and to try another non-pumpkin dessert.
author: Kiera R.

description:
Overpriced hype. Not good food.

Interior is contemporary and refined but rather dark and a tad cramped (uncomfortable chairs).

They are strict on reservations. Booking via opentable = $25 per person fee if you cancel.

Made a reservation for dinner and was seated promptly. Friendly and courteous staff.

Ordered:

Squid ink noodles - texture was a bit too soft; utterly devoid of flavor. Typical SF restaurant to add ink to spruce up an otherwise boring dish.

Kale salad - pretty good, but I fail to see how a salad without truffles or protein is worth $13. The best part of this was the garlic crouton which is essentially just a buttery toasted bruschetta.

Duck leg - small portion size. Hideously over cooked. Skin was even noticeably charred. The carrot was cooked nicely though.

Squash and green curry - my favorite dish. Interesting balance of creaminess and spice with some nicely cooked veggies.

Black sesame Eton mess - ice cream was good but the mandarin and buddha's hand were mere afterthoughts drowned out in some really sweet sugary slabs (not sure if toffee or nougat or something). Cream with sesame was too rich and should have better balanced the sesame flavor.
