Honey crumb pudding - decent dessert, not too sweet yet had a robust flavor and texture to anchor preserved fruits. The creme fraiche was a nice touch.

Service was attentive and professional.

They also charge a mandatory $4/customer charge to offset the increases in employee healthcare (thanks, ACA).

Overall my issue is in how expensive the food cost given the quality. Michelin prices but below Michelin flavors. Based on other restaurants in the new America genre and this part of the world, Octavia charges 1.5-2x what they should.

I don't plan on coming back.
author: Erik R.

description:
Having been underwhelmed by quite a few Michelin 1 stars, I regained my confidence in them after my experience at Octavia. We had the Oyster, Devile's Egg, Tomatero Kale Salad, Squid Ink Noodles, Duck Hearts, Salmon, Duck Breast, Honey Crumb, and Profiteroles. All are extraordinary! Squid ink noodle is my favorite; so fresh and refreshing! Tomatero Salads are also outstanding! Duck breast is skillfully cooked and super, though I was looking for more tenderness. I highly recommend their Ethiopian coffee, aromatic and full of great flavor. I didnt like the Profiteroles as much as my friend's Honey Bread.

Service is good. I wish they used lint free napkin or paper napkin--recycle paper napkin vs reusable napkin: probably contributes to the same environmental impact (one has to be washed and one just be disposed or recycled) anyhow, my dark pants were dotted with lot of white lints after dinner. Another mishap: When the server was wiping the table next to ours, maybe a bit too fast, the wet cloth swung a few water drops off, flew and landed on my face. Maybe the server did not notice, neither did the one I was talking to when this was happening, didn't want to make it a big deal as they are nice and polite from beginning with. Also there is a smaller chance that it could be from the other table pouring water and drops bounced out and landed on my face. Didn't see it clear where it came from. No big deal. 

Open kitchen is very cool. You can see things run really well and smooth under Chef Melissa P. 

Overall, a great experience. Will come back.
author: S N.

description:
+ Dungeness crab wrapped in pear was light and refreshing. Well done, creative combination
+ Squid ink noodles were unique, worth trying
+ Fantastic bread, like a thick sponge with chunky, chewy knots
~ Boullabaise was thick and intense. A little too strong, imo, but a different take on the dish.
~ Petit Four with Trumpet Mushrooms was nice, but not terribly special.
~ Pear "Float" was a bit too sweet for our tastes
author: Dustin H.

description:
I may be biased but Melissa Perello has won me over with her interpretation on American/Californian fare; quite possibly my favorite execution. I've been to Frances and Octavia when they first opened and experienced her cuisine once again at a special Michelin All-Star dinner in August. Of all Californian fare restaurants, I think Melissa does the best at synthesizing the flavor profiles utilizing our great produce and creating eclectic, fresh dishes that are memorable with their flavor combinations. 

Like Frances, the vibe at Octavia is homey and comfortable, although in a bigger space, more mood lighting, and an open kitchen visible in the back; it's very much solidified itself as a neighborhood gem restaurant. Service is warm and friendly while being restrained and not pushy. The wine list is quaint, but expansive and well curated with great selections from Frances, Italy, and California. The $25 corkage fee is also a tremendous bargain if you want to pop special bottles. 

Now for the food;
1. Tempura butternut squash with sudachi (a Japanese citrus) aioli. Very well done tempura with a light crisp batter while still perfectly cooking the squash to a tender al dente. 
2. Nettle tagliatelle with house cured pancetta was a Californian rendition on carbonara. Well made noodles with a nice chew to accompany the texture and richness of the sauce, while the nettle (an edible plant with an earthy profile) was made into pasta giving extra flavor depth. 
3. Ling cod, clams, nori beurre-blanc w/ potatoes was incredibly memorable. I'm stealing the nori beurre-blanc because it's so good. It gave the fish added umami and a slight Asian influence from the seaweed (nori). The cod itself was so flavorful, flaky, and moist, with perfectly charred skin while not being overly salty to achieve that perfect crust. Clams and potatoes accompanied perfectly with the dish's cohesiveness and was a very well rounded and thoughtful dish. 
4. Angel food cake with pumpkin sherbet. I was eyeing the signature chocolate souffle again, but its so interesting to taste their more seasonal desserts. Creamy pumpkin sherbet with fluffy and cloying food cake. Overall not that heavy and not cloying, although the roasted pumpkin felt slightly out of place/excessive? 

Overall I love Octavia, I love Frances, I love Melissa's cooking. With all the great places to eat in SF and constant restaurant openings, it's important to revisit these classics and Octavia, along with Frances,reminds me why it's going to be one of my monthly spots. As an FYI I'm writing this the same day of dining because the food was so memorable.
author: Chad S.

description:
We were impressed by Frances when we went a couple of years ago, but we were even more pleased with Octavia.

Highlights of the meal were definitely the grilled petite filet, and the chocolate souffle tart. The steak was perfectly cooked, tender, and extremely flavorful.. It makes me think that the best steaks in SF aren't from steak houses, but from the more ingredient-focused, fine dining places like this. The chocolate souffle tart was just.. wow. Probably one of the best desserts that we've ever had!

We also had the deviled egg (which isn't really a deviled egg, and more like a poached egg with chili oil and spices), the squid ink pasta, campanelle, and the panade (a warm, cheesy bread-pasta like concoction). The appetizers were all pretty good, and the panade was a wee bit rich but went very well with a nice glass of full-bodied red.

$25 corkage is a steal, so bring some wine, and order one of everything.
author: Kazu O.

description:
Be careful about one thing: the downstairs "chef's table".  We were required to sit there tonight with a party of six. The main dining room, where I have eaten twice recently, is pretty terrific: warm, lively, well-lighted, romantic, fun.  The "chef's table" room is, frankly, highly unpleasant -- loud, overly-bright, sterile, with a radio playing too loud and many people (servers, etc) coming up and down the stairs and sometimes out the side door.  There is a single oversized "chef's table" off a secondary kitchen/prep/dishwashing (?) area and near a bunch of storage facilities.  Service down there seems to slow down considerably. The food is the same -- very good.  

Had we been told beforehand (as we should have been when we booked the reservation) that this is was the only place available for us in the restaurant, we would have gone elsewhere.  I advise you to do the same  if you face the same lack of options.  

In any event, Octavia needs to change their policy and tell people (at the time of a reservation) if this "chef's table" is the place they will be sent to -- or if there is any risk of that.
author: Jeff F.

description:
Had a stellar experience at Octavia for my birthday. We arrived a few minutes early for our reservation, and were promptly seated once the previous diners table was cleaned up. 

The space itself is beautiful, the bold dark hues against the white walls and wooden tables was really charming. 

While the menu itself isn't particularly large, it does feel like there are a lot of dishes to choose from, and multiple dishes that would suite an array of palates. I will 100% make my way back to Octavia as soon as I can stand going to back to the city (lol).

We ordered:

+ The Deviled Egg - This is a MUST GET. When we initially saw the pictures I didn't think a homely egg could be a stand out dish on it's own, but this really really works-- so long as you break the egg into the relish below and get a bite with a little bit of everything. If you're not into sharing (we are) you could probably get one per person, but we wanted to taste a little bit of everything on the menu so we only got one.

+ Steak Tartare - This was a little underwhelming and I think the kalamata olives mixed in don't really add anything and are too powerful on their own to be in a tartare. That said, it wasn't bad, but I probably wouldn't order it again.

+ Corn Chowder - This came in second to my favorite dish of the night. There is something wonderful about a great bowl of summer corn chowder and this hit all the notes I was hoping for. Despite having a dollop of creme fraiche and potatoes, it wasn't too heavy and the broth was rich, flavorful, but not heavy handed. This was the only dish I regret sharing because it was so, so delicious.

+ Saffron Linguine w/ Dungeness broth & tomato ragout - My mouth is watering just thinking about this pasta. They listed it as an appetizer, but our server offered me an entree sized portion if I wanted it. I actually stuck to the appetizer portion and it was plenty after all the appetizers and still saving room for dessert. This dish was phenomenal. The sauce was light, and not as fishy as I had expected it to be, and full of crab flavor despite not having any meat in it otherwise. I also enjoyed the linguine which were prepared al dente, and clearly made in house.

+ Fingerling potato hash w/ cioppolini onions, padron peppers, and sweet summer corn - I only had a few bites of this, but for a vegetarian entree I thought it was really good. The cioppolini onions and padron peppers were of course, my favorite bites.

+ Chocolate Souffle Tart - Get this dessert. Get it. Lick the plate clean! The balance of sweet/salty/creamy/rich/chocolate/crunchy/chewy was FIRE.
author: Siobhan F.

description:
Tried to make a reservation but being a new restaurant they were booked of course. Walked in and we're lucky enough to get a table right away. The food was fantastic. Ordered the spring veggies, fried artichokes and the pacheri with baccala to start. Everything was delicious!  Had the salmon and ribeye to share. Both cooked perfectly and seasoned so well. 

The service was outstanding. But the timing from last appetizer to entree lagged about 30 minutes which we didn't mind because it gave us time to digest since we were feeling full already. The desserts were amazing. I loved the honey crumb pudding. The flavored were so good together. The chocolate soufflé tart was very good too but was a little too sweet for me. 

They have a great selection of wines and cocktails. And the restaurant is decorated very well for such a small space. 

By the way the bathroom is unmarked looks like you're walking into a closet lol

The restaurant is only 3 blocks from my house which is convenient for me but is located in very residential area, so parking will be difficult. There are no other businesses around for a few blocks which kind of has the feel like you are having dinner in someone's home. 
Highly recommend !!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
To celebrate a special occasion my sister and I went to Octavia. We got a reservation on the earlier side and were one of the first patrons to join for dinner.

To start, she ordered the fried green tomatoes and I got the deviled egg. Both were amazing to the point of inspiring my sister to claim it (the fried green tomatoes) was the best dish she had ever tasted. The dish included chanterelles, purslane and a vinaigrette that I'm pretty sure she still dreams about. I was equally impressed with the egg. It is one of their signature items and isn't your typical deviled egg. It was soft-boiled and covered in a marash pepper and spice mix and surrounded by a tasteful amount of fresno chile relish. The flavor of the spices surrounding the egg paired well with the relish, and both were spot on with the perfectly cooked egg.

For our main dishes we picked two to split. We ordered a pork mole. And a salmon, French-inspired dish. The king salmon was served over a fresh bean cassoulet, arrowhead cabbage, summer squash and squash blossoms. The pork featured pork from a local farm, Llano Seco, salsa mole, blistered peppers, roasted grapes, and tomatillo. The roasted grapes through me for a loop, but the flavors of the pork mole were incredibly unique and surprisingly delicious together. Together they created a flavor profile that knocked both our socks off. The salmon was also delicious, and very rich. We left quite satisfied with this amount of food for the two of us.

Everything is prepared based on the season, so you may not be able to enjoy these exact dishes, but be confident the chefs at Octavia will put together a delicious and creative dish made with the finest of ingredients.

The service was pretty spectacular. I'm pretty sure the waiter was not as excited about our excitement about the delicious food, but he was patient with us and quite kind. Since there weren't many other people there at the time we were well attended to, with refilled waters, and answers to all of our questions about the menu. They were incredibly accommodating to food intolerances and had options for meat-lovers, non-meat eaters, people trying to eat Whole30 or paleo, gluten free, and so forth.

The restaurant is located in a quite unassuming area in San Francisco. It could easily be mistaken for an apartment, since it is tucked away in a residential area. That all just adds to its charm. With just one visit Octavia has made it into my top five restaurant choices for dinner in San Francisco. Highly recommended to dine there as a place to celebrate, a date, or simply enjoy really good farm fresh, creative, and thoughtful cuisine.
author: Mary L.

description:
Booked a table for 5:15 pm reservations and a friend and I had dinner here on Sunday evening. Scott welcomed us to come in as soon as they opened. We sat by the corner window. For starters, I ordered a glass of sauvignon blanc. We perused through the menu and wanted to eat mostly vegetables and seafood. The room filled with customers quickly. 

We ordered a quad of sweetwater oysters for starters. You could definitely taste the brininess. However, I wished there was a bit of heat and acidity to the oysters. We also shared the roasted beets and fig salad with arugula and watercress. We ordered the albacore tuna confit and that was a winner. It was so good that we both agreed to order a second one! They came in cubes marinated in a yummy asian dressing with sesame oil, soy and heat. I'd like to say that they used japanese togarashi but I could be mistaken. We also shared the crispy skin salmon entree which came with white beans and squash. The servings were just right. The baked fresh slices of bread arrived to our table piping hot and it was crusty goodness! Not too mention

For dessert, we picked the rocky road and the wildflower honey crumb pudding. The deconstructed rocky road was perfect. The wildflower honey crumb pudding was nothing short but an afterthought. I also ordered a hot green tea with creamer and sugar. 

The spread of food was exceptionally delicious and memorable. Service was impeccable and outstanding. I was very impressed from the service to the farm to table concept of their food. You can definitely taste the quality and freshness. There was an ebb and flow to the restaurant and it worked so seamlessly. 

I would return if I'm back in the City again. Thank you to Scott and the front of house staff for the warm hospitality as this was my last dinner in San Francisco before my flight home back to SoCal.
author: Mika D.

description:
The old Baker and Banker spot. Opened in mid-April. Came across an early dinner reservation on a Sunday night and couldn't pass it up since this is "hot and new". I've been to the sister restaurant Frances a long time ago and wasn't that impressed, but was ready to give this new place a try. 

Food/drinks- chilled squid ink noodles: delicious, a fancy pasta salad; mushroom 'a la creque': lots of mushroom flavor and came with toast; beef tongue and marrow broth: good, but a bit disappointed especially after reading yelpers' reviews saying it's amazing; turnip greens and rapini salad: very refreshing, enjoyed a lot: king salmon: beautifully cooked medium rare with classic components, summer berry Eton mess: amazing dessert, refreshing yet creative in terms of flavors and textures, would order again; bread: read some yelp reviews saying bread is available upon request though not written anywhere on the menu, but our waitress kindly asked us if we wanted any bread without us asking, it was really good seeds/nut bread; had a glass of Chardonnay which was nice

Ambiance/Decor- clean, modern and sleek with open kitchen. I couldn't tell that much things were different compared to the former restaurant that was here, but I'm sure there were. I liked the tables and chairs, bench seating available at one corner of the restaurant. 

Service/Staff- friendly and attentive. Seated immediately at our table when we arrived on time for our reservation. Our waitress wore cowboy boots, how cute. There were white (fabric) napkins on the table already but the waitress brought over a black one especially for me after we ordered our food/drinks because I was wearing black pants. I very much appreciated that since it is a pain to have white lint sticking to black pants, which happened to me before! The items we ordered were all correct and other staff were attentive to take away/replace plates and refill water etc. throughout our meal. 

Tips- there is no sign to or on the restroom door so I almost went into the kitchen side door thinking it was the restroom! Restroom is located at the back, left of the kitchen; it's door looks like a closer and is grey/white color. Make reservations, drop ins are difficult, at least during this time when the restaurant is still fairly new. 

We saw Brett Cooper, the ex-chef of Outerlands/current chef at Aster came in to dine. Very interesting to see the chef circle interact and so that was cool. I'm sure he got to taste everything on the menu!

Overall a solid restaurant that I actually enjoyed much more compared to Frances. Most things were prepared in a fairly classic way, but I think that's Melissa's style. Food and wine was delicious, everything was executed well, service was awesome, and the place is nice. I was content.
author: Iris H.

description: beautiful food, wonderful service and a really great experience!
author: Danielle T.

description:
Who doesn't love date night?

Pick a great restaurant that serves wonderfully delicious food and you're almost guaranteed an awesome night. Throw in some booze and some oysters, and you're guaranteed an even better night. *Wink Wink*

Opening on Thursday, April 16th, comes Octavia, Frances' sister restaurant in the old Baker and Banker space. Having a been to Frances several times, I knew we were in for a treat with Octavia. The New American menu is comprised with seven "bites"/small apps ($3.50 - $8), four small plates ($9-$13), four entrees ($24-$48), and five desserts ($8-$9). Wine and beer only but they do have a house loophole cocktail and a good variety of vermouth available. Wines by the glass were $10-$22+ (house wine is $15/glass).  Like every new restaurant that has been popping up, portions are small so expect to spend around $80-$100 a person for a full meal with wine. 

Reservations are highly recommended as we saw several parties turned away. Do note, that you need to provide a credit card to secure reservations and there's a 48 hour cancellation policy. If they can't reseat your table, you will be charged $25 per person and the credit will be applied on your next visit. 

~ * ~ D R I N K S ~ * ~
*House Cocktail: Lillet blanc, vermouth, petal, thorn ($10): http://bit.ly/1JZeaXV
*Domaine de Galouchey - Bordeaux - Vin de Jardin - 2011 ($22/glass): http://bit.ly/1DtiJ7k

I'm a hard booze girl so getting things started with a cocktail was a must. Usually not a fan of loophole cocktails because they tend to be overly sweet but the house cocktail was good. I asked for a red wine to pair with the ribeye and was brought the most expensive one at $22/glass. Go figure but the bright silkiness was unparalleled. 

~ * ~ F O O D ~ * ~ 
*Shigoku Oysters w/ fennel mignonette ($3.50 each): 5 STARS
http://bit.ly/1H7ZFCU
Uber fresh, clean, sweet and meaty. 

*Kale Salad w/ garbanzo, preserved lemon, carrots, feta, toasted sesame ($10): 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/1cQfxgy
Great balance of creamy, nutty and subtle citrus flavors. I really enjoyed the mélange of lemon, feta, and toasted sesame. 

*Deviled Eggs w/ Fresno chili relish, marash pepper & spice ($4 each): 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/1HnP6dx
Nothing like a little egg porn to make you salivate. Although the egg was perfectly soft boiled, it just seemed like a standard egg to me; even with the spices.  

*Grilled Beef Tongue w/ charred broccoli, marrow broth ($8): 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/1HLF06A
One of most favorite cuts, the lengua was incredibly tender. Seemed braised rather than grilled though (no grill marks). 

*Chilled Squid Ink Noodles w/ cortez bottarga, lemon oil, green garlic ($6): 5 STARS
http://bit.ly/1bdxSmM
My favorite dish of the night, the squid ink noodles had a great toothsome chew with a lovely brininess from the bottarga. You get a heaping tablespoon of this per an order so I highly recommend ordering one for yourself. 

*Dry Aged Ribeye w/ watercress, wild ramp, stilton butter ($42): 3.5 STARS
http://bit.ly/1E1HKuV
The only disappointment of the night. We were requested the steak rare-plus and was told the kitchen tends to undercook their steaks, and that medium rare should be sufficient. It arrived medium. *sad pouty lip* Other than that, the rib eye was deliciously tender and flavorful from the 60 dry aging process. Additionally like another reviewer had commented, I wish the steak had charred crust. Had the steak been cooked rarer, no doubt this would be a 5 star ribeye. 

*Almond Milk Panna Cotta w/ delta blueberries, pain d'amande cookies (comped - $8): 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/1aKKEIF
For all you chinese folks out there, if you like dofu fa, you will like the almond milk panna cotta. It was silky smooth and I enjoyed the sweet, tart bursts from the blueberries. 

~ * ~ S E R V I C E ~ * ~
Professional, knowledgeable, and gracious. As it was opening week, there were some kinks but that's to be expected with any new restaurant. For example, there was a 30+ minute lag before receiving our steak entrée. I did mention to our waiter that our steak was overcooked to our liking and he was very apologetic so he comped our dessert. 

~ * ~ A M B I A N C E / D E C O R ~ * ~
What huge change from when it was Baker & Banker! The space has been transformed to a contemporary rustic space with an open kitchen and lots of natural light. Good for dates but not large groups. Not the greatest acoustics as it got quite loud once the dining room was full. 

~ * ~ P A R K I N G ~ * ~
I hope they consider valet in the future because parking is very tough in the area and there's no nearby parking lot. 

So...who doesn't like date night right?

Oh yah, the one footing the bill. In this case, it was moi's turn. *Insert Al Bundy, Mr. Empty Pants Face*
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Dinner at Octavia was enjoyable, but pricey. I was definitely drawn in by the deviled egg (which, upon receiving, was a bit disappointing as it was just an expensive poached with some spices), but was fairly happy with the rest of the dishes we ordered.

We dined on...
+ ROASTED DUCK BREAST (texture and flavor wise, simply incredible and worth the wait)
+ CAVOLO SALAD (Caesar-like, with delicious, creamy flavors)
+ TURNIP GREENS SALAD (simple, tasty, but a little lemon-heavy)
- DEVILED EGG (as said earlier, a bit over-hyped)

The restaurant itself is smaller than I thought it would be, and the tables are closer together than I prefer (I dislike it when my conversation is drowned out by the tables surrounding me, and having to squeeze in/out of my seat). Our server was very attentive and friendly, which is always a win. The ceramics used for all the dishes was beautiful, as well.

We had a nice time overall, and the restaurant was within walking distance of the Jack's Mannequin show we were seeing that night, so I'd call Octavia a win (just not a repeat).
author: Claire S.

description: Excellent 'nice dinner' option in SFO. The menu is quite interesting with 'fresh and well known ingredients' prepared in a unique way creating a combination of old/new flavors. Portions are generous and good for sharing.
author: Carlos V.

description:
My friend treated me to dinner for my birthday. It was magnificent in every way!

I love Frances so I was very excited to try Octavia. It exceeded my expectations.

I appreciate the great selections offered in their wine list. 

The food was phenomenal...every dish was outstanding!

The two of us tried:

1) Crudo - Umami in your mouth!

2) Deviled Eggs - I almost skipped on this until the server explained that it was a soft boiled egg. It was silky smooth and divine.

3) Chilled squid ink noodles - perfect texture and flavors, it was actually refreshing and not heavy

4) Pork chops - Juicy, tender, deliciuos

5) Steak - Generously portioned, perfectly cooked and very rich in flavor. It was the one dish we couldn't finish..and as a left overs it was just as amazing. 

It was a terrific meal and I look forward to repeat visits.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Gave Octavia another try and it fell again.  Still didn't like the squid ink noodles, and the entrees were under-seasoned.  Desserts were pretty good though.

I don't know why people call this a neighborhood spot because it's clearly not your quintessential neighborhood joint -- you almost will never be able to walk in without at least a one-hour wait, it's really pricey for what it is, and reservations are constantly booked out months ahead.  Given how average the food is, I don't understand the hype.
author: Christine A.

description:
When you go to a Michelin-starred restaurant you expect outstanding cuisine, impeccable service, and staff that knows the menu and can offer helpful recommendations. This was not the case at Octavia for the four of us. 

Food was average and the waitstaff was surly. A simple question of "do you have any recommendations on the menu?" was responded with "I don't know it changes all the time." When we asked about the amaro to have after dinner she said, "I don't know, I haven't tried any." 

The one recommendation we got was for their famous deviled egg.  The amount of spice on the thing wasn't reminiscent of the photo on the website--it was covered so much in red spice it looked like it had been murdered.  A tad too spicy.

The ricotta gnudi was great as was the Cauliflower and Jerusalem artichoke.....but they couldn't make up for the mains (just so-so) or the grumpy staff.  Hoping that I just caught everyone on a bad day, I spoke with friends who have also been but they reported similar experiences.

We will not be going back.  A shame.
author: Heidi I.

description:
We were really excited to try Octavia and were expecting great things, we chose to go to celebrate our 1 year anniversary. The room is beautiful, they've totally nailed it on the branding, and the staff is friendly. The vermouth list is awesome. The bread was INCREDIBLE. Presentation is beautiful on all dishes.

Unfortunately the cons outweighed the pros:
- The staffing system means you get served by multiple people. I get that this is a "thing" but it made us feel not cared for. Stick with one server for a table, sometimes the old way is the best way. There was duplication in people asking to get us things, when we had already asked someone else.
- The staff was not educated on food and beverage. One of the servers, in a conversation with us about vermouth cocktails, said "that one's like an old-fashioned, old fashioneds have vermouth in them!". No, they don't. 

The food was ok:
- Risotto - really good, pretty hard to go wrong 
- Osso Bucco - cooked well but was overly strong and salty, 2 people sharing and we couldn't eat it all because it was overwhelming
- Duck - some of the worst I've had. The skin was not seared (what?!), it was wet and undercooked. The breast itself was VERY rare, honestly too rare. Both of those things combined with it being cut into HUGE slabs made it just gross. 
- Crumb pudding - dry and lacking flavor.

Bummed overall, but glad we finally went.
author: Ashley B.

description:
Their menu is somewhat limited and their appetizer and salad portion sizes are quite small for the $$. We tried their salmon and mushroom entrees and their deviled egg appetizer.  The deviled egg is just one soft boiled egg with a lot of spicy pepper sprinkled on it with the egg sitting on an oily pepper sauce. You might think $5 for a soft boiled egg is a bit of a stretch, but the pepper topping and sauce made it worth it.  The entrees were great too, although I would say the price point was a bit high and the salmon could have used a bit more flavoring, but overall we enjoyed everything we bought. The chocolate cake with caramel ice cream was not the best, but was pretty good.

The ambiance was very romantic, the waiters on the other hand although very efficient and quick can learn to smile a little more.
author: Sharanya A.

description: Had the tasting menu and my favorites were the pasta and steak! Wine was delicious and the sommelier was awesome. Salads were fresh and well balanced. How do they make a simple tomato salad so tasty?! Great service and food in a cozy atmosphere. Famous squid ink noodles and deviled egg were just ok. Salads, pasta and beef were better.
author: Lisa H.

description:
Custom earthy plates, curated Chinese desserty utensils, & legally haunted #melvinbelli tables? I am so down. 4 stars food x decor, +1 star for awes service.

(^_^) Beef Tongue $8 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/octavia-san-francisco?select=wThtBEXHU-ACKBqgvfRZcQ)
(^_^) Service
(^_^) Quailman $23 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/octavia-san-francisco?select=QKiWIfLp8XmbU9eD6l9IRA)
(^_^) Tongue Broth x Bread (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/octavia-san-francisco?select=bwlhpqk1WA_gf8zCTwB7Gg)
(^_^) Asparagus $6 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/octavia-san-francisco?select=J9ju6jK36fgwvgucmE2XEw)
(^_^) Silverware (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/octavia-san-francisco?select=cyBDbeaWMwhGwq5nqZ-TuA)
(^_^) Plates & Dishes (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/octavia-san-francisco?select=A5S7nbsy4hojneUaXdhkpA)
(^_^) Tables, Decor (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/octavia-san-francisco?select=nO9ZIbifYWbt6WSSbMYl8g)
(^_^) Bottomless Iced Tea $4 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/octavia-san-francisco?select=z8SbVF6JKDaNUCubksu2tQ)

(-_^) Oysters $3.5ea (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/octavia-san-francisco?select=r6FM0pEc6DcWpWw_unQ54g)
(-_^) Salad (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/octavia-san-francisco?select=_7TMcRF6ZeAgFarTta_VPA)

(-_-) Typography (didn't photograph!)

Plenty of restos nowadays do the two-part name; lots do the address-as-name trend. This place takes not just its own addy but the whole moctafoctan street. After my experience, I can see why.
author: Dan B.

description:
Delicious, scrumptious meal. We ate so much we had a hard time getting up and walking home. Amazing service. My boyfriend had made the reservation noting that it was my birthday and they'd put a happy birthday from Octavia card on our table -- subtle but much appreciated. 

Only real downside is that they forgot to give us our leftover (most of the duck entree), which we didn't realize until we were halfway home :/
author: Rowena L.

description:
You meet an old friend for dinner at the corner of Octavia and Bush. Over glasses of sauvignon blanc and thoughtfully plated dishes, you catch up on the last two years that has somehow flown up. 

Maybe the Lychee Citrus Crush from happy hour had something to do with it, but my friend and I were a bit infatuated with the place as soon as we gazed into the restaurant. The cool and modern ambiance, the low but warm lighting, open kitchen, and rustic decor all wrapped together very nicely - kind of like the living space of my dreams.

I am a huge fan of a simple menu. It tells me: here's what my chef was inspired to create today. Here are the highlights for me:

Local Halibut Crudo - delightfully refreshing pieces of halibut paired with avocado and fresh tomatoes. The toasted pistachios were unexpected but more than welcome.

Bodge Bay Black Cod - aside from the tender and flaky cod, I have to say the charred tomatoes really stole the show here. A must order.

Wildflower Honey Crumb Pudding - I was expecting more of a bread pudding but the texture was more of a nice wheat bread, and the creme fraiche and toffee added the perfect balance of sweetness and texture. Loved this dish for sharing. 
 
Topped with the endearing service, reasonable price points, curated drink selection, on and on, I was sold.

If you're looking for a modern, chic spot to catch up with girlfriends, a place to step up your date nights, or a treat to pamper your family, this is it.
author: Linda X.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday night for dinner with a friend. She had made reservations so we were seated immediately. Our waiter was cordial and gave us good wine recommendations. He recommended a light and crisp chardonnay to go with out food. No complaints in regards to the service.

FOOD was decent. We ordered: the deviled egg, chilled squid ink noodles, corn soup, tagliatelle, and pork loin. Portion sizes are small. And we split all of the five dishes.

Not sure if we misunderstood the concept, but the deviled egg was a bit confusing to us, as it didn't seem deviled. It was really just a boiled egg...that had some seasoning on it...that we cut open. The squid ink noodles were interesting and novel to me. But my friend commented that she didn't like it very much. Other than that, I thought it was decently prepared and not bland. The next dish that came out was our corn soup, which I thought was very well done. It was a little sweet and pretty flavorful. The tagliatelle was a favorite for both my friend and I. Flavorful, well done pasta. The last dish that came out was the pork loin, which for me, was not the most flavorful. They put a mustard sauce below the pork loin, but it was overwhelmingly mustardy when I ate the two together. And significantly less flavorful when I ate the pork loin on its own. I also found the pork loin a bit too chewy for my liking. 

Personally my favorites were the corn soup and the tagliatelle. But what sticks out in my mind is the small portion sizes and how pricey it was.
author: Julie L.

description:
Food was amazing! Loved this place - definitely deserves the 4.5 on Yelp. My favorite dish was the saffron pasta. Perfectly cooked and seasoned (wish the portion was larger). My boyfriend fell in love with the steak! It was perfectly charred on the outside and perfectly pink on the inside. 

The appetizers sounded so normal on the menu but we were blown away by the green beans. On the menu they called it "beans" so we thought it was going to be black beans or something and when it turned out to be green beans we were like okay...its just green beans. But after I took a bite, I just couldn't stop salivating. The sauce that was drizzled on the green beans was super bomb! 

Was too full to try dessert but that means I'll go back again.
author: Rohenne L.

description:
The menu sounded more exciting than the actual food.  It wasn't bad, but nothing to 'wow' about.   My BF and I shared a squid ink appetizer:  rather hard noodles.   I had a dish of 'little gem' that was more like the glorified Caesar salad; the dessert, 'wildflower honey pudding' we shared was very dry that we only ate 1/2.   
Overall, what you get for the price you pay, I was a bit hesitant to give more than a 2-star rating.
author: Peaceful S.

description: This is the perfect spot to go to catch up with a good friend over great food. Everything is shareable - my friend and I wanted to split the butternut squash soup (delicious) and they prepared one portion in two separate bowls. Definitely order the bread - you won't be sorry! We didn't love the kale salad, but the tagliatelle was absolutely delicious. Deviled egg is actually a soft-boiled egg, but it was cooked and seasoned to perfection.
author: Emily F.

description: Amazing place. Every course was way above par, way above expectations. After awhile it was just notable.. try the tasting menu. Service was down to earth and super attentive--e.g. I said I don't like cinnamon (in the context of a pear spiced lemonade they had), and the server swapped out the desert from one with cinnamon to one with chocolate without me saying boo. Will be back.
author: Stanka I.

description:
Text message from my sister: "Want to eat dinner on Wednesday?"
Me: Yes. Where?
Sister: Octavia

I have never been to Frances before but Octavia was a great mid-week treat. 
Their bread was amazing. We had 3 slices each, haha.
To share- the beef tongue, really tender! We gobbled it up. ($8)
Sister had the Chicken Roulade which she had at Frances previously. Delicious with sausage stuffed in the middle. Super moist and yummy! ($27)
I had the Rib-Eye. Medium rare with some root veggies and greens atop. Perfectly seasoned and cooked. ($38)

For dessert we opted for the Warm Chocolate Souffle Tart with Salted Caramel ice cream. INHALED. ($9)

Service was EH...pretty inattentive and lackluster. The napkins were linty and got little lint bits over my black dress. The table next to us was offered black napkins which we were not. Inconsistent in service standards. 

Anyways, food is good but I say don't expect much from the staff.
author: Angela D.

description:
Chef Melissa Perello's, known for Frances (1 Mich star in the Castro), opened Octavia back in April 2015 - replacing Baker and Banker. As expected, reviews have been consistently high, and reservations (at normal times) are tough to snag, so I came in with high expectations. I was fairly disappointed in Frances, and I was worried this would be a repeat: an over-hyped American (new) restaurant. 

Let me tell you. The hype is real guys, Octavia is awesome and IMO better than Frances. 

APPS
* Complimentary sparkling - Woohoo!
* DEVILED EGG - 4.5 STARS: A single perfectly poached, runny egg topped with a delicious spice mix. Scrumptious. 
* CHILLED SQUID INK NOODLES - 4 STARS: A really interesting, unexpected combination.
* GRILLED BEETS AND BURRATA - 4.5 STARS: This burratta is pastier than usual, but worked well with the grilled beets and chips. Will order again!
* Complimentary bread & butter - 5 STARS: De. Licious. Bread.

PRIMI:
* TAGLIATELLE - 2 STARS: Tasted fishy, and not in a good way. Very buttery. Weird pasta texture, and not rolled thin enough.
* DUCK - 4.5 STARS: Really tender, delicious duck

DESSERT:
* CHOCOLATE SOUFFLE - 4.5 STARS: Molteny chocolate cake with an amazing cookie-like crust. 

My only gripe is that it took 30-40 minutes between apps and entrees. Overall, most everything was just incredibly delicious and I can't wait to come back.
author: Jess C.

description:
TLDR
I'd do a 3.5/5 if I could.
Decor - Simple and pleasant - (5/5)
Service - Polite, approachable and well timed - (5/5)
Food:
Baked Levain - Crunchy crust, dense, fresh and flavorful - Excellent (5/5)
Chilled Squid Ink Noodles - Good texture, al dente and delightful - Excellent (5/5)
Smoked Mushroom Pozole - Unorthodox and delicious - Good (4/5)
Petit Fillet- Good quality meat, nothing you can't do at home - Okay (3/5)
Peruvian Purple Polenta - Too many Peas! - Nah (1/5)
Toasted Angel Food Cake - Light cake with rich ice cream -V. Good (4.5/5)
Warm Chocolate Souffle tart  - Rich and not overly sweet tart with delicious salted caramel ice cream  - V. Good (4.5/5)

After reading about Frances losing it's michelin star, we decided to get dinner at Octavia to taste Melissa Perello's instead. Although does an executive chef cook at the restaurant?Nevertheless, we made it there on Thursday night. We found street parking a block away. The decor of the place is simple and contemporary, not overbearing like some other places and still very pleasant. They don't have a liquor license but their wine list is expansive. Sommelier was helpful and not snobbish (we've all dealt with that person!) and service was friendly.
We started with Sarah's house baked Levain, Chilled Squid Ink Noodles and Smoked Mushroom Pozole.  Sarah's house baked Levain with the cultured butter  was wonderful, we ate it all up before any other thing came. It was crunchy on the outside but the crust wasn't too big with soft, fresh and dense on the inside. Chilled Squid Ink Noodles were delicious and went well with the lemon and fennel flavor. Their take on Pozole was interesting and flavorful. However, I don't know how I feel about the popcorn in it. For the main course we got the Petit Fillet and Peruvian Purple Polenta. We got Petit fillet as medium rare, the meat was good quality and went well with accompaniments. It was nothing special that you could not do at your grill. Peruvian Purple Polenta was my least favorite. It is hard to make polenta bad in my opinion but the high ratio of peas to polenta in it didn't work for me. For dessert, we got the Toasted Angel Food Cake and Souffle tart. The Toasted Angel Food Cake is served with blueberry, mascarpone, lavender ice cream and goes complimented it very well. Cake was light, juicy and not too sweet, the ice cream was delicious too. Warm Chocolate Soufflé tart is accompanied by cocoa nib brittle, salted caramel ice cream, which is quite obviously a good combination. Tart was hot and perfect texture. Ice cream was good too but not as good as Bi-Rite Salted caramel. Overall, I'd go here and get several small dishes and dessert and skip the main course.
author: Kritika K.

description: Months ago, I came in here not knowing about this place. All I wanted was a pastry and coffee. I walked in noticing how nice it was inside. I became shy and embarrassed at how inappropriately dressed I came in, but the staff was still so welcoming! I sat and went straight to the dessert menu and ordered this vanilla ice cream with coconut whipped cream and a chocolate brittle with some coffee. It was FAR from just a pastry and coffee. It was beyond words how wonderful it tasted! Each bite accompanied a mental "oh my god" pleasure-facial expression
author: May A.

description:
4.5 stars rounded up to 5 (the duck was THAT good).

Service was very good.  Knowledgeable staff.  Friendly.  There when you wanted them, not there when you didn't.   I felt really bad since, due the ever-increasing shittiness of Bay Area traffic, we were more than 30 minutes late for our reservation.   The staff made no big deal of it (thank you!) though.

For drink, they don't have a full liquor license, so you have wine, beer and loophole cocktails mostly with vermouth.  My friend had a madera and tonic which was very good.  I had a wonderful Chenin Blanc with a light, crisp fruity flavor and a minerally finish.

Food:

Deviled Egg:  Perfectly cooked soft-boiled egg with some spices and chile thrown on there.   Really enjoyed it.  If you don't appreciate the value of a perfectly cooked egg, the subtleness and refinement of this dish may not register.

Spring Greens and Burrata:  Fresh greens, burrata and asparagus.  I adore spring veggies and burrata.  Needless to say, we were very pleased with this dish.  Generous portion too.

Papardelle:  Toasted walnut and brown butter pesto with aged balsamic and cress.  I am not sure where the cress was in this dish, but I don't care....it was sumptuous and comforting and delicious.  Perfect pasta and sauce was delectable.  

Duck Breast:  Best duck I have ever eaten.  The breast was perfectly medium rare.  Silky smooth, delicate and toothsome all at the same time.  There was the perfect amount of delicious fat and the skin was so perfectly crispy.  The duck on its own was a trip to flavor country.  It was served with grilled escarole, fennel and some type of pepper.  They all added a necessary and welcome crunch.  It was also served with these bready/crouton things that must have been soaked in crack.  Really, really impressive.

What I liked most about this place was that it was unique and different while being comforting and familiar and non-pretentious at the same time.   I have been getting so tired of all these high-concept restaurants that ultimately don't deliver on flavor.   This place also seemed like a a good value for the quality that you get.  The four dishes above were more than filling (there was no room for dessert even though we really wanted to order one).  With our food and two drinks each, our bill was $118 before tip.  Not cheap, but I have paid much more for less.

Enjoy.
author: Christian C.

description: Our family did a private dining at the chef's table, and we loved every course. Such a simple dish like heirloom tomato drizzled with olive oil was also so delicious. The eggplant was everyone's best eggplant ever. I particularly loved the seafood dish and the dessert. It was a nice touch to print a menu with our names on. A very memorable dinner indeed.
author: Esther L.

description:
Honestly Octavia was just okay - I would give it a 3.5/5. The atmosphere is nice with a dimly lit romantic vibe. The servers were nice and the service was fine. The food however, was a disappointment. For the price point and reviews I would have expected a lot more.

Oysters - 2/5 stars $4/each SKIP - I've had better oysters at Fisherman's Wharf. They were very sub-par.

Deviled Egg -  4/5 stars -  Definitely interesting and tasty but nothing to be raved about. It's essentially just a soft-boiled egg (cooked to perfection) with spices. We are going to try replicating it at home.

Chilled Squid Ink Noodles - 3.5/5 - The noodles were refreshing and lemony. Definitely interesting and worth trying but not anything incredibly amazing

Spring Greens Salad - 3.5/5 - Burrata, Pesto, English Peas, Spinach - again tasty but nothing special

Papperdelle - 5/5 - This was by far my favorite dish of the night, I highly recommend, very flavorful

Duck - 4/5 - Crispy skin, tender meat, delicious - highly recommend

Flourless Chococate Cake - 3/5 - very tasty but also extremely dry, if it was moist it would have been 5/5

I'm glad we came here to try a restaurant I have been hearing so much about but I won't be coming back. The food was good but not exceptional and for $150 I am looking for the latter.
author: Erica C.

description:
Octavia lived up to the hype!  Amazing food, excellent service, and an elegant, inviting setting.

Our group of four shared three appetizers to start:

1) Deviled eggs (amazing!  I would recommend each person getting their own!)

2) Squid ink noodles - awesome!

3) Pappardelle - excellent, though not really "sharing friendly" (again, consider getting your own!)

I had the petite fillet for my main, and it was wonderful.  The meat was juicy and flavorful, and I loved the eggplant preparation with which it was served.

I had a few bites of my husband's duck, and it was great as well!

The dessert we all shared - the angel food cake with corn ice cream - was exquisite and unique.

We appreciated the fact that you can order wine by the carafe, which was perfect for our little group on a Sunday night.

The service was very friendly, attentive, professional, and efficient.

I enjoyed the setting - it's spacious, elegant, bright, and inviting.  I had last been in the space when it was still Baker and Banker, and I like the fact they've opened up the space and made it brighter.

Overall, Octavia was fantastic!  Highly recommend!
author: Barnali D.

description:
location: street parking available; the interior is so well lit and beautiful! 

service: all servers are very helpful and quick. 

food: 
-bread: amazing crust and chewy mushy inside. 6/5 
-deviled egg: not your traditional type of deviled egg; it's a soft boiled egg smothered in amazzzzzzzzing spices. 5/5
-squid ink pasta: if you like lemony things - this is for you. if not... then probably not the best choice. has a slight seafood-y aftertaste, but nothing overwhelming. 4/5
-beef tartare: I definitely didn't like the olives in it.. but the beef was great and the garlic toast was deeeelicious! 3/5
-burratta salad: don't be fooled - there is a lot of buratta in it. initially, it looks like a tiny bit on top but it's layered and delicious. 5/5
-pappardelle: this was a bit too bland for me, I wouldn't order this again. 1/5 

overall a wonderful dining experience! I hope to come back if their menu changes
author: Shelley K.

description: When my fish arrived cold, they reheated the fish and presented it to me as now "medium instead of medium-rare" - recooked fish is disgusting. When I complained, they cooked it to the point where it was inedible. They then charged full price, and the management hid behind the poor waiter rather than come and explain why we should pay for terrible food. With so many good restaurants around, why would you take a chance on this?
author: Schnoodlin G.

description: First off, the atmosphere in the space is great, with big open windows and dark wood decor. The service was great; they helped us with wine selection and recommendations. The squid ink noodles are a must-try, and the salmon was cooked to perfection. But save room for dessert!! The chocolate souffle was the best I've had.
author: Melanie U.

description: Good food and service, in a gorgeous setting with lots of natural light. The pappardelle was a highlight, but everything was delicious.
author: Everly H.

description: A girlfriend and I had reservations at Octavia to celebrate my birthday, which coincidentally is only one day off of Executive Chef Melissa Perello's birthday. We had walked several miles through the city and wound our way back a bit early just as they were opening the doors. They threw the doors open and greeted us with the same enthusiasm as though we were family that has just come in from a journey. We grabbed a bottle of Pinot Noir and after some deliberations, decided to try the ten course chef's tasting of small plates. As plate after plate arrived for us, our conversation would be delightfully derailed by yet another fresh pairing of elements and flavors. Gotta love it when a bite of food makes you stop in your tracks! The wait staff were wholly unobtrusive and never missed a beat. Absolutely will be back with friends to do it again.
author: Mila F.

description: Fantastic place.  Octavia is now on my "let's go back" list.  They have casual but nice ambiance, good service, great drinks and excellent food.  I enjoyed dry sherry to start with, and we did a beautiful bottle of Riesling afterwards.  Our server who helped us to pick the bottle, he gave us some options and described each wine really well (with passion).  As for food, each dish is relatively small, which I like because I can try more dishes.  I had Oysters, Tokyo Turnips & Radishes, Cucumber salad, Sea Urchin Tagliatelle, and grilled King Salmon.  All were delicious, but my favorite dish was Chilled Squeed Ink Noodle.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Akiko O.

description: Disappointing. Not what it used to be. Service is good but food was underwhelming and even boring. I would not go back nor would I recommend it. Not the same Octavia that originally won so many people over.
author: Nala P.

description:
Hands down one of the best, if not THE best meal I've had in SF yet.

My bf found this place and took me here for our two year anniversary. Even a month out, he could only get 5:15PM reservations, but it worked out well.

First up was the bread and butter. If it was just that, we probably could have still left quite satisfied. The bread was amazing. 

We shared a carafe of the white house wine and started out with the "Deviled Egg" and Chilled Squid Ink Noodles. The egg was an interesting interpretation, adding a lot of spices and textures to a familiar dish. While it was far from my favorite of the evening, its presentation and taste were so unique I was still thrilled. The noodles were also interesting. Slightly tangy, but without a distinct flavor present, it was exciting for my taste buds.

For our entrees, I ordered the petit filet and my bf ordered the duck. AMAZING.

But it doesn't stop there. For dessert, I ordered the float and my bf ordered the lemon angel food cake. My dessert was a treat for the eyes and stomach. My bf's dessert was just as amazing. The tartness of the lemon was nicely balanced and I don't think I've had such creative and tasty desserts before. [If it's any indication how much I loved dessert, I stumbled upon the lady responsible for Octavia's dessert creations and I follow her on Instagram now!]

Looking for a lovely restaurant for dinner? GO HERE! It's amazing. The food is some of the best, the service is on par, and the decor is super cute.
author: Leana L.

description:
Octavia was the perfect restaurant to complement a Union Square holiday ice skating date. Well done, boyfriend. The twinkling lights and rustic/warm interior just screamed "Christmas in San Francisco."

Atmosphere: Refined and modern "rugged" typical of SF. Slightly dim lighting with candles, wood tables and hefty wood beams in the restaurant. This would be a great place for a special date or even a work dinner. The chef's table in the kitchen looks cool for that too. We had reservations at 5 pm and the place filled up completely by around 5:30/6. Not surprised though.

Food: This is where the star gets knocked. We ordered the deviled egg which is more like a soft-boiled egg (still good though), salad to share (too salty), and gnocchi (very good). For the entree, I ordered the pork loin which was amazing. The pieces were thick cut and the apple butter was flavorful. The side of vegetables with curry (I think) did not mesh well with the meat, in my opinion. They were also pretty salty. A little disappointed by the saltiness of 2 of the dishes but still good.

Service: Attentive. They ask if you have any type of obligation after the meal so that they can course the dishes properly.
author: Salma R.

description:
I really, really wanted to like Octavia.  I swear I really do.  I was so looking forward to going here, but I'm thinking I just really ordered everything wrong.  

We were greeted quickly and seated right away by the hostess.  The place was lovely and very relaxing to me with the dark wood throughout.  The menu looked great and I was really excited as I've heard great things about the food.  Unfortunately, it just didn't really work for me.  I started with the oysters.  My oyster was very salty, almost briny, and may have set the tone for my meal.  The deviled egg was good, I think the highlight of my meal.  I enjoyed the sunchoke soup that my friend ordered and wish I ordered that instead of the roasted cauliflower salad, which was good as well, but I still had a salty taste in my mouth from the oyster apparently and things just tasted slightly off to me during the whole meal.  For my entree, I had the malfatti ricotta dumplings.  I guess I was thinking of some ricotta dumplings that I recently had else where, because I was disappointed at how dense these dumpling were.  I was hoping they were more on the light or fluffy side.  Dessert did help finish the meal with a high note.  The eton mess was different, but delicious.  

In regard to service, our server was ok, but we were seated next to another table of 4 that had a different server who was more engaging and entertaining.  I really wished we had him instead as our server wasn't really as engaging or descriptive as he was.  She didn't really offer much when we asked for suggestions on the menu and I noticed that the other tables were being served bread, which we eventually got after I asked her for it.  Again, she wasn't rude or anything like that, just not much initiative to offer things.  

I do think Octavia is worth trying again eventually.  With so many places to still try though, it may not float to the top of my list right away.
author: Maria S.

description:
Had their duck breast which was amazingly tender.  Cauliflower, deviled egg, and broccolini soup was all very good.  Only the dumpling dish was very doughy to me...felt like a ball of dough with no texture.

Parking here is horrific!!
author: Patrick C.

description:
The good:
All the food we ordered was amazing!  Even the bread was warm and flavorful.

The service was very accommodating.  We were high maintenance: we asked to move tables, then asked to close a window because it was cold inside, and they didn't hesitate to help us out.

The bad:
All the food took really long to come out.  And the bread didn't come out until after the main course, which was odd.

Wines were more tart and light than what we're used to.  They even warned us when we wanted to order a carafe of the zin that it would taste more like a Pinot.  (If you have to warn people, maybe you should find another zin?). So we got the Syrah instead, but it had the same deviation from the norm.
author: Rego S.

description:
Went there last night for a celebration dinner with my wife. This is the old Banker & Baker spot, which is tucked away in a quiet part of pacific heights. The food was excellent last night and the service was impeccable. The ambiance is also really cool given the open kitchen concept and very rustic furniture. 

We had the oysters, deviled eggs, crab, squid ink noodles, pappardelle, duck breast, filet and then the honey crumble and angel cake for dessert (wow, that was a lot of food). Honestly, all of them were great but if I had to skip one it would be the crab and if I had to pick a favorite it would be the deviled egg. 

Only downside to the place is that there's no where to wait inside or nearby if you show up early for your reservation, so just be aware of that.
author: Jay G.

description:
Amazing dinner. Everything we had was delicious. 

Their homemade bread alone makes me want to come back. Our favorite dishes of the night was the halibut crudo and the bone marrow ragu.

Can't wait to go back to try the Squid Ink noodles!
author: Lucy D.

description:
Took a friend out for their bday. Even with reservations we still didn't get seated for another 15 minutes so that's probably saying the place is popular. The services once seated was good though.

The appetizers were awesome and you must try the deviled egg make sure you tell em to keep the bread coming which also surprisingly tasted great. The gem salad is a must it tasted very very fresh  and the peas were consistently popping with every bite. 

However the entrees to me were not that empresive . I had the snapper the portion was good but the fLavor bland to me. I took a bite of my friends steak, but it seemed bland to me too. 

So overall I think it's worthy of four stars just need to work on the entrees
author: Ahmed H.

description:
Not sure how Octavia was given one Michelin star, the food was unimpressive and the all the plates were really small.
Ordered the fillet.  Tasted like an over-cooked London Broil.  Not tender at all and very chewy meet - tasted cheap.
There was a gentleman that said he was an owner.  He was a really unfriendly person to be greeting guests at the door.  Had a big attitude.  
With so many good restaurant in the city I would certainly skip Octavia.
author: John W.

description:
I loved Octavia! I made a reservation online through Open Table, which was easy to do. I reserved 30 days in advance just to be safe, but you can make reservations closer to the night you want to go. The service here was incredible, and I found Octavia to be a casual and fantastic dinner out.

We ordered the Deviled egg, little gem salad, gioia burrata, grilled petite fillet with mushrooms and the warm chocolate souffle tart. The deviled egg was beautiful, but I found it to be the most underwhelming dish of the night. It was basically an egg with spices on top. The bread that came out though was amazing and fresh, I could eat that bread forever!!

Next up, burrata and little gem salad, were both great. There was A LOT of burrata on the plate, so it's a great table share. The salad was dressed perfectly, and had persimmons and pistachios, a great accompaniment to the burrata.

The petite fillet, I drool. It was cooked perfectly and the trumpet mushrooms they cooked with the steak were so flavorful. The steak itself had a slight mushroom flavor and was seared on the outside.

Lastly, the dessert was possibly my favorite. The molten chocolate was perfectly baked and it had such a deep chocolate flavor. 

I would definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for a birthday dinner, date night, or even a fun and nice dinner with friends! While it's a nicer restaurant, it's pretty casual inside and would be fun for any occasion.
author: Lauren G.

description: We ended up revisiting Octavia for their Valentine's Day pre fixe menu because some friends gave us a gift certificate as a wedding present, and we really liked everything on the menu!  Their bread and wine are still good, and each course was delicious, although I'm still not sure I agree with the Michelin star rating.  Glad we gave it a second chance though!
author: Michelle K.

description:
I had a week of eating in San Francisco and Octavia was one of my first stops. The menu seemed short and sweet but a friend had promised this would be a meal to remember and it did not disappoint. 

The atmosphere is cozy but modern. They do require a credit card to hold a reservation so only book if you are sure you can attend. We ordered family style and tried: 
-Deviled egg - not sure why it is called this as it in no way resembles a deviled egg but it had great flavor with a lot of spices and chilis
-Halibut crudo - delicate and beautiful with avocado crema, strawberries and chilis. 
-Tagliatelle - this was served with fennel and homemade ricotta. The noodle was more like a fettucinie as my friend pointed out and she was right. This was good but not great. 
-Salmon - the figs, squash blossom and brown butter sauce made this dish POP! We even asked for extra sauce and soaked it up with their homemade bread. Yum. 
-Eton Mess - wow one of the most unique versions of this dessert I've ever had and I absolutely loved it! 
-Short cake with peaches was clean and fresh but I wouldn't order it again. 

Great meal with solid food.
author: Brittany F.

description:
We had a great time at Octavia, and the service was unbeatable! We had a 5:30 reservation and needed to be at a show at 7, and our waitress was on top of everything to make sure we got our drinks, appetizers and meal with plenty of time to enjoy each course and pay before we had to leave, which we really appreciated.

The freshly baked bread was delicious (and now they sell it for $8 a loaf too!). We had the burrata plate and a salad for appetizers and followed it up with the osso bucco and pork loin dish. It was all great, but it was a ton of food, and if you aren't starving you could probably skip the appetizers or share an entree.

Overall it was a really great experience, and I would love to visit Octavia again (when my bank account allows it)
author: Sophie C.

description: Loved our experience here last Thursday. Scott was our server and he was what made the night. He was very pleasant, professional and welcoming. He gave us superb recommendations as he engaged with us in such an unforgettable way. To start I told him I wanted a glass of red. He asked what I usually look for in a red and I told him, I typically like fruit forward wines from Rhône Valley, in France however I wanted a new world wine. He recommended Copain and I was so pleased. My girlfriends and I were all about sharing and even though it really isn't suggested he definitely pointed us in a great direction by not over ordering. We enjoyed the deviled eggs, snow peas with burrata and the crudo starter. My main was the salmon, cooked to perfection while the girls ordered the 5 spice duck which was my favorite and the steak. We were indeed impressed. Absolutely make room for dessert because that soufflé will have you begging for more! It was made with love as it hit our table in its perfect timing. Nice warm outside layer but the inside just a tad warmer with some toffee on the bottom accompanied by ice cream. Wow! Just wow! Everyone who was a part of the Octavia team was amazing. Five star service in a quaint casual atmosphere is just the ticket to feeling like a million bucks! Thanks Scott!
author: Debbie L.

description:
This is a great spot for date night. Ambiance is just right and the servers are good. 

We had:

Deviled egg - not actually a deviled egg, which means I actually like it. 5 stars. 

Chilled squid ink noodles - great, could be even better warm or with something else on them. 4 stars but still worth ordering. 

Fried green tomatoes - uniquely prepared with mushrooms. Standout dish. 5 stars. 

Zucchini soup - we both commented that we wouldn't normally like zucchini soup, but... 5 stars. 

Calamari campanelle - skip, too salty. 3 stars. 

Burrata - I like it better in olive oil. This had more of a tangy sauce. 3.5 stars. 

Wild mushroom panade - much more bread and cheese than mushroom, but if you feel like cheesy bread pudding (heavy), it is tasty. 4 stars.
author: Mike G.

description:
Have been a fan of Melissa Perello's and I love Frances. The food here at Octavia was great as well but nothing blew me away.

Best dish of the night was the shrimp tagliatelle. 

We arrived on time and still had to wait about 15 minutes for our table.

Service was good. I mentioned that we were celebrating a birthday on Opentable and they did follow through with a candle on our dessert at the end. I do however wish they explain what the dish is when they bring the dishes to the table.

The space was a lot more open than when it was Baker and Banker but tables are still really tight. We have to move the table to get in and out. It was a cold night bit the restaurant was really hot even with the door open. 

Aside from the tight space, my only gripe is really not having enough non-alcoholic drink options. The only soda option was Izze and only one flavor. Would love to see house made sodas.

Overall a great meal but I prefer Frances over Octavia.
author: Andy W.

description:
Beautifully presented, innovative takes on straightforward classics from Melissa Perello.

Upon entering Octavia, diners will immediately feel welcome. The natural wood, pale walls, and large windows seem to say, "Welcome home." 

The menu is as unpretentious and well put together as the dining room. An interesting appetizer is Perllo's interpretation of a deviled egg ($5): poached then brined, it is perched atop a good-sized dollop of fresno chile relish and coated with marash pepper and spices. Combined with the heat from the peppers, the runny yolk is just delicious. Toped with bottarga and served with fennel and lemon oil, the chilled squid ink noodles ($7) were tasty, but a little salty. With a refreshing hint of lemon, the linguine al pesto ($14) is cooked perfectly al dente and paired with winter greens, a serious helping of parmesan and fennel.

The food is great, but the staff makes the dining experience even better:  from Samantha, the hostess, to the servers and bussers, everyone is awesome.

House wines, a Paul Hobbs sauvignon blanc and chardonnay blend and a Gros Ventre Sonoma coast pinot, are available by the glass, carafe or bottle at reasonable prices. In addition, the list boasts numerous other gems available by the glass and by the bottle.

There is no doubt in her abilities: with Octavia, Perello has done it again.
author: CJ G.

description:
Very good food and service. 

For the life of me cannot remember all of what six of us ate here, though I recollect we came away full and happy, albeit with much lighter wallets. The big front windows afforded a full view of my friends Porsche getting another ticket for lacking a front license plate which was amusing and we even saw some crazies walking by.

The only misses was the deviled egg and squid ink pasta. The deviled eggs taste great, but I told my friends I can serve them perfectly poached eggs all day for $5 a pop at home. On the other hand the squid ink pasta is just too basic. It either needs some additions or should be replaced on the menu. 

Although... if choosing between Octavia or it's sister restaurant Frances I would definitely go to Frances. No misses there at all once the reservation is secured.
author: Easwud C.

description: Very disappointing experience last night. I booked a month in advance for Valentine's Day to go with partner. There was no mention of pre fixed menu as "valentines day menu" when booked and we didn't know about it until we arrived. Option of ordering from regular a la carte wasn't there and none of their signature dishes were on the menu. Partner is vegetarian and limited the option even more as their entree were beef or fish. My beef was uncooked (not rare) and cold. Felt cheated on with 150$ per person with wine pairing!
author: Me M.

description:
Creative and mostly delicious food, great service in a great ambiance. 

Food:
- Complementary bread and butter: 5*. Adds a lot of value to the dining experience. 
- Oysters: 4*. Great if you are in the mood for some oysters. I've had better ones in the city, though.
- Deviled eggs: 4*. I loved it but it really does not have a "unique" taste. Perfect presentation, though.
- Tomato and Watermelon salad: 5*. Highlight of the day. Very unique and tasty
- Tagliatella (fish): 5*. Best warm dish of the day. It was really very well done. 
- Zucchini soup: 3*. I've had high hopes but it unfortunately did not meet it. Still tastes decent, though.
- Chilled squid Ink Pasta: 4*. It's a salad alternative and a very good one for that purpose. Not sure if I would order the next time I visit though.

Dessert:
- Bread crumbs: 2.5*. Nothing special really. 
- Strawberry float: 5*. Unique taste, light flavor. 

Drinks:
- Wine: 5*. Great selection as well as house wines. 

Bill: $150 for 2 (which makes it $$$$ unlike Yelp's grading).
author: Gokhan T.

description: The overall food is mediocore. The duck is so raw that I had to ask server to recook the roasted duck. Then the remade duck became too gard to chew. The only small highlight is devil's egg. Both appearance and taste are very fantastic. I ordered twice right after the dessert.
author: Haixing L.

description:
I really wanted to love this new restaurant by Melissa Perello. The dishes were of high quality, but some of them worked better than others...in particular, the artichoke was delicious - like fried chicken! The pasta dishes - first the squid ink was tasteless, and the salt cod was too firm and didn't marry well with the noodle. 

The service is what pulls this rating down. It felt like nobody was coordinating the kitchen. There wasn't a sense of ownership of the dining room, nobody cared about the guests and their meal. Gaps are fine between courses, but only if the server communicates
author: Cate R.

description:
Delightful spot in Pac Heights, sister restaurant to Frances in the Castro, and a menu that changes daily-Octavia is a great place for a second date!

While they don't have wine by the oz, their wine menu is extensive and cutesy and you can get a carafe to share. We ordered the Squash Salad, Summer Beans, and deviled egg (not really a deviled egg; just a soft boiled egg on a hot chile relish) to start. For entrees, the Polenta was outstanding!

Atmosphere is very quite. We called about a week ahead for a reservation for a late dinner (9:30) and were easily seated upon arrival.

Overall, definitely a 5-star place!
author: Andrew C.

description: Love this Restaurant. The food and the deserts are soooo good. I have been to many fine dining restaurant but Octavia has an authentic taste. Just love the food here..
author: Fanny G.

description:
4.5 stars - yay! octavia! congrats on the one star! came in with a friend on a tuesday evening and the place was packed! such good ambiance though - i also really loved baker and banker at this location previously.  the restaurant is really open with a good view of the kitchen - such warmth!  we were immediately seated for our 730 reservation and offered water.  

the menu is simple and straightfoward - small bites, appetizers, and entrees.  i obviously wanted to try EVERYTHING - so we ordered close to that.  started with: deviled egg, squid ink noodles, continued with roasted cauliflower, turnip greens, and got serious with petit filet and duck breast. my friend also got a dessert concoction (the float?) that he really liked, but i got a glass of yummy dessert wine - miraflores semillon. also - the selections are amazing! literally i think there is something for everyone! we picked a great red from the new world section and were super pleased with it.

to be honest, i wasnt super impressed by the bites - egg or noodles (which seem to be overwhelmingly popular! both were a tad too salty for me, and..i guess i dont really like cold seafoody noodles? who knew!  the turnip greens, on the other hands, were deeelicious! they were my fave dish beside my entree.  cauliflower was also yumms - the gremolata paired just perfectly.  THEN my duck entree! OMG! soooo good. and i've had my fair share of delicious duck entrees. but this was cooked just so perfectly, so juicy and tender and i want to eat at least 18 more pounds of it. nod nod.  the bread they served was also great, warm with salted butter yayyy.  i'd come back again in some time..!
author: Christina L.

description:
We spent a wonderful evening celebrating our 6 year anniversary at this lovely restaurant. 

First course included the "deviled egg", roasted cauliflower, and tuna conserva. In reality the deviled egg is a slow poached pouch of yolky goodness topped with a fresno chile creation that gave the dish some delightful spice and smoke. The roasted cauliflower was a sweet surprise with figs while the tuna had a basil Nicoise vibe. 

Second course include the light a refreshing little gems with fuyu persimmons tossed in a caesaresque  dressing. Followed by a rich and decadent gulf shrimp tagliatelle, the shrimp were plumb and fresh and everything was tossed with fennel and pimento.

For the main we shared the petite filet which had been butter poached (yes that is an actual thing) for two hours and served with ciopolini. I can't even doesn't do this dish justice. Imagine a perfect tender petite filet filled magically with buttery goodness. So heavenly and relish.

Dessert was a chocolate soufflé tart. Picture a crispy chocolate shell filled to the brim with pillow of rich thick chocolate.

Wines included a bottle of Syrah and carafe of the cab franc both paired perfectly with everything. 

In all it was a memorable evening with amazing attentive service. I was not bothered by the noise level but we dined in a corner window seat which likely helped diminish the sound issue.

Would I go back yes yes yes! 

Side note I think Judy would be adorable with a bow tie just saying! Thank you Matias for the wonderful service. Thank you Melissa for your food and for cooking up a memorable anniversary meal for us! Yes lucky me she was cooking away that evening.
author: Matthew B.

description:
3.5 stars, rounded down to 3 due to the snail pace service. Still somewhat new, but c'mon.

They did a great job updating the space and making it more cozy and well light with the exposed wood/rustic feel and romantic lighting.

Our favorite dishes were the starters - the fried eggplant and the halibut crudo were both outstanding.  The only disappointing aspect of those dishes were how small the portions were.

The saffron tonnarelli was also good.

The deviled eggs weren't ordering (inmho).

The pork chop was good, but daunting.  They're rather generous and give you a large piece, but you realize a huge slab of it is fat and it's a huge piece of meat that covered half of the plate it's served on.. just not incredibly appetizing, and surprising given how small the starter portions are.

Overall, the meal was good and I would return in a year+? The service was terrible in the sense that it took forever every step of the way.  It looked as though they had a good amount of staff working the small restaurant but literally every course we'd be left sitting with empty dishes waiting for our plates to be cleared, more bread, water please!!!, etc.  Even at the end we were trying to get out of there and they just took forever - we dined with 3 of us, 6pm reservation and we finally left around 8:45-9pm.
author: Melody T.

description:
I can comfortably upgrade my review to 5 stars now!  Just went back to Octavia a few nights ago and had a great experience.  The food was amazing from top to bottom.  Some of the highlights:

Deviled Egg - Great, similar to my experience from last time.  The pepper on the top has the right amount of kick but is not super spicy.

Beef Tongue - Not tough and chewy at all, which was what I was expecting from beef tongue.  Velvety, soft beef with a great beef jus that was both rich and subtle.

Corn Soup - Chef Perello always makes a great soup.  This is no exception.  Extremely smooth, buttery corn soup with a great addition of creme fraiche.

Pork Chop - Well-cooked, juicy and tender medium-rare.

House red by the carafe was pretty light and complemented most of the dishes well.  We had a great time and will be back again!  Hard to split time between Frances and Octavia now.
author: John T.

description: Lovely, elegant and cozy restaurant with excellent and unblemished service.  We enjoyed the deviled egg, the corn soup, fresh bread, calamari and other lovely dishes.  Well balanced and flawlessly executed.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Dare I say that Octavia is better than Frances. Yeah and I totally did during the entire meal. Repeatedly. A lot. And probably enough to annoy my husband but what do I care - he is married to me and stuck with me. I'll be as bold to say it's the best restaurant right now in SF (and totally better than the overhyped State Bird Provisions - which is good but not GREAT).

We tried to recap what we liked the most, so here it is in the order of MY favorites (different than my husband's):

Beef tongue: Apparently beef tongue is fatty, delicate, and pulled-pork like in its consistency. It's not at all chewy. This stuff just melted in your mouth. I had no idea that beef tongue was so delicious. I was always grossed out by the concept, but this dish totally converted me into a beef tongue fiend. Forget the steaks. Cut off all their tongues and give me their milk. Also, I now have a mental note to go to fancy butcher shops and buy a lot of beef tongues to cook.

Chocolate torte (dessert): I thought this would be a standard fare but was feeling the idea of having dessert. I was delightfully wrong. I went to Liholiho for their baked Hawaiian (which is EXCELLENT) but this actually outdid it. It was chocolate HEAVEN. Best of all, the salted caramel melted into the hot torte... and then there were crunchy chunks of dark chocolate around it (yay for food texture!).
