I kept making awful jokes to my husband (that were pretty serious in nature) that I wanted to kidnap the baker and bring him/her home with us. Then lock them in a room with an oven and cocoa.

Romano beans: Had thought of not getting it. So glad we got it. Flash fried so it was very lightly crispy and then there were small fried onion bits on top of it. Second favorite starter.

Halibut crudo: My husband's favorite. For sushi and tartare lovers. Halibut was raw and silky, avocados were buttery and firm, and the crisps were (duh) crispy. 

Saffron tonarelli: Tomatoes were fresh and acidic. Saffron was present but not overwhelming. Dish had just enough oil. So good.

Butter beans and garlic with mushroom soup: Buttery. Creamy. Delicious.

Deviled egg: Poached egg with melty yolk and a lot of hot spicy stuff. Very good. Surprised it wasn't my favorite dish - the egg specials are usually my favorite at every restaurant I go to. Goes to show the caliber of Octavia. Soooo good. This probably would have been my favorite at any other restaurant.

Chilled squid ink noodles: Excellent but not as memorable as the other dishes. 

Oysters: Good.

Also the complimentary bread was served perfectly warm, the butter was fresh and light. Everything was perfect. Wine was excellent (I think it was the Tenuta 2010). Service was attentive and on pointe. Really have nothing bad to say about the restaurant. Ranking the dishes was incredibly hard. Please take all my money.
author: Sylvia L.

description: This is honestly my favorite restaurant in all of San Francisco.  My fiance and I have tried a number of michelin star restaurants in the city and this one is by far the best. The service is amazing, the wait staff so kind and attentive, the food is spectacular.  I would highly recommend the deviled egg and the squid ink noodles, but we have been multiple times and ordered various things, and you really can not go wrong.
author: Sarah J.

description:
Octavia is Michelin starred, but doesn't feel like one - the atmosphere is more casual than one would expect from a restaurant on Michelin's short list. But here the mood fits the neighborhood and the cuisine. 

We had a deviled egg, which is not to be missed (we liked it so much we ordered another one one!) - it's  topped with a spicy and peppery spice mix, reminding of Yemenite Zhug in dry form, and compliment the runnyiness of the egg perfectly. 
Followed by squid ink noodles, which had a perfect texture, with just enough hints of the ocean in taste. 

The Tagliatelle was so great, my partner decreed she would divorce me and marry it instead; and I might do the same myself. 

The chicken confit was the least interesting dish we had. It was still quite good, but wasn't up to par with the dishes leading to it. 

To conclude, the food was amazing, the prices reasonable ($100 per person including drinks and a tip), and we are looking for an excuse to visit again.
author: Shay E.

description:
My wife and I are fans of Frances, Octavia definitely did not disappoint.  At some restaurants, some dishes are great, some are so so...We liked everything we tried at Octavia, the food across the menu is consistently delicious and they have a nice selection of wine as well.  

The beef tongue was outstanding, and the preparation of the oysters was unique and complimentary to the flavors of the oyster.
author: Jay K.

description:
Award winning chef Melissa Perello is at it again! Octavia is an elegant restaurant that happens to be named after the street it lies on...Octavia! Haha

My girlfriend and I dined here on a Friday around 6pm. Surprising we got seats without a wait, though the restaurant was at capacity throughout our time here. 

Starters:

Chilled Squid Ink Noodles: This was cooked to perfection and had just the right amount of lemon oil added to it. 

Beef Tongue: The accompanying ingredients were roasted garlic and a marrow broth. In my opinion this was the best dish offered. I could have ordered this over and over again. 5 stars!!

Local Halibut: 4 stars. I felt as if I was having sashimi thought the avocado and chips gave it a good western feeling

White Corn Soup: 4 stars. I have a thing for anything that contains or is made from corn. This was a great soup though it was a tad bit too creamy for my liking. 

Snapper: My girlfriend ordered this and thoroughly enjoyed. She said it was cooked well and the fish melted in her mouth. 

All in a all a very good experience. Octavia is relatively new and word of mouth is getting around regarding how good it is so get a reservation if you can! If not dine here earlier during the week :)
author: Ray H.

description:
Decided to try Octavia because I used to patronize location when it was Quince. 
Fabulous!  It's the small things that make a restaurant great and memorable. Our server was fun and knowledgeable. Then the memory maker:  the bread is TDF. I even bought a fresh loaf to take home. Each course made a memory (I'm salivating right now) all the way through the dessert !  I wish I had more. 
This is a definite return when I visit SF again
author: Mun Yei C.

description: First off, I was surprised I was able to get a reservation the day before, albeit it was an early dinner on a weekday night. Food was delicious and innovative, especially the watermelon salad and the deviled eggs. The salmon was prepared so that it would literally melt in your mouth, not the usual dry salmon served at restaurants. The pasta was also made in house, loved the chewiness/ texture. Overall ambience is very laid back and cute, definitely a spot to try when in SF -- just make sure to make reservations beforehand.
author: Ron W.

description: I had the fortunate opportunity to be invited for a pre Christmas bash 12-23 with a great group of people. Ian, Nadia and David thank you for the superb invite.  The dinner was incredible. We sat at the chefs kitchen table. Several courses including great scallops, steak and so much other perfectly cooked food. I will be back again.. Frances is in my neighborhood so having feasted at both, I'm hooked. Also great wine choices by our hosts and others at the holiday bash.  Bravo.
author: M Jake M.

description:
How can I possibly write a Yelp review for a Michelin-star restaurant?  Rating it by Yelp stars seems so beneath... well, whatever standard I use to go by won't seem to work.  I mean, I gave 2 stars to i-Tea in SF for my overrated, underwhelming bubble green tea.  Compared to THAT, Octavia should get about a million stars.  It is on a completely different level... Yes, this is ridiculous and it's just Yelp... I'll move along to at least offer my two personal cents.

Octavia is a beautiful restaurant.  I loved the clean and airy space/design of the interior, the polished service, and the location.  The food was heavy on the salt, to the opinions of everyone in my party, unfortunately.  Squid ink pasta was found wanting ("not enough squid ink flavor" according to one).  Impressive sunchoke soup, however, and bread service was a huge hit in addition to the snapper entree.

You should at least check Octavia out for yourself!  Overall it was a great experience.
author: Teenie K.

description: Dinner with two friends on a Monday night, and would go again for sure.  The Mt. Lassen Red Trout main course was probably the best trout I have ever had, perfectly cooked, perfectly presented, just delicious.  Wine list is great, reasonably priced and solid selection.  I loved the open feel but rustic, not stuffy or too modern decor.  Perfect service level and kudos to the staff overall.
author: H. H.

description:
Octavia is a beautiful restaurant: open, airy, friendly, and cozy. The staff is attentive and friendly, and we loved our meal. My friend and I shared two starters, a salad and an entree and were deliciously full at the end.

Crispy artichokes - out of this world. If they'd brought me this in a bucket, I would have had it all and called it a day.
Grilled asparagus - I don't LOVE asparagus, but this dish was fantastic.
Spinach salad - again, for something that could be just so-so, it was delicious.
Ribeye with charred radishes and (more) asparagus - In small places like this, sometimes you have to lower your expectations for how the steak will turn out. No need here at Octavia - this was incredible meat, perfectly cooked and seasoned. I was blown away. 

As a young restaurant, there are two small things I noted that I'm sure they can work out:
1) Timing - the pacing of our meal seemed slower than it should have been. Maybe it was deliberate, but if so they need to find a better balance between not rushing our meal and not making us wait too long between dishes.
2) Bread service - we saw the bread basket being offered up to some tables, but never to us. We were actually fine with that, but at the end of the meal were curious why. Our waiter informed us that, like water, bread is available upon request. That made sense to us both...but unlike the water shortage, there isn't a bread shortage that everyone is aware of. Considering Octavia prints up fresh menus every day, "Bread upon request" could certainly be added at the bottom.
author: David B.

description: This place is the real deal. I can't say enough good things about the experience we had there. The food is fantastic and the service is professional and friendly. They have an extensive wine list with some excellent choices by the glass. We ordered a special 40 ounce bone-in ribeye steak and I have to say it was one of the very best steaks I have ever had in a restaurant. Their house made bread is not to be missed.
author: Lee D.

description: Everything here was very good. I got 4 different plates here - bread and butter, deviled egg, cauliflower soup, and angel food cake. I have to say the bread and butter was AMAZING. Like seriously, order this. Cheapest thing on the menu and so freaking good. The deviled egg I really did not care for. I get that they're trying to do something different, but if you want a deviled egg, this is not going to satisfy you. Cauliflower soup was very good and filling, a little salty but still delicious. Angel food cake was also amazing but I was so full from eating all the bread that I couldn't even finish it lol. I am giving this place 4 stars instead of 5 because while everything was good and they really nailed it with the textures in each dish, I wasn't as crazyyy about the flavors. Overall, great dinner and excellent service. Will go back as it seems like the menu changes frequently :)
author: Tara K.

description:
This is my new favorite restaurant.  

I love the space itself.  Warm, inviting, very Northern CA.

We had:
grilled CALAMARI - delicious
MIZUNA salad - fantastic flavors
I had the wild salmon, which I loved and my friend had the spring lamb (which I got to sample).   Really delicious combination of flavors and perfectly cooked.

The bread was out of this world - there was some kind of anise or fennel in it.  We had to pry ourselves away from it.  All of the desserts sounded amazing--I want to go back and try more.  But we had the toasted Angel food cake and pistachio profiteroles.  A slight nod to the toasted Angel food cake with rose geranium-out of this world!

Service was impeccable.  Everyone is warm and welcoming.  Highly recommend.  I can't wait to go back!
author: Maria F.

description:
loved the food and overall dining experience. will absolutely plan a return when i'm back in town!

MEAL:
- bread: a must; levain freshly baked on site; purple barley, black sesame and dark rye go into these perfect nutty slices; fairly generous portion - enjoyed some just with butter and also used some to sop up the yummy flavor (see below) but still several leftover pieces that i brownbagged for tomorrow's breakfast (5/5)
- deviled egg: not usually my item of choice but heard so much about it i had to try - wasn't converted on d. eggs as a whole but appreciate the big flavor and craft of the dish (3.5/5)
- negroni: more like a gin spritz due to the sparkling wine - delishh, perfect serving size (5/5); i think i'd easily enjoy the house cocktail just as much 
- tagliatelle: their take on carbonara; rich delicious creamy sauce surrounding delectable pasta with plenty of juicy crunchy perfect pancetta bits (5/5)
- dessert: none this go around; wanted to try the eton mess but they just switched over from summer berry to warmer autumn spice

EXTRAS:
- bench seating with pillow reinforced the cozy comfortable vibe (even without being able to enjoy any daytime glow the evening vibe is just as inviting and easy on the eyes)
- fantastic service; with the exception of one server who several times i felt tried to rush me out of there, the staff (in particular my server, kevin) was very warm and welcoming, sincerely kind (rather than forced and stiff) making suggestions, telling me more about the food, and made me feel right at home. especially for a solo dining experience in SF (an exercise not nearly as comfortable as it is in NY) this was very much appreciated
- female chef runner = YAS KWEEN!
author: Diana O.

description: Small menu but very fresh ingredients and executed very well. You really taste the high quality ingredients because they are adorned so deftly and so simply. Classy neighborhood place without the pretense!
author: Puay K.

description: I decided to try on a whim. I wasn't expecting much and was very pleasantly surprised. The service was polished and attentive without being overbearing. The food was delicious. The wait between dishes was a bit longer than I felt it should have been, but each course was worth the wait. I will definitely return. Loved the profiteroles! All in all this was the best meal I can remember having in several years.
author: Michael W.

description: Great place for a special occasion.   Had an amazing meal!  Thanks!
author: Edgar C.

description:
Day 3 I think and ... wow ... 
The food was stellar and we tried about 60% of the menu.  

The food: same same and a little different than Frances.  As with her i think the stars are the smaller dishes, soup wizardry and desserts.  Wine is fantastic.  

The vibe:  warm and cozy with the same great attention to detail as Frances.  The space is completely transformed in a good way.  Not as cramped...Loved the open kitchen.  A couple of familiar faces.  

All in all I feel fortunate to look forward to being a regular here.  Well done!!
author: Pink ..

description:
Really loved Octavia. Hidden in a part of the city that I did not expect to find this caliber of restaurant, the ambiance of the restaurant was quite welcoming. The kitchen is open and the dining area is intimate providing a quiet elegance. The selection of items was small, but all were clearly fresh and well curated for the day.

I very much enjoyed the heirloom tomato salad with pistachios and sesame seeds.  Really refreshing.  The restaurant clearly wins with a Farm-to-Table sensibility that brings flavors at peak freshness.  I did not have a reservation, and this is clearly a place where you want one. But they allowed me to take a quick table with a commitment to be out in 45 minutes and during that time I still managed to have 3 courses that I very much enjoyed.  A nice list of wines as well.

Highly recommended restaurant with a commitment to excellent service and fresh flavor.
author: Angela M.

description:
Drink 4 
Food 5+ Every dish was great! Especially desserts were amazing!
Ambience 5 Very comfy, modern and elegant.
Service 4 
Price 5
author: Tory T.

description:
The food here was so damn good that I could almost ignore the fact that it was so noisy I couldn't hear my dining companion and that they are still working out some service issues.

TL:DR review-delicious homey but classy food served in a very noisy setting with entrees in the 20's and starter in the 10's. Plan at least 30-50 a person without drinks. Plan on screaming to hear your dining companions. Plan on this place being very popular.

The food is not the most radical but that was some of the best beef tongue I've had in SF in a while outside of a Mexican restaurant.

The smaller plates were the standouts for us. The beef tongue with broccolini and a delicious broth was pure heaven with melt in your mouth tongue. The "deviled egg" was just one soft boiled egg in a spicy sauce, I would have loved something with a contrasting texture and $5 for one egg still kills me. The mushroom and green garlic soup was also incredibly good, it reminded me of soup in France where it has the right balance of being rich while still maintaining a lightness and airiness to the creamy soup. The Mushrooms a la Grecque was probably my least favorite dish although the portion was more condiment or snack size than starter or app size. It was not like what is common in France where the dish comes from or at least that name does but the French Spouse liked it well enough.

The French Spouse enjoyed their pasta with salt cod which they said they could make in two portion size. My quail was cooked well but it lacked salt and seasoning within the bird and on the skin. The morel and jus that came with it were the real stars but alas there was not enough of either.

We finished with a comped Panna Cotta which was delicious but a bit loose for my liking and a poppy seed angel food cake which I found quite fascinating with the crisp outside, not as sweet as most angel food cake and delightful with the berries and really good ice cream.

The non-alcoholic drinks are limited to bottled sodas, teas, espresso drinks and water.

Decor: What is with restauranteurs spending money on designed and then not doing anything about sound design or accessibility? That is whack and I am seeing it more and more in places that are charging over 25 a plate.  When did being cool mean being noisy and unaccessible or perhaps it's just the market they going after. There were many many tech guys in jeans (not guessing, I literally recognized people) with skinny girls in stilletos and perfectly straighten hair as well as old fashioned older WASPs. The bathrooms and door are not wheelchair accessible. The light is poor and the sound is even worse than Alta CA.

Service: There were issues, not surprising for a place that has only been open a couple of weeks. There is no front host stand so there was confusion as to whether anyone had helped the people at the front door. Our server wanted to take our order without asking if we had questions or even explaining the menu which is odd since for 99 percent of the diners it was a new restaurant. There was also long gaps between course which the tables on either side of us did not experience.  I will admit I was thrilled to look in a kitchen it not be all bearded bros. It's amazing how few woman are running kitchens in SF and it would be great if that changed considering how many excellent female chefs there are.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: My boyfriend and I came to Octavia to celebrate an anniversary.  Seeing as it was a special occasion, we ordered a bottle of wine, a bunch of appetizers, one entree and a dessert.  We loved loved loved everything we had, especially the calamari and salted caramel ice cream.  Only downside to the experience was the unamused wait staff.  Overall great food.  I'll be back.
author: Brianne J.

description:
Delicious! We took our parents here who are in town visiting and decided to check out this gem, creating quite the buzz after only two weeks. Standout dishes were the fried artichokes small plate, the ribeye, pasta with salted cod, halibut, and chocolate soufflé tart.

The small plates are quite small, but very flavorful. The fried artichokes especially were cooked amazingly well - best artichokes I've ever had. The dry aged ribeye was also extremely tasty - huge portion (we split among four of us), cooked to perfection, honestly the best steak I've had in a really long time. Everything else was also delicious, and the service was great! Everyone was very friendly and happy to offer us recommendations when we were crippled by all of the options. It also had a wonderful ambience.

Loved this place and will definitely be back!
author: Amanda L.

description:
Cute atmosphere. Great wine. Deviled egg, beet salad and bread were delicious. Now for the bad: took our entree orders with appetizer order. Apps came out reasonably quickly. About a 30 minute wait after that for entrees. Waitress said entrees were being plated and we still waited another 15 minutes. If you're backed up just say so. I ordered the filet mignon. Honestly tasted reheated. One of the more poorly cooked steaks I've had. 

I really wanted to like it here, but the entrees were a huge letdown.
author: Nicholas C.

description:
Beautifully designed place with good service. It's definitely high end without feeling stuffy. Food was good overall though some dishes were great and others were only okay. 

My top picks were the beef tongue and the butter bean garlic soup. Those were amazing. The soup in particular was mind blowing.

The salt cod pasta was interesting and the pasta was really well done but it just didn't come together well enough that I'd get it again. The quail was a nice size and light but just wasn't amazing. 

I think it's reasonably priced for the quality you're getting here.
author: Victor W.

description:
This place is very good. Most of the dishes landed solidly, and the ambiance and service are excellent. 

Deviled eggs are quite spicy and served runny which was very good. The homemade pastas were particularly excellent, especially and surprisingly the chilled squid ink pasta. Duck was very good. 

I thought the oysters, osso bucco, and desserts were fine, not great. 

Service was excellent, and wine list had some great and interesting stuff. 

Yay good restaurants!
author: Amjad S.

description:
"Don't. Don't. Don't believe the hype."
- Public Enemy

To clear up non-existent widespread confusion on the topic ... in 1988, when the iconic rap group, Public Enemy, released their single "Don't Believe the Hype," neither Chuck D nor Flavor Flav were referring to Octavia. 

This is generally believed to be true by even the most fastidious of culinary historians. Perhaps that's because at that time Ronald Reagan was still president, Flavor Flav was a solid 24+ years from embarrassing himself on reality TV & Melissa Perello was 12-years-old. 

But ... the fact that 3 generations of golden retrievers would live happy lives & die of natural causes back-to-back between the release date of that rap song & the day the James Beard winner would open her sequel to Frances, also helps verify the chronology.    

All that is to say, despite getting a semi-obnoxious amount of buzz & generally being an uppity hipster's wet dream, the menu is fresh, the food is original & Octavia is truly one of the great restaurants in San Francisco.       

If you can get a reservation. Do. Do. Do believe the hype.
author: Sam N.

description: They don't advertise the fact that this is a Michelin Star restaurant but then they don't have to as the food is excellent, everyone has already written about the chilled Squid ink noodles, Deviled eggs, Burrata, Petit Filet etc so won't repeat what others have written except agree that the food is superb. Only advice that make a reservation as the place is quite full.
author: Rajiv M.

description:
Everything I expected from the people of Frances, and more.

When you walk into Octavia, you're immediately swept up with the open space floor plan and sense of community in this simple, modern-rustic space. The place is busy yes, but the waitstaff is so calm and collected.

We started with the "deviled" egg, which isn't a deviled egg at all. It was a perfectly soft poached egg with an array of red pepper/paprika blanketing the top. We also shared the artichoke dish, which was one of my favorites. Refreshing, light and also full of different flavors/textures.

For dinner my girlfriend had the duck, and I had the scallops. Now, obviously everything was superb and cooked to perfection, but that's not what I'm going to rant about (and here comes the "and more" part). What I LOVE here is the portion size; 5 large scallops? Most popular restaurants give you 2 or 3. And so much duck that we had to take home leftovers? I was stunned and so impressed, I couldn't have left happier. The mix of flavors and textures on the plate made for a fun experience I won't forget.

Do dessert- we didn't have room but definitely do it!
author: Meredith M.

description: The food is just ok. We got 4 people and nobody feels it tastes good. It doesn't worth the time.
author: Arthur W.

description:
Came here with a friend, unfortunately it was Valentine's day so the menu was pre fixe.

I started off with the "oregon dungeness CRAB, star route little gems, charred mandarin, house yogurt"; a little too salty and there was lack of crab, and no presentation whatsoever.
My friend had the "grilled ARTICHOKE & shiitake mushroom salad"; full of flavor with a pleasant smokiness to it.

Second course: "spelt flour PAPPARDELLE with pork ragout", over salted, thought the pasta was all dente, nice texture and had a very nice and rich flavor.
Friend had the "semolina DUMPLINGS, confit sonoma duck"; this dish was good, very smooth to the palate, but I think the best part of this dish was the roasted garlic, it stole the show to this dish. It would just melt in your mouth and did not have an overpowering flavor.

Entree: I went with the lamb, disappointed. Incredibly chewy and very tough to cut with the knife. Basically gave up at this point.
My friends BLACK COD from Monterey was a good dish but nothing to write home about, though another dish that was heavy on the salt.

Dessert: "chocolate ETON MESS, amarena cherry, mint, creme fraiche, bitter chocolate sorbet", very good, the cherries were the best part.

## Service was decent, though the waitstaff only once cleaned our table after the first course, after that, nada. Though there was food crumbs/remains on the table that were visible, no one bothered to clean it.
Had to ask for a bottle of water twice, the first time they were more attentive.

## Michelin star, yet no flavor to live up to it. However with that said, I will not discard this restaurant and will try again on a normal day that does not have a pre fixe menu, just for the benefit of the doubt. Though it won't be any time soon.

Side note: Pre fixe was $90 per person.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Went back to Octavia and was as happy as can be afterwards.

- Got the deviled egg again - perfectly running egg. We were told we each needed to have one but between the 2 of us we could have definitely shared.
- Squid ink chilled noodles - the essential dish for a warm evening dinner
- saffron TONNARELLI, local dungeness crab, fennel 'bouillabaisse,' espelette aioli - the pasta and not the crab was the highlight of this dish
- sonoma DUCK BREAST, roasted cherry, balsamic, cress, wild ramp 'panzanella' - duck was just right however I didn't love the fried bread panzanella
- the chocolate souffle tart with the cocoa nib brittle was a winner again!
author: Nicole L.

description: Amazing food, detail and sensitive dishes that are simple, approachable and just so pretty to eat.
author: Simon K.

description: Good food though not Michelin star worthy. Service is not very good. We were told by our server that he could not take our appetizer order alone but only the entire order for appetizers AND entree because of the kitchen's planning. Not sure how that makes sense. Another overrated restaurant.
author: La La L.

description:
I had mixed feelings about posting a review of Octavia. The appetizers and desserts were outstanding but the entrees were uninspired (salmon, chicken, steak, vegetarian risotto). In fact, both my friend and I decided (for the first time ever) to forgo ordering entrees because they all sounded so pedestrian. 

Staff was wonderful, great ambiance, and I'd like to support neighborhood restaurants. I just wish they had at least one stand out entree and more old world wines by the glass.
author: Rachel C.

description:
YUM! One of the best dinners we've had to date in SF. 

Was attracted to Octavia courtesy of browsing their menu on Yelp.  Reasonably priced + unique appetizers plus really enticing entrees, beautiful intimate interiors -- we were sold! We decided we had to try it. 

Walked in at 5 PM on a Saturday without a reservation and were seated right away. Everything was deliciously and thoughtfully plated, portions were extremely reasonable, and we saved room for dessert, which was a very crumbly, warm and gently sweetened crumb pudding. 

Everything was nothing short of amazing. Would love to come back here :)
author: Alice W.

description:
So I decided to make this my first Michelin Star Restaurant to start off our Michelin Star Mission!!

It was my GFs birthday and booked a table for a party of 4. This happened to be 2 days prior which made me nervous. None the less the online reservations was super easy and user friendly. Was able to lock in one for 930pm.

We were able to get a table, which was right next to the window and had a cool view of the fog rolling through the street. Lighting in the place was really dim, however the heavenly light from the kitchen shined over the floor as people ate what seemed to be delicious food. Making it sort of an in-kitchen eating experience. Keep in mind they do have a table in the back for larger parties as well with a very personal experience with the chefs. 

The service was exceptional. Our server politely asked to hang up my jacket and kindly sat us at our table.

Nowwww onto the food...where to start...
We ordered everything on the menu, so I guess we will go over the highlights..

2 Deviled Egg-Super Fresh Tasting Egg with a perfect hint of fresh chili slightly refreshing kind of heat. The chili sauce & egg yolk make for a great dip with the bread

Chilled Squid Ink Noodle-Def. a first for me. Very unique flavor in its own. Worth trying. Once for me though.

Avocado Cream/Strawberry-I want this avocado cream on the daily. Bagels, Salads, Fish, shoot put it in a drink!!! Perfect blend with the strawberries and the freshness of the dish was perfectly balanced with textures.

Artichoke and Walnut-Personally my favorite dish on the menu. Even tho is was an small plate. Wow!! The flavor!!! The walnuts and artichoke create this forest, smokey, savory taste and the cheese is the crown of it all. The way this dish melted in my mouth I wanted to order a second.

-Kale Salad VS Brassica -Little over powering hints of provolone taste at the beginning and end of my bite. However it was well seasoned and perfect amount of dressing and olives. Now the Kale salad was phenomenal!! Perfectly dressed with the fennel I couldn't get enough!

White Bean/Chanterelle Mushroom Soup-Wish it was a little hotter in my opinion, however the flavor was very very good! With crispy mushrooms at the bottom to compliment this soup was an new tasting experience for everyone at the table.

Duck-Was a little to raw for my liking. Had to chew a bit to get it down. Flavor was delicious, fat was perfect flavor balance. Veggies were perfectly cooked. The carrots went great with the Duck.

Petit Filet-Wow!!! Perfection!! I usually base my experience with meat from a time I had at PorterHouse some years ago. This lived up to a prefect beef taste. Cooked to perfection the Filet was served with an even seared outside leaving the middle with pink! Veggies were all cooked well.

Curry-Now this was fresh!! To go back and forth between meats and then sneak this in for a bite or two was perfect! Mint stood out to compliment as well overall this was a perfect twist on a curry dish. 

Our experience at Octavia was exceptional. We will be back and thank the entire staff for letting us shut the place down!!
author: Brandon C.

description:
The seemingly quiet storefront belies the fact that this restaurant is a tiny bustling island in the Lower Nob Hill area. A daily changing menu means that you most likely won't see the same thing twice, though it does seem that some things stay on longer than others. Service was attentive, if slow, so grab a drink as you wait it out. And with that, the food portion of this review!

In descending order of happiness with the dishes:

Roasted Duck Breast - Great texture, medium rare was recommended by our waiter and definitely well worth the wait. 8/10

Cavolo Salad - Flavor profile reminiscent of a good Caesar, the garlic croutons were tasty without overpowering the salad. 7/10

Turnip Greens Salad - Good flavor combinations, the lady got a funky tasting chunk of Meyer lemon and passed on the rest. 7/10

"Deviled Egg" - There's a reason it's in quotation marks on the menu - it is definitely not a deviled egg; what came out was a single poached egg sprinkled with red pepper and plopped in a blob of red pepper sauce. 0/10
author: James K.

description:
Deviled egg is a must. The rest of the food was yummy, though nothing particularly memorable (this review is a few months late and I can't remember what else we had). I do remember enjoying dinner though, and recommending it to a friend who lives in the area.

Space is cute - love the natural light - and service is great.
author: Amanda L.

description:
I just finished dinner here. Resies are highly recommended but not impossible to get a table via walk-in. Hubby went to put his name down at around 8 and we were seated around 9:30. Thankfully we live nearby so we didn't leave the abode until 9:15 to walk over. 

The most memorable dishes of the night were:

Squid ink spaghetti: small dish but big on flavor. It may be a bit too much on the seafood flavor but I relished that. The surprising part is it is a cold dish, but that just made it feel refreshing. 

Cauliflower salad: salt and zest combined for a very well-balanced dish. The dates with the cauliflower balanced in texture - crunch with chewiness. It's a winner!

Shellfish bisque: very Very big on seafood flavor, but a dish i would order all the time though I did wish it was warm. The hubby didn't like it as much so definitely not a dish for everyone. But if you love sipping the juice from a crab head, a lobster when you break into its claws, or a clam, then you'll love this bisque because it tastes as though someone gathered all those juices into a bowl. 

Tagliatelle: this made it onto this list not because it was good, but because it was memorably disappointing. The pasta had the perfect texture but it just tasted overwhelmingly green - must be the nettles. 

We also had the beet burrata, and deviled egg. Both good dishes to try but the first three above are in my book.
author: Linh V.

description:
My expectations and enthusiasm were through the roof when we became the first-in-the-door dinner guests on a recent Friday night.  Melissa Perello has dazzled crowds for years at Frances but I've always thought it was too packed and too loud to really engage in the kind of artistic appreciation the food deserves.  Here, Perello has a lot more space, as do her patrons, and the results are impeccable in every way.

In lieu of entrees, my wife and I took the tasting route, fitting in five different smaller plates and a dessert for maximum menu coverage.  This plan proved to be a stroke of genius by the end, when we were stumped at the thought of trying to pick favorites.   The first two arrivals were a beautiful (ok, all the dishes were works of art) roasted cauliflower salad with Meyer Lemon and Medjool dates and toasted almonds.  The cauliflower was crisp outside and soft inside, and the date puree (along with a few whole dates) added a fun and sweet complement to the tart lemon.  Along with this salad, we received sauteed prawns on a flavorful, deep green bed of broccoli and cavolo nero.  The prawns were done just right, and the bowl (each piece here is handmade for the restaurant) was encircled with a stream of earthy, fabulous pumpkin seed pesto.  

Next came heartier, more robust courses.  The soup started with a mound of roasted kuri squash, poured over with a creamy broth of red lentils in a fragrant Madras curry and then doused with a drizzle of whipped yogurt.  This is my kind of comfort food.  This was balanced by sharp, tangy bites of spinach tossed in rapini pesto with provolone and taggiasche olives, all topped off with crunchy garlic toasts.  Finally, another deep green delight unfolded itself with the tagliatelle constructed of stinging nettles nicely finished with grana padano, lemon, and a superb flurry of toasted bread crumbs (pangrattato) that added unique taste and texture.  

Sometimes a meal is so good you have to push yourself to have dessert because you know they'll just kill it, and we were right.  We received a lovely round brown-toasted angel food cake, surrounded by chunks of pink lady apple and smooth brown butter (evoking caramel) ice cream.  All about the plate were delicate traces apple sauce that helped bring everything together decadently.

There is gorgeous, rustic, natural decor abounding here, and a full open kitchen is always a treat.   The spacious area in front of the kitchen is a great stage for watching food emerge, wine (or cocktails - the house special is a real find) being delivered, and hot bread being wrapped and carried to tables.  And every server was delightful.  I'm already recommending this experience to others.
author: Derek W.

description: Octavia was recommended by close friends and it did not disappoint!  My girlfriend and I had for appetizers: oyster, dungeness crab, and deviled egg; and for entrees:  osso buco and grilled pork sausage w/ a carafe of the Dozon cab franc.  I recommend all, especially, the pork sausage which comes with a tasty apple chutney.  I enjoyed the ambiance (modern/fancy/trendy) and had a nice view of the kitchen.  Will definitely be back!
author: Kevin N.

description:
Having dinner three to four times at Frances Restaurant in the past three years, it's fair to say I'm a fan of Chef Melissa Perello's cooking as well as her pleasant approachable attitude. I had the pleasure of meeting her during one of my Frances visits and she seems like a very nice, genuine, humble woman.  So, after hearing Octavia was opening in Pacific Heights, I was thrilled to plan a visit. 

Dinner at Octavia was the evening of July 4th. Happy 4th America and happy 4th to me getting to finally try this new local gem. Upon arriving, I noticed the light airy feel of the space. I had dined in the location before when it was Banker & Baker which had a darker feel to it lacking the nice bright light and California farm to table, chabby chic esque-style the new space has. I would guess the restaurant seats approximately 35-40 people offering a nice intimate feel (about 50% more seats than found in Frances I would estimate). We were immediately welcomed by our server and walked through the menu.  She was very pleasant and informative and I quickly saw that we were in store for a fabulous visit!

After studying the menu and taking into account what I had read thanks to Michael Bauer's review we decided we would start with the Local Halibut Crudo, sharing two entrees: The Long & Belly Pork Chop and the Saffron Tonnarelli (an appetizer portion so I'd recommend two if you plan to share as Entrée).

I have to admit as a wine enthusiast (and student since I've recently started taking classes including California and Italian specializations) I was surprised by the Wine List. We had mentioned to our server we would like a full body, fruit forward California red (take note readers that's my FAVORITE type of red wine!). This is a typical request, especially for a California Red Wine list.  We were told there were many similar options, however, they were French and not California. As local California residents eating California cuisine, we were hoping to enjoy California Wine with our lovely dinner. I took a peek after the visit and the only by the glass California wine is a Sonoma Coast Chardonnay (yum). I'm still curious about the Wine selection and why there isn't a full body fruit forward California wine? Anyone else agree with me on this?

As for the food selections, I have no such complaint. We were in heaven with delicious menu options, especially once we discovered there was house-made bread. Yes please, who says no to that. 

Thanks for checking out my post I hope you enjoy dining with The JetSetting Fashionista. Emily
author: JetSettingFashionista J.

description:
We dined at Octavia on New Year's Eve, when, like many restaurants, they served only a prix fixe menu ($90 pp) with limited choices.  I assume this is intended to make things easier for the kitchen on such a busy night, but given the high tariff, I do not believe the restaurant should be held to a different set of standards than any other night.

That's why it was so disappointing to be served a meal in which not a single one of my three courses - a seafood bisque, a gnocchi, and a beef dish with petit filet and short ribs - was delivered hot.  Each dish was lukewarm at delivery, which meant that even though I consumed each dish as rapidly as could be expected of anyone in a fine-dining restaurant, each dish was cold before I finished it.

When I consider that I can order food at home from Sprig' and have it delivered from God-knows-where and arrive piping hot, it should not to too much to expect food delivered from the other side of the room to similarly arrive hot.

I should note that my partner only complained about the lukewarm soup: his other two courses were apparently hot.  The service was fine, as would have been the dishes themselves if I had not had to consume them at a breakneck pace to try to finish them before what little heat was there disappeared. 

It left me feeling a bit like my food had been mass-prepared and scooped out of a cafeteria bin.  (And perhaps it was.). I did not complain to my server, as I didn't really want to wait while my food was taken away and microwaved; it wasn't inedible or gross, it just wasn't hot.  I'd expected more from the folks behind Frances, and for $90. Probably won't return.

I'm wavering between two and three stars.  Serving hot food seems so basic that I kind of think it should be two stars, but I'm going to be kind and give three.
author: David T.

description:
Went here for my boyfriends birthday and we both enjoyed it.

Burrata: great dish. It had friends onion, toasted pistachios, etc and it tasted different than all those burrata apps you get at other restaurants.

Squid noodles & Deviled Eggs: these are on the menu since they opened. To be honest, I was disappointed in these. It was good, not excellent. Definitely had better squid ink pasta.

Salmon: excellent. It was juicy and done just right with a soft center. Would recommend

Pork with mole sauce: the meat itself was okay. The best part of the dish was the fried pork belly/fat. 

"Rocky Road": absolutely loved this dessert. Not too sweet and airy.
author: tiffany y.

description:
Regrettably forgettable given the hype. The restaurant is contemporary earthy (i think that's the way to describe it) and oozes hipster, including standoffish, almost snobbish, service served alongside bites of alternately over- and under- seasoned food.

Sad that the best dish here is essentially a soft-boiled egg covered in cayenne pepper. Tried the squid-ink spaghetti as well, i typically dislike chilled dishes...i still do. really can't remember what else i ordered. i do remember that they own, or are related to, a winery and that the wines i tried were enjoyably crisp.

not worth a trip into sf but if you live nearby like i do, it's worth swinging by to check it off the list and tell your friends how much you disliked it ;) really too bad because i'm typically quite easy to please when it comes to overpriced fancy foods...
author: Sherman L.

description: Had 30 minutes to kill so decided to stop in here for some quick snacks. They have a unique form of deviled eggs, it's more like soft boiled with a runny yolk- worth a try. Also tasted their seafood soup and squid ink noodles. Might come back to try their other entrees.
author: S T N.

description: Octavia was a perfect way to celebrate NYE! The service was impeccable for the whole evening and the staff were so friendly and accommodating to every patron throughout the whole evening. The food was delicious and the wine pairings were perfect for their NYE pre fixe menu. Overall it was an amazing experience and I can't wait to come back and celebrate another special occasion here!
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Probably my favorite in San Fransisco. Came here with my dad on a Friday night during our spring trip and we split four things, perfect portions. Amazing food and service, i reccomend the deviled egg. The spices in the egg are delicious. Honestly everything on the menu was amazing. The service was great as well, they spaced everything out and wiped the table in between. Courteous staff aswell, very accommodating. Extra Kudos to our servers Erin and Kevin. Definitely going here next time i come to san fran!!
author: Emily M.

description:
Loved the ambience but unfortunately can't say the same for the food. The bread was by far the highlight of the night - generally not a good sign. We tried the following dishes:

Beef tartare - the boyfriend tried this and noted it was completely overpowered by garlic. Not ideal for an anniversary dinner!

Salmon - this was very disappointing. The salmon came out very undercooked and everything on the plate was luke warm.

Chicken confit - this was good, not as good as the bread, but good. Our server said it was served over a hash, however, it was more just large chunks of potato (not a traditional hash). This was tasty though - since the salmon was so bad, I asked (forced) the boyfriend to give me half of this dish.
author: Mindy G.

description:
Octavia was the venue for anniversary dinner v.3. I had expectations set at roughly 112.7 out of 10 since Yelpers have been hyping this place up since it replaced Baker and Banker a few years ago. Sad to say, the dinner experience was mundane and frankly a little underwhelming. 
 
Overall - 3.5 stars out of 5

Food (3/5) 

- Deviled Eggs. The egg itself was cooked well, trademarked by delicious runny yolk the moment you cut into it. Unfortunately, the seasoning ruined the dish for me. It was this weird tangy, salty, peppery concoction that I can only describe as a spicier version of Mexican candy. The seasoning also gave the dish a grainy texture, kind of like when you eat hardboiled eggs but pour too much salt on top.

- Squid Ink Noodles. Good, not great. Tapas sized so it only yielded about two bites per person. The noodles themselves had good texture and taste. It is served with this white cream sauce that is citrusy. This dish is served cold, which is different.

- Steak Tartare. Middle of the road for me. There's nothing that is inherently wrong with the dish, just that you can pretty much find something of equal or better quality and taste at any higher end establishment in the city.

- Beef Ribeye. This was probably the best dish out of the bunch. Cooked medium rare, the meat has melt in your mouth texture and has a nice hint of gaminess. 

Ambiance (4.5/5) - Good overall. I would describe the decor as contemporary rustic. The restaurant is split between two tops for those on Tinder date #5 and four tops for folks at dinner with friends. You can actually hear those sitting across the table without having to shout, so that's a plus.

Service (5/5) - Server was helpful choosing dishes and was attentive without being too in your face.

Value (1/5) - Dinner plus 2 glasses of wine and tip ran just south of $200. I think this is the biggest issue I have not only with Octavia, but a majority of higher end dining in SF. Had the food been transcendent, then okay whatever, I'll pay the price of admission to play. I think Octavia has good intentions, but the execution and flavor profiles of the appetizers was lacking for me.
author: Paul V.

description:
It took me a few months to get around to writing this review, but Octavia deserves the praise.

This place was amazing. The bread(it's not just any bread) was incredible, service was amazing and everything we tried on the menu was very good. Tough to get a reservation, but I'll be back.
author: Nick M.

description:
Sunday date night to check out our new neighborhood gem Octavia on 4/27. The space that once housed Quince and Baker and Banker has transformed into the lovely and rustic Octavia. The restaurant has barely been open a couple weeks but we thought it was running smoothly. No one seemed to be waiting on reservations and most of the tables were filled. The room is casually elegant yet intimate. The dishware is custom made for Octavia and complement the feel of the room. 

We ordered the squid ink pasta, hen of the wood mushrooms, grilled asparagus and beef tongue as our small plates. The beef tongue was so delicately savory and the squid ink noodles brought the perfect mix of salt, tang and heat. For entrees, we tried the quail and pacherri with cod. The quail was the meatiest and moistest quail we've every tasted and packed a lot of flavor. The pacherri had great sauce that I wish I had more of. 

For dessert the standout dish was the chocolate soufflé tart. It is like a molten chocolate cake encased in a chocolate crumb crust and presented on a bed of warm caramel and caramel ice cream. We also tried the honeycrumb pudding which had more of a rustic cake consistency but it just couldn't complete with the chocolate. Overall a solid meal. We didn't feel engorged or hungry. Just happy and excited to return when the menu has picked up new dishes.
author: NJ A.

description:
This restaurant is for the smug and pretentious. It caters to the Michael Bauer elitist, Nob Hill folk. No thanks.

My boyfriend waited out front before opening on a Sat night in hopes of getting a two-top within the hour or so (no reservation). Upon entering the restaurant, he was literally looked up and down by the waitress as well as the front of house manager. Apparently jeans and a button up is considered underdressed at the five o'clock hour? 

The manager quoted him close to four hours without any reassurance and without eye contact. Please note that more than half the restaurant was empty and it was early on a Sat evening- 5:00pm. 

I was walking over from a local community clinic that I volunteer at. When I heard the rundown of what had occurred, I was disgusted. I understand that we didn't have a reservation, but to not even attempt to be accommodating? This situation clearly depicts what is wrong with the city of San Francisco today. Where has hospitality gone? 

I'm a waitress at a popular and respected neighborhood restaurant in the city. 
 
You can offer quality without being ostentatious.
author: Monique G.

description:
Nice experience, good food.  Dinner for two was $112 without drinks, but we over-ordered.  Found street parking just down the corner.

Sourdough bread:  5 stars.  Simply amazing bread - crisp exterior with dense, moist and chewy interior.  And they salt the butter.  Perfectly done.

Squid Ink pasta: 2 stars. Very small portion, maybe 3/4 cup.  This is dish is salty and tart.  Not sure the ink taste was prominent, but might be a good thing for most people.

Little gems salad:  2 stars.  Wonderfully fresh produce/greens but dressing was underwhelming.  Not worth it unless you really need roughage or veggies for the day.

Deviled egg:  1 star.  A very expensive soft boiled egg.  It LOOKS like it would be amazing but flavor is just ok. 

Sweet Onion Soup:  4 stars.  Wow.  Not an overpowering onion flavor at all, and the hint of sweetness was nice.  Creamy soup topped with creme fraiche, so rich and calorie dense.

Crab pasta:  4 stars.  Delicious but definitely scant on the crab.  I had maybe 1 1/2 claws, and I mean just the claw part, not the entire appendage.  Enough pasta thought for an entree (with the above appetizers, of course.

Duck:  4 stars.  Well prepared duck.  Husband loved it.

Toasted angel cake dessert:  5 stars.  A perfect ending - light, minimally sweet.  Elder flower ice cream was delicious - not floral at all.  Cake was crusted with sugar on two sides so it was lightly sweet and crisp.  

ONE PROBLEM:  

Don't come early.  We came 20 minutes early for our 7:30pm time, so we were standing in the servers' aisle, plastered against the window.  On the other hand, they would have to remove more than a couple tables to make space for a waiting area in an already small dining space.
author: Gina T.

description: By now it is well known that I like to be and be seen being grown and sexy at grown and sexy places....ooooooh gurrrl....this call to action ain't for everybody.....a friend took me to Octavia for my birthday dinner a week ago....Mind you my birthday is in January but that is how long that I was willing to wait until it was a good time for both of us to go..lets just say I was in my element with that beautiful delicious ass food and service...the atmosphere does a little sumthin sumthin too. The entire menu was a feast to wandering eyes however uhm..dem damned deviled eggs .......off da chain......It's not your typical deviled egg it's more like an eloquent poached egg at its finest..when you dig down up in it ........it just oozes with that delicious ass golden yolk. Then you go in with that warm homemade wheat bread....sopping it all up....uh..uh..Uhmm....like buttah baby....get there and soon don't walk.....run....run real fast!!!!
author: Stacie J.

description:
Second time around, and most of the menu has changed.  We were seated pretty promptly with our reservation.

A few things I liked from last time were still on the menu (but I was sad they no longer had the beef tongue):
1. Deviled eggs
2. Squid ink noodles (chilled): it's a small portion, but it's perfect for 2 people to share since it can be pretty intense 

As always, I love their warm bread and salted butter.  My boyfriend actually enjoyed this more than the Animal Farm butter we had at Per se last week.

Other dishes:
1. Delicata squash: lightly breaded and fried (unexpected), but the burrata and pipian verde (almost tasted like guacamole) made the dish 
2. Little gems: if you like fuyu persimmons, it's good. I liked the sunchoke for the fall 
3. Iacopi butter bean and parmesan soup: very wonderfully cheesy. It was rich and had leaves of baby kale, and the grilled levain croutons had a great char on them. 
4. Tagliatelle: with pesto, winter geens, fennel, and meyer lemon. The lemon was a nice touch.  
5. Petite Filet: a very generous portion for $35, but I wasn't blown away by the beef. The trumpet mushrooms and toasted barley were actually the highlights for me. 
6. Gulf snapper: perfectly cooked, but the best parts of the dish were the roasted Japanese eggplant and charred early girl tomatoes, which had so much intense flavor

Desserts: 
1. Chocolate souffle tart: I got this last time, and again, I love the outer crust of the souffle and the generous portion of salted caramel ice cream 
2. Wildflower honey crumb pudding: kind of like a spiced loaf with quince and creme fraiche; our friends who got this didn't love it

At times, we felt rushed on service when they kept trying to clear our plates before we were done, and one of the servers seemed distracted and a bit annoyed when we asked for pepper, but overall, service was ok. 

I do appreciate that they change their menu a bit more than Frances, but I like that they keep some favorites on the menu.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
I was actually pretty disappointed with Octavia, given it's high ratings and chic, classy interior. The entire dining experience was made very uncomfortably by the over warm temperature - I was sweating the entire meal (very sticky, not cute, causes crankiness). 

Tip #1:  No AC or fans, plus the open kitchen in the back = very warm.  Uncomfortably warm.  Constantly-drinking-cups-of-water-to-cool-down warm.  Not a pleasant dining experience.  

Tip #2:  The deviled egg and salmon were good, but given the price I don't think it was worth it.

Overall:  My experience was definitely negatively colored by the temperature.  After such an uncomfortable dining experience, I don't plan on coming back again.
author: Sarah W.

description: This was one of the best meals we have had in a very long time. The deviled eggs (really soft boiled) were excellent and perfectly seasoned. I loved the squid ink noodles and both of the salads we ordered. My husband's duck was perfectly cooked. However, I must say the star of the show was the desserts. We had the chocolate soufflé and the bread pudding, both were suburb. We will absolutely be back soon.
author: Maggie M.

description:
Loved the rustic elegance decor; finishes of wood, steel, and red bricked wall & beautiful ceramic dinnerware. 

The food was ok, it's down to earth, small portions for appetizers, but nothing stood out. 

* Hog Island Oyster 4.5 I 5= I don't usually eat oysters but this was very very fresh and the sauce that went with it was on point!
* "Deviled Eggs" 3 I 5= Nicely cooked egg, but the seasoning was underwhelming
* Chilled Squid Ink Noodles 3 I 5= Meh
* Smoked Trout and Grilled Asparagus 4 I 5= Probably my favorite dish of the night. The trout was fresh and tasty, the asparagus was crispy and all the flavors on the dish came together nicely. 
* Pappardelle 4 I 5= The texture of the pasta was amazing, the sauce was great but a little on the sweet side for me. I recommend this over the ink noodles. 

Overall, it was a pleasant night although the food didn't really stand out. It's a good place to chat, have some drinks, share some plates, and relax.
author: Joyce C.

description: We celebrated a birthday dinner here at Octavia as a recommendation from State Bird Provisions.  It was a spectacular dining experience.  The ambiance was intimate, cozy and the service was excellent.  Each dish had unique and interesting flavors.  The Polenta with sweet corn, mushrooms and peppers was presented as Risotto and the mushrooms had the texture and flavor of a well marinated piece of steak.  The Kale Salad was delicious and the Squid Ink Noodles were prepared as Sobe.  The desserts were amazing too.  Each dish was wonderful and the flavors all flowed very nicely together.  Thank you Octavia for a great dining celebration.
author: Lan N.

description: Second time here and still love it.  We got the spicy deviled egg and pappardelle (pasta was made a bit thick but my friend liked the sauce which I think had walnuts and balsamic).  Onion soup was perhaps too subtle for me, tasted mostly cream.  The petite filet was nice and the risotto (lemon, English peas and mint) was one of my favorite dishes though slightly salty.  The dessert was surprisingly our favorite course!  Easton mess (meringue, Tahitian vanilla cream, chicory ice cream, toasted almonds, chocolate syrup) was the cleanest plate left at the end of the evening!
author: Zoe B.

description:
Arrogant.

At 5 minutes before 5 as we stood outside alongside 4 very elderly people, we could see the restaurant was in perfect shape and ready to open. The staff though was just standing around. Even though they saw the 4 people in their 80's, 1 was severely hunched over, they would not open the door or acknowledge anyone until exactly at 5. 

That's when the arrogance began. Asked why they couldn't open the door a couple of minutes earlier for the older people, a cocky bus boy who opened the door told us, they were not ready and there was a bench outside. Not a good answer. 

He proceeded to tell a couple of other waiters and the red headed unsmiling hostess about the fact that we dared to question their perfection. After we told the hostess, she was non-apologetic also. 

The arrogance was repulsive. No matter how good your food is, it does not give you permission to treat people poorly. I plead with you to not be seduced by reviews of the food and to stay away from Octavia.
author: Fred G.

description:
For a start of my birthday weekend, Octavia comes to mind as my first choice to kick off this weekend. Having seen but not tasted some of the dishes served up at Octavia makes me very curious to try out the replacement of what used to Bakers and Bankers.  

We arrived a few minutes early and let the dinner crashers in first since we already have our reservation. At first glance, I do admire the beautiful space of the restaurant and get excited to be seated. Having been one of the first few patrons of the day's dinner service, it was brave of me to even tried to ask for the table by the window but the server informed me that the table for two was currently being reserved for a party of 6, since we were there early enough and had no plan of holding up the table, I asked if the waiter would check again. I guess I was being too bold to even ask because I was immediately met by the man who works as the day's host who as soon as he walked up to me said, "That space is reserved for 2 people who've requested for that space already. So I can either seat you here or there." So now the store's changed, not only was the table reserved for the party of 6, it's now for 2 and these two wanted this table also but not here yet. 

I was stunned at the tone and arrogance of this guy who was supposed to be the front of the house host and stared at him for a few minutes; trying make a decision whether to turn around and walk out and immediately he followed with, "so, we can stand here and have a staring contest or you can choose a table?" Wow, since when does it make one deserving of being talked to like a child? Not a good sign, but I didn't feel like letting this arrogant man host ruin my night and ruin my dinner, I chose another table. Having done so, this same man still continued to run his mouth saying "...always have to wrestle someone every night about that table." "Wrestle" Your patrons are not some sort of children or wild animal you have to wrestle into a seat, really??? I thought, another bad sign.

So I ignore the arrogance and the attitude of this host, perhaps he's poorly paid, perhaps he's going through a divorce, perhaps it has been his manifesto to be disrespectful to his patrons, who knows, at this point, I just want to sit down and have a meal. 

We tried the famed and very photogenic chilled squid ink noodle and the Halibut Crudo to start and the chilled squid ink noodle was nice, lemony and refreshing, but it might be just me but I would have preferred this warm as the consistency of the noodle was a bit off being chilled and broken up instead of chewy. The Halibut Crudo was fresh, well seasoned and well complemented by the sweetness of the melon that kept me wanting more.

For our mains, we had the King Salmon and the Pork Chop. The King Salmon was cooked perfectly but the vegetable or grains were way over-salted to the point where we couldn't even finish the rest. I did inform the server of the level of overpowering saltiness when the server checked in on us and nothing, he didn't say anything. What again is the point of checking in on your patron's experience? To elicit the canned "oh everything's great?" 

As for the Pork Chop, it was not memorable. The dish was constructed of a whole large hunk of bone-in pork chop that was tender but not anything spectacular. Nopa's pork chop would still kill this one any day. 

We cleaned our palate with the Nectarine Float which was the star of this dinner experience. The unsweetened fizzy Lavender water acted as the liquid within which the fresh Nectarine and Nectarine sorbet floated in amalgamation with a scoop of perfectly creamy and tart ricotta cheese. Wow, what a refreshing and effervescent experience of a dessert! This one is a must try for sure. 

Anyway, Octavia, I may try you again in the future but really do hope I don't have to deal with the arrogant and disrespectful host who seems to really hate dealing with a patron's request for a table. It is possible he might be ignorant of how tack goes a long way when communicating a negative response to a request but I'm not here to make excuses for this kind of behavior. 

A good restaurant is represented in the way it's food is made and the level of care of this process just as much as how its staff treats the patron and this 3 star is a fair representation of the whole experience at Octavia tonight.
author: Taffany H.

description: I am at a loss for words. I really cannot believe that a Michelin Star restaurant can really mess up on the entrée. Everything was going well prior though. From the time we first enter the restaurant to the very hospitable host that made sure we were taken care of. One thing to note is that their home baked sourdough is fantastic. It's warm and soft in the middle and has a crunch to it around the crust. I know their menu changes on a seasonal basis, so it's not a surprise that some of the photos and menu items that you are seeing on Yelp do not align with the current menu. I really want to love this place and I genuinely enjoyed everything from the atmosphere to the appetizers, but do not order their steak. You will get a piece of meat that is very chewy, but very hard to shallow. I almost choked on the piece because it was impossible to break up the pieces and cut. The host was very attentive and asked how my steak was and they were able to replace it with another appetizer (corn soup). Again, order their appetizers because it will be your best bet.
author: David H.

description:
It took a while for us to get resos and the staff are great. The reviews were great and this was personally recommended to me by a foodie boss. We ordered every single appetizer and only a couple entrees as this was the tip from my boss. 

I didn't have a bad experience but everything was just mediocre. Not a single dish was impressionable. Perhaps I've been spoiled by plethora or dining options in the Bay Area, but this one was truly underwhelming.
author: Yvonne N.

description: Great restaurant with awesome and tasty food! The service was also outstanding and the bread was delicious. We chose a Spanish wine but they had a huge list of wines of Italy, California and France. I tried the pork loin and my husband tasted the beef dish. All delicious! We also tried the yummy squid ilk noddles. For dessert we decided to order the Warm chocolate souffle tart and a latte and capuchino. We loved the restaurant! We'll be back soon!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
It was hands down the worst dining experience I had at a SF restaurant. Service was lackluster at best, and most of the food was unpalatable. 

The seasonal menu looked promising with bold dish offerings such as beef tongue and squid ink noodles with botargo. Our enthusiasm waned as our wait time for the remaining meal stretched frustratingly long. The chilled tomato soup lacked the sweet flavors of tomato now in season. The pork chop was overcooked. The gnocchi dish was outright inedible. Instead of pillows of softness, think meatball-sized dough balls with bland mushroom (it lacked any mushroom flavors). 

We were also promised bread but didn't get a slice until we were finished with our first courses. The table behind us came in later and ordered later were given bread, butter, and plates a good 10 minutes prior. The server also plonked down the bread that it almost dropped out of my plate. Never once did we get an apology for poor and careless service.

It took almost 2 hours for us to get 2 first courses, a bowl of soup, and 2 entrees. We left feeling irritated and disappointed, vowing never to return. EVER.
author: Jessica K.

description: The food was on par with the Frances dishes I've tried. Great service in a very nice location. Easy parking (for SF). Loved the deviled egg, but the kale salad's dressing was a little much for this health nut (I typically put dressings on the side and decided to just once let it slide). Strong recommend!
author: Jana J.

description:
i haven't been to frances yet so i was surprised i decided to go here first

ordered:
-hog island, sweetwater OYSTER, caramelized citrus & espelette chile jam: so good wish we ordered more than 2

 -"DEVILED EGG," fresno chile relish, dolcini egg, marash pepper & spice: nice soft boiled egg with a good kick from the spice

-chilled SQUID INK NOODLES, cortez bottarga, fennel & lemon agrumato 

-calamari, GEMELLI, tomato ragoût, taggiasca olive, fennel pollen pangrattato: i liked this pasta dish more than the squid ink noodles

 -grilled PETIT FILET, matsutake broth, roasted tokyo turnip and trumpet mushroom: mm so tender

-GULF SNAPPER, celery root, caramelized endive, curry-scented pippin apple: this was good too

-Wildflower Honey CRUMB PUDDING: apple & preserved fruits, honey toffee, crème fraīche: loved it 

-Warm Chocolate Soufflé TART: cocoa nib brittle, salted caramel ice cream: loved it.. the brittle made the dish

wash it down with the house red 10

no bread served unless requested.. by the time we realized we haven't gotten any yet, we were already on to our entrees 

everything was great but it wasn't mind blowing, also service was pretty slow

i liked that they have an open kitchen and that our table was in front of it
author: Raquel T.

description:
FOOD //
1. "DEVILED EGG," Fresno Chile Relish, Marash Pepper & Spice
Solid deviled egg with great consistency. Spice and pepper was a bit heavy-handed but not so much to take away from the dish.

2. Castelfranco RADICCHIO, Roasted Persimmon, Sunchoke, Pistachio, Pecorino
This was a great appetizer salad. The persimmon, sunchoke, and pistachio worked really well together.

3. Chilled Squid Ink NOODLEs, Cortez Bottarga, Fennel, Lemon Oil
In an ironic twist, the dish I was looking forward to trying the most actually ended up being the most disappointing dish. Although the texture was fairly on point, it was extremely tasteless. I was excited because reviews ranted about the perfect mixture of salt, tang, and heat. It might have been an off day but those flavors were mysteriously absent.

4. Grilled Brandt Farms Beef RIB-EYE, Trumpet Mushrooms and Persillade
Ribeye was well cooked but nothing too amazing. The mushrooms were the highlight of the dish and I enjoyed eating them more than the ribeye itself.

5. Wildflower Honey CRUMB PUDDING quince, honey toffee, crème fraîche
The desserts were the best dishes of the night. This was my favorite dish by far.

6. Warm Chocolate Soufflé TART cocoa nib brittle, salted caramel ice cream
Second best dish. The salted caramel ice cream was awesome and perfectly complemented the tart.

SERVICE //
The restaurant is intimate and the tables are far enough apart from each other to provide enough privacy for conversation. The waitstaff moved effortlessly, from filling our water quickly to bussing the empty dishes and refreshing our plates efficiently. Our waitress was helpful in describing the dishes and providing context on the right number to order.

TL;DR //
The casual feel of the space works well for an easy dinner, but be prepared to shell out a generous portion of your wallet for smaller portions of food. If you're disappointed by dinner, focus on the dessert menu as the savior for your meal. Without any real standout items that had a wow factor, I would pencil Octavia into the "good to try once but wouldn't go out of my way to come back again" category.
author: Daniel S.

description: Cute restaurant located on the corner of Bush and Octavia. Basic menu, not too fussy but done very well. Fish, pasta, beef and pork selections for entrees and smaller plates that felt in time with the season. Our table ordered a rib eye and it was cooked perfectly. We also enjoyed the pork chop with peaches that was a good portion and nicely done, a ricotta dumpling that was freshly made and a halibut crudo (was fantastic! By far best thing we ordered ). The dessert menu had a choice for just about any type of sweet- tooth. We ordered a chocolate cake and profiterole dessert, it was good and what you'd expect. The bar menu was pretty creative, the wine list was a bit all over tho. I spyed a few known name bottles with a hefty markup.... you may want go off the grid here and try something new. My only other knock on this place, outside of the wine, was how difficult it is to park. It's located on a busy street and there are apartments nearby...we circled for some time. We were coming from out of town so could not cab/walk there. I would say tho, Id frequent the restaurant again if in the area and would definitely recommend it to others. Check it out!
author: Lisa, L.

description: Amazing dinner. We went here for a friends birthday dinner and it was just amazing. We got 4 appetizers, 1 entree and a dessert and it was perfect for 3 ladies. One thing I loved was the wine recommendation from our waiter we told her what we were looking for and the bottle we got was just fabulous! The waiters really know how to give you what you want. Also, the wait staff was perfectly attentive and not hovering asking if you need anything of filling up your water every 5 minutes. I would highly recommend Octavia to anyone!
author: Ranna K.

description:
This review is a couple of weeks old.

But all I can remember is there is only one bathroom (it's not a deal breaker but you have to wait) and I waited 20-25 minutes for entree after the small plates. It was like slitting my wrist during the wait. It was too long. 

Food was good. But The wait killed my flow tho.
author: Ken C.

description:
WOW!..So few restaurants live up to the hype but his one was such a special gem.
We had 9pm reservations and showed up early. Sadly we had no idea that they didn't have a bar to wait at. But they went out of their way to try to make us comfortable and got us some glasses of wine whilst we waited for our table. The manager (Shagy beard guy) was very gracious. The food!!...small menu but obviously very well sourced and thoughtful. Nice to see a chef that has restraint and let the ingredients speak for themselves. We were delighted to discover some things we have never tried before. Marash pepper spice, red quinoa, chamoy. Tasty and interesting discoveries. Service was terrific. Our waitress answered all of our questions without batting an eye and had some spot on wine recommendations. We were all commenting how busy this small restaurant was at 9pm on a Monday night. Obviously we weren't the only ones to discover this hidden gem. We were almost going to skip dessert because we were so stuffed but decided to share 2. So happy we did. The desserts are just as  thoughtful as the savory dishes and they are portioned to share easily. I dont know what more you can ask for for a great dinner in San Francisco. Decor, service, food all spot on. Look forward to coming back.
author: B W.

description:
Have been wanting to try this place for a while. Was a huge fan of Baker & Banker, and wanted to check out the latest incarnation of the space.

Pros:
great ambiance, beautifully designed interior
DELICIOUS bread + butter (make sure to ask for it!)
complimentary sparkling water

Cons:
service was a bit slow - was a good 30 minute wait between finishing our appetizer salad and receiving our entree. took us a good 15 minutes to flag down someone to get down the check, even though the restaurant was not full and it was close to 10pm
noise level can be a bit much as you are seated very closely to your neighbors, hard not to eavesdrop / feel like you are being eavesdropped on!

Food:
- squid ink noodles: we could have done without these. the fish and tart taste was interesting, but the fishy taste was slightly too strong. the consistency of the noodles themselves were nothing overwhelming.

- butter lettuce salad: delicious! the parmesan vinaigrette added a lot of richness and the avocado added nice layers of texture to the crispy lettuce

- crab pasta: our favorite dish of the night! the sauce was rich, flavorful, and the noodles were nice and chewy. there's also generous helpings of crab meat and we asked for extra bread to soak up the delicious pasta sauce left over

- duck leg: our second favorite dish of the night. the dish worked well on many levels, the crispy skin of the duck balanced by the smooth texture of the cherry compote. the warm panzanella salad soaked up all the delicious sauce from the duck leg. my only complaint would be that on its own, the duck leg is a little salty - however with the cherry compote - the sweet/tartness of the sauce balanced it out perfectly

- chocolate souffle tart: delicious and decadent

would definitely come back again, would probably stick to a salad + pasta + entree order to share between two people.
author: Angela D.

description:
Some of our dishes were very good and some just didn't make sense. I got the Ricotta Dumpligs and my wife got the Duck. Both were really good. The dishes we got before our main courses were strange though. 

We got the Deviled Eggs and the Squid Ink pasta. The Deviled Eggs were not deviled eggs. They wete soft boiled, which was strange, but would have been fine if they tasted good. Sadly, they were covered in what tasted like a mixer or chili powder and Old Bay. It made me cough immediately and completely ruined the great flavor of the egg. 

The Squid Ink Pasta was equally weird, as it was served cold and tastes like it was just covered in fish sauce. Again, strange and it didn't work.

On top of the couple of weird dishes that we got, we had to book a reservation pretty well in advance and it just didn't end up being worth the wait or the price. We could have ended up going to some place like Blue Plate and spent half of the money for better food. I won't be going to Octavia any time soon.
author: Brett P.

description: I love the ambiance of this restaurant. It feels so warm and cozy. My favorite things to order are the deviled egg, squid ink pasta, burrata, and gnocchi.
author: Julie N.

description:
Great ambiance! Was a little awkward coming in and not knowing who/where the hostess was - but we waited in the doorway and were seated within a couple of minutes. 

The ricotta dumpling was worth the month wait to eat here! If it's on the menu don't hesitate getting it. 

Came here for my best friend's birthday because her favorite restaurant is Frances, and thought we'd try the chef's new venture. Sad they don't have the same wine per ounce as Frances - but not a deal breaker. We ordered about 2 things from each section (including dessert) and shared it all which I highly recommend. 

The reason for minus 1 star: Didn't love the celery root soup and wasn't wowed by everything... I was also a little bothered by how much the servers were coming and wiping the table/removing the crumbs/changing the silverware.
author: Maggie F.

description:
I'm sure this place doesn't need another 5 start review but I'm going to give one anyway.  I just tried this place the other night and have to say it was everything I expected. Maybe even better. I lucked out walking in off the street, they managed to squeeze me in after minimal waiting (I will make a reservation next time). I did not explore the entrees as I only wanted something light but everything was perfect and simple. I wish now that I had ordered 1 more oyster! 
The hospitality was also excellent, not too pretentious and my server chatted me up a bit seeing I was alone.
