The only thing that was missing was my sweet partner who would have equally appreciated the food, ambience and class Octavia had to offer. I can't wait to bring him here on my next visit to SFO!
author: Helena M.

description:
Went there last Wednesday. As soon as we walked through the door the staff started touching us repeatedly - first one of the attendants and then the hostess. Not cool! It's desperate, unprofessional and culturally inappropriate.

Luckily our waitress was hands-off, but service was slow.

The food was good, but not worth coming back for.

Their napkins are really low quality. I was covered in lint afterwards. What's so hard about buying proper napkins?

There are way too many tables. If you're seated next to loud and obnoxious people, your dinner is ruined. They need to be less greedy and remove some tables.
author: Tracey W.

description:
Wow, what a pleasant surprise! This cute cozy corner restaurant has AMAZING food! From the warm bread to start with to the desert...delicious food! We ordered the deviled egg which was beautifult seasoned, crispy eggplant that was delicious and had an amazing miso butter. The pastas were to
Die for! The squid ink pasta and the torrantelli, yum, i want to go back for those!
author: Maria C.

description:
Octavia was amazing... the price point is great so order everything; you will not regret it! The service was great as well! 

Check out these ones:

Squash salad
Deviled Eggs
Pork chops
and the Souffle tart
author: Nolan M.

description:
I've been here twice now and tried a few different things.  
All on my just ok list: deviled egg, chilled squid ink noodles (hoping it'd be better!), mushroom starter, beef tongue, rib eye, 
Ricotta dumplings were better then ok.  
Their best thing on the menu is the corn soup!  

I might've tried a couple of the desserts - they were delicious but I can't remember what they were.  Great ambiance and service.
author: Meredith K.

description:
Good food. Service could be better.

Appetizers: we had the squid ink pasta, the deviled egg, and the eggplant. 

All were very rich in flavor and I was left wanting more. I don't even like eggplant, but this dish left me wanting more! For about $7 a plate, I was expecting more, and these were literally all ONE BITE worth of food. 

Entrees: I had the rib eye and is was perfection. Came with a side of peppers and kale. Flavors were amazing and it was perfectly cooked to my liking (medium rare). Good portion and it definitely left me full!

The bread was delicious (you don't even need the butter), but we only were served that midway through our entree (and we had to ask for it). Had to hunt down my waitress for more water. 

Will definitely go back for the food, but won't be holding my breath for the service.
author: Victoria B.

description:
Oh man! No disappointment from appetizers to dessert! Excellent service. 

I had to agree with other Yelpers that the beef tongue is to die for! Super tender and juicy! I loved how our server divided our corn soup into two portions, so we could each have our own bowl. 

Don't forget to try their summer berry dessert!

This will be one of my favorite restaurants in the city :)
author: Amy Y.

description: Absolutely amazing. The food was incredible.  We had the fillet, deviled egg, kale salad and a glass of wine.  The fillet melts in your mouth and the bread feels like it was just taken out of the oven.  I have lived in sf for 10 years & haven't had a steak like this in the city.  The staff is incredible and helps you pick from the menu.  The ambiance is nice, you can tell they put money into a nice remodel.
author: James R.

description: Treated like a second class citizen. Food was super salty and really not good. Steak was borderline inedible
author: Jason S.

description: I like Frances a lot and when Octavia opened up, I knew I had to try it. The menu looked delicious. I wanted to order everything but I didn't. Started off with deviled egg. It's very simple. A soft boiled egg with tons of red pepper flakes. It was really missing the creamy component. I wish it had like creme fraiche. Halibut crudo, beef tongue, and chilled squid ink noodle were all decent but all these plates are super small to where there isn't more than a bit per person if you brought a date. If you was to get a salad, avoid the little gem salad. It is just lettuce wedges. Highlight of the meal was the corn soup (must get!). Creamy and screams corn. Shared the ribeye. Sad but that meat took about +20 minutes after our last dish and one side of it was charred and well done. I asked for medium rare! Didn't complain because I couldn't wait another +20 minutes. Just sliced off all the super charred edges and moved on. If I ever come back, I would avoid the entree all together and just order appetizers and do it tapas style.
author: Kien M.

description: Delicious food and intimate atmosphere. Overall lovely dining experience and wine list. We booked reservation through Open Table, which proved to be glitchy; however the staff was cool and accommodating. Great service!!
author: Karen S.

description: Food is not exceptional. Would expect more from a Michelin star restaurant. Seems like the star might have gone to the owners head. Asked politely if we could get seated at another table and his response was rolling his eyes (restaurant was not even half full and we actually asked to be seated at a table for 2 instead of the table for 4 that he originally directed us to). Not expecting this from a high end establishment and especially when we are paying a decent amount to eat there. Will definitely not go back.
author: Veronica B.

description:
I came here on opening night, and these guys already had there stuff on point.

The decor is gorgeous, cozy, and unpretentious.

The food is creative, inspired, and versatile.

The staff is friendly and smart.

The bread is to die for :)
author: David K.

description:
Fabulous creative menu and a "wine program" that is diverse, eclectic and inclusive of both old and new world selections. Ambiance is lovely and unrecognizable from its former incarnations. We were here for a soft-opening dinner and were blown away. We started with aromatic vermouth-based drinks which were delicate and refreshing. Big fans of Frances, we weren't surprised that chef Melissa Perello has pulled off a superb selection/curation of dishes including a "deviled egg" like no other with Fresno chile and Marash pepper, mushrooms "a la Grecque" with grilled levain which were fantastic, spring vegetable salad with both dill and cilantro accents, grilled asparagus with miso and burnt shallot, and quail with roasted spring onions. There were other very tempting dishes but we will have to return soon to experience them!

As long time SF residents from a different part of town, Octavia is definitely is a great reason for us to return to Pac Heights.
author: Sandy G.

description: Octavia is Frances' younger sister. The food is just like Frances but I would have to give the ambiance to Octavia. I love that they have ginger beer. Her soup is magic as always and her starters are most delicious.  Overall it is an excellent experience. And, I am glad that it's only less than a mile from my house.
author: Peppa ..

description: Delicious food in a warm, cozy environment. Our server was super attentive and easy-going, and able to accommodate my guest's eating restrictions with ease. This place is super cute and neighborhood-y, and reminds me of the small town feeling in a big city. There isn't a long menu, but that isn't a problem. I had brussel sprouts, and soup, and both were tasty and left me satisfied without feeling full. The chocolate souffle was an amazing dessert to share, and worth every satisfying bite.
author: A. P.

description:
A thoughtfully executed experience and a delicious meal. Basically, everything a contemporary, casual restaurant should be. 

I made it here for date night after months of scheduling snafu. While awaiting the date, the restaurant even managed to snag a Michelin star so I knew there was going to be some semblance of standard to be met coming in. But boy, were they met, and then some.

First, the space is warm and inviting. Warm, soft lighting fills the open space, with rustic decor, and the hum of happy conversation fills the air. The wine list is both creative and playful in its descriptions of its wines making even less well known vintages and terroirs feel like they're just around the corner. The full bottles of tap and complimentary sparkling water are always much appreciated. Heck, I even loved the antique styled (if a little too light in the hand), cutlery.

Then there's the food. Oh my god the food. Started off with the levain bread which was warm and hearty. Then for starters we had the cauliflower with fig and almonds. I am obsessed with dishes that eat well i.e. taste amazing but also perfectly balance texture and bite on the palate. This one did just that. The deviled egg was perfectly runny with a touch of spicy flare. The tonarelli with gulf shrimp was to die for: the pasta, al dente and the shrimp fresh and cooked not a second past perfect. Then, I had the duck with olive tapenade which was again, perfectly executed. We finished off the meal with a decadent chocolate souffle tart with salted caramel ice cream, familiar yet unique in its delivery of a plethora of chocolate textures. 

This is without a doubt one of the best meals I've had all year. I left feeling extremely full and satisfied. Octavia is thoughtful in every detail (down to the scent of the hand soap), impeccably flavored and perfectly cooked. I hope to come back again soon.
author: Mark D.

description: We are wine and foodies from the East Coast. I personally made the reservation. The waitress never told us of the tasting menu,  never poured our water or wine, and was invisible throughout the meal.  Everyone around us received their meals , arrived later, and received their meals before us. The lamb was tasteless. In addition, cheese on lamb?  My son's pasta with butter was minuscule and delivered to our table at the end of the meal.  The manager never checked up in us, despite spending $400 for our party of four.  We poured our own bottle of wine.  No one refilled our water glasses.  Way too many great restaurants in San Francisco than to waste an evening at Octavia.  Shame on Michelin!  Worthy of zero stars!
author: Kevin C.

description:
Overall 3.5 Stars

4 stars - Lovely restaurant with very good wait staff

3 stars for food...here is break down

2.5 stars -  oysters - fresh but I felt the mignonette need more acid.  It really didn't taste like anything to me

2.5 stars - Squid Ink NOODLES - ok but for me not memorable

3 stars - DEVILED EGG - good egg and sauce was quite interesting but for me not especially  memorable

4 stars - BEEF TONGUE - yummm!

4 stars - Salt Cod - another yummm!

3.5 stars - RIB-EYE - delicious but it needed a touch more Horseradish to punch it up

Would definitely return to hit up the beef tongue and salt cod.  Looking forward to trying other items on menu.
author: Lev E.

description: Lots of reviews of the food so I won't say much there (squid ink noodles, deviled egg, and petit filet were ridiculous). The atmosphere is super casual (typical SF) but also very cozy without sacrificing elegance. Staff was super nice, and their "house" wines are exclusive and excellently paired, making the whole experience, well, great!
author: Nick B.

description:
Wow, I am SO happy this place has opened and is MUCH closer to where I live than Frances!  There was a great selection of vegetarian starters for the hubby and we ended up trying most of them.  We loved how the veggies were so fresh and tasty - loved the peas in the avocado dish, the mushrooms had great flavor, the house made ricotta was heavenly, and asparagus was so juicy!  I also had the beef tongue that just melted in my mouth.  I stuck with the beef theme and ordered the rib eye that was just decadent.  

They made a pasta dish with spring veggies for the hubby which he LOVED.  The ONLY complaint is that I wish they had a dedicated vegetarian entree, which would have made deciding how to order a  little easier.

The crumb pudding with rhubarb was the perfect way to end the meal.  We'll be back!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Octavia may be my new favorite place in SF.  Went for an early birthday dinner. It's a sister restaurant to Frances.  Nice light with large windows. My porkchop had a kumquat sauce which was a bit too ambitious and had a little bit much sourness to the dish. But the chop was juicy so I scraped the kumquat off. The dessert I had was luscious, the Mess.  Order it!  Parking can be tough. Note that there is only one bathroom there. So the line can get long. Also, the dinner napkins had a lot of lint. They would benefit from having dark napkins to offer.
author: Angela L.

description:
I wasn't sure what to expect, but the value of the experience was remarkable!

The staff worked as a team and offered excellent service. The atmosphere is very clean with an artisanal aesthetic.  The pork chop was the best pork chop I've ever had. Highly recommend this place.
author: Jacob A.

description:
Food sourced and prepared with loving care this restaurant was an absolute treat.
Everything we ate was delicious. The proportions were a realistic size . All courses were good  too. I fell madly in love with my four  Malfatti in an exquisite source. they were light as the lightest chinese steamed Peking duck buns. They were pale white and made with ricotta and without the usual Spinach the flavours haunted me for weeks . Sofisticated dumplings I guess you could call them - such a treat

For price and quality Octavia falls in my sweet zone 
although more high end than I usually frequent
author: Joseph M.

description:
Really fun restaurant.  I really like the space and I thought the menu is even better than at Frances.  The lentil and squash soup was excellent, I wanted to sop up every last drop.  I thought the pasta dish was good, but not amazing.  It was flavorful enough, it just didn't stand out a whole lot.  The pork chop and ribeye were delicious.  Great quality meats and cooked exactly as we ordered.  We indulged with the angel food cake for dessert, which was lovely.  

I also appreciated the service, which was really top notch and pushes my review to five stars.  We arrived on time for our reservation, but there were several parties who were taking their time to pay their checks.  I understand not being rushed, but I also find it's a growing problem in SF where parties who have completed their meals and drinks linger for 20+ minutes after the bill has been brought to the table.  Not only is it inconsiderate to the people waiting, it's rude to the restaurant's staff, who are cheated of the opportunity to have another party seated.  Anyway, that was going on the night we visited, but the staff were very kind to acknowledge our patience and give us continued updates, which is better than pretending there is not an issue, which we've experienced at other dining establishments.
author: Michelle C.

description:
All the dishes were simply prepared but tasted really good.  Several weeks has passed since I and my wife had dinner here: salad, squash, red snapper, steak, some desserts.  I still remember the plainly delicious taste at the first bite of every dish, which made me think that Octavia chef is a born chef.  

Highly recommended
author: hun y.

description:
Went here last night for our 24th wedding anniversary. The ambiance was hip if a bit minimalistic, the food was fabulous (deviled egg, duck confit, creamy risotto with peas), but the service was aloof, inattentive (to say the least) and the slowest in my memory of dining out. 

We were in the restaurant for 2 (!!!) hours, and we had one deviled egg (a 2-bite starter) plus two entrees. No appetizers, no dessert. Two hours!!! We were full (on wine, bread--and disappointment) by the time our delicious entrees arrived. Service was unfriendly. Bus boys were clueless. One delivered bread but no butter. Another, when told we couldn't open our water bottle (which had a tricky top), opened it and set it on the table. (Had he opened and poured it initially, we wouldn't have had this problem.) 

When we left, it took five minutes to retrieve my coat as, apparently, they do not track what table has which coat. So as we stood near the door, the bus boy kept retrieving coats and holding them up at the back of the restaurant, like, Is THIS the one? Kind of basic.

Were it not for the hideous service, I would rush back to try everything on the menu.
author: Purple Daffodil S.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for our 1 year anniversary, and were impressed with the attentive yet unobtrusive service and food that was to die for. 

We started with the deviled egg, a soft boiled egg with the most delicious pepper sauce and deviled spices and the squid ink noodles. Both were incredibly flavorful, and rich enough that a few bites was the perfect amount to enjoy without being overwhelming. 

Following that we shared the tomato soup, which was creamy and sweet and just perfect for a summer evening. The tomatoes were allowed to speak for themselves, something I really appreciate about well done summer soups. 

For our entrees we had the salmon on a bed of farro and purslane and the pork chop with roasted nectarines. They were both phenomenal and cooked to perfection. 

For dessert we had the lemon poppyseed angel cake with berry sorbet and the mission fig crumble. Neither were overwhelmingly sweet, and the fruit balanced the baked goods of each dessert perfectly. 

Overall it was an awesome dining experience that I look forward to repeating!
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Such a disappointment! It's a mystery to me how anyone would give this place more than a couple of stars. The food was just bad all around, every dish (tried 5 of them unfortunately) was either over or under seasoned. The bread was by far the best part of the meal
author: Jon E.

description: My husband and I decided to go out on a romantic date. This place came highly recommended by one of his friends. As soon as we walked through the door we were greeted by a not so friendly host. As we were seated our table started to wabble and the host was trying to fix it. He was having a hard time and told my husband not to touch it while he was fixing it in a very rude manner. After that we were greeted by a not so friendly server who looked like he couldn't wait to get out of there. Everything I asked him about the menu was answered in a very condescending way. For example I asked him for a champagne that was less sour than what I had before and he couldn't wait to correct me and say less dry, after which he recommended the most expensive one on the menu which was still "dry". Aside from all of this, the food was not that amazing. I started with oysters which were covered in cumin tasting dust and were not that great. The rest of the food was just ok. Whatever you do do not get the vegetarian dish! The pickled mushrooms and beans are not as smokey as the server described. The moisture of flavors was horrible and I could not get passed the first bite. The whole experience completely ruined my night.
author: Elena S.

description:
If this restaurant experience weren't such a massive, massive disappointment I might have given it three stars but given the expectations I brought to dinner at this joint it simply fails on so many fronts that I can't give it more.  Ironically, if I were to deconstruct the elements - the food, the service, the ambiance - it might deserve more but in this case the whole is less than the sum of its parts.

Let's start at the beginning: my wife and I went there in celebration of my birthday.  We'd been to Frances, the younger and much hipper sister of this restaurant and really enjoyed it so we were looking forward to a very special evening.  We were greeted in fine fashion and seated promptly (a restaurant in San Francisco that honors reservations?  maybe I should have been suspicious).  Anyway, the maitre'd took our coats, took our wine, seated us and turned us over to a very pleasant server, who was both attentive and unobtrusive - a great start.  The table next to us was occupied by a family enjoying a quiet meal - this was soon to change but more on that later.

The first course arrived promptly.  My wife liked her cauliflower salad quite a bit and I thought the flavors in the shellfish broth were outstanding - or they would have been had they been other than lukewarm, at best.  Oh, well - the shrimp beignets were outstanding. And the bread?  Out of this world!  But now the wheels start to come off the bus.

I'd say, conservatively, we had 45 minutes between finishing the first course and the arrival of the mains.  You know what happens when you have that long, with bread and wine, between courses?  Right: you lose your appetite.  By the time the mains arrived we were dying to be impressed and not caring at all.  But wait - there's more: I ordered the duck, which arrived cut into thick slabs (duck should be sliced thinly) and stone cold (duck should be warm, yanno). It was served on a bed of kale, persimmons and carrots, which was simply weird and didn't work well at all.  My wife's fish, snapper, was served on a bed of black rice and tapenade, which overpowered the fish and worked even less well.  In short the mains were just a mess of flavors, none of which were complimentary.

What about the noise, you ask?  Well, after the family left they were replaced by a table full of stereotypes who bleated away in a shrill, atonal cacophony that brought into high relief the fact that the walls, tables, floors - every surface, in fact - was hard, reflective and unforgiving.  

So, couple together terrible food service, muddled and confusing food that couldn't seem to be served at the proper temperature and a noise profile that went from soft to extreme in seconds and you have a recipe for an unpleasant evening.  A shame, really, because individually the components could have worked but thrown together and it was a disappointing disaster.  We won't go back.
author: robert l.

description: Very solid food. What they've done with the space was very updated and polished, I loved it. The house pasta with albacore was delightful, as was the Bavette steak entree, which was a healthy portion and cooked perfectly. Their house made bread is wonderful as well. All around, a pleasant experience. Hope to be back in the near future. Possibly for the chefs table.... :)
author: mel l.

description:
I'm a total fan. Everything was amazing start to finish. Food delicious. Service attentive and thoughtful but not overbearing. Our waiter found out we were celebrating an anniversary and he quickly added 2 candles to 2 of our desserts - classy touch.

Starters: chilled squid ink noodles, Cortez bottarga, fennel, lemon oil - small dish, very tasty.
Main dish: red snapper, potatoes, capers, creme fraiche, dill, green beans - cooked and seasoned to perfection
Main dish: Chicken roulade - perfectly cooked and vegetables were fresh and delicious
Dessert - Toasted almond Profiteroles, noyaux ice cream - delicious
Dessert - Summer berry Eton Mess - perfect way to celebrate in-season berries
Dessert- Wild flower honey crumb pudding - little savory, warm and my fav dessert

One note, they have bread but will only bring it upon request. Definitely get the bread, it's warm and so so good!

Hats off to the interior designers. They did a fantastic job with the space. It feels spacious and cozy while at the same time elegant. Love the huge windows which bring in all the light.

I'm definitely coming back when the menu changes!
author: Lisa K.

description:
Every small plate/appetizer we had was unbelievable. I'd happily go back and eat just those! Best asparagus dish ever, a super delicious pickled mushroom number, loved the squid ink noodles, deviled egg - all amazing. I also loved how various folks from the kitchen delivered dishes to our table with a short & sweet explanation - very approachable vibe. For mains we did the ribeye (delicious!) & a halibut (I think? Can't remember - under other circumstances, delicious, but compared to everything else that graced our table, meh).

Since we visited in the first ~3 weeks of opening, we dealt with some minor bumps (slow service, multiple waiters juggling our table, forgetting drinks/parts of our order, favoring other tables who I assume were critics). Will 100% be back in a few months when those kinks are hopefully worked out.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
I had high hopes because Tiffany, my partner for the evening, is well-ensconced in the San Francisco food scene, working at one of the city's popular eateries in the Mission. She had wanted to try Octavia so we took a 5:30 pm reservation, which was available. We were well greeted and quickly seated at at table against a side wall. The tables are a beautiful natural wood, thick and sturdy and the dish ware, at least some of which is crafted for the restaurant by an obviously gifted ceramicist, is beautiful. But despite some high points along the way, the experience went downhill from there. 

The waiter, who ran down the menu, was rather abrupt and cool, snobbish is the vernacular. He wanted us to order all at once, rather than start with the deviled egg while we reviewed and discussed the menu. So we complied. We made our selections, which we decided to share and have served family style. 

The wine list is robust, with a wide selection, but as one who lives in the provinces so to speak, in Sonoma County, the prices were very high. We gave him our order and then asked about wine, saying we were looking for something light that might match our order and that we had just come from an intensive tasting of big Italian wines (the Slow Wine event). He said something to the effect, well this (his suggestion) is French and the tone implied that meant better than Italian. The comment turned us sour on the waiter. But we took his suggestion, which proved to be good. The 2012 Domaine Jean Claude Regnaudot PINOT NOIR 'Les Clos Roussots' 1er Cru Maranges France, in 500 ML carafe for $44 was perfect for our diverse array of dishes. 

The meal started with two tiny dishes: a Deviled Egg ($3.50) with some fresno chili relish. It was cooked very well, with a wet yoke in the center, but warm still. A nice way to begin. The egg was delivered with Roasted CAULIFLOWER Salad, Meyer Lemon, Medjool Date, Toasted Almond ($7.50). It was perhaps the best dish of the evening. Nice contrasts between the roast vegetable and the date. The dressing was not too lemony, but had creaminess to it that made it long on the palette. A short wait later and we received the SHELLFISH BISQUE, Shrimp Boulettes, Espelette, Lime & Crème Fraīche ($12) and the Stinging Nettle TAGLIATELLE, Grana Padano, Meyer Lemon, Pangrattato ($14). This where the meal crashed. Both were too salty and the bisque tasted too much like crab guts. It was overpowering. Both Tiffany and I have eaten and made plenty of shellfish soups and this was simply too strong. We did not finish it despite the fact that we split one bowl. The Nettle dish was also way over salted and killed what would have been a delicious dish. It was beautiful to look at, but I could not fathom wanting more than the first moderate helping I took. I think Tiffany found it more acceptable to her taste, but agreed it was over salted. We ended the meal with the Five-Dot Ranch PETIT FILET, Toasted Farro, Cipollini Onion, Trumpet Mushroom ($35). It was actually also very good. I love farrow and it was cooked to perfection as were the onions, mushrooms and the medium-rare filet, which was cut into three narrow ovoid tubes, perhaps four or five inches long. 

So, three of five dishes were good, the wine perfect for the meal, but the snobbish head waiter and two bad dishes, given the price ($157 all in for basically one full meal) would make it hard for me to return, given the many great places in the city. Too bad, because it is a beautiful restaurant and I really like Melissa Perello's food and her other wildly popular place, Frances.
author: Michael D.

description:
Food was more of a 3.5 but service push this review to a 4. 

This is very on par with restaurants like stones throw or 1760. But I prefer those two over Octavia. I came to dinner with high hopes which quickly diminished. Everything tasted OK, but there wasn't a stand out dish amongst what we order...and we ordered a lot.

Oh well...c'est la vie!
author: Christina L.

description: Second time here and again just mediocre.  Everything is over salted.  The petit filet was bland. The onion soup was too rich and creamy. My friend's duck was tasty. The bread is the best thing they got going. My stomach feels heavy and bloated.
author: Eric C.

description: This review is based on our most recent experience with Octavia. Our group was looking forward to reviewing and tasting Octavia on Valentine's Day.  However, we were notified via text just two days before our reservation that instead of the regular menu, they were forcing everyone to pay $90 for a pre-fixe menu and $50 for wine pairing. They would not allow for anything else. Furthermore, they continued to argue justifying that it was on the fine print on Open Table's website. With all the amazing restaurant options in SF, there is not need to go here.
author: Trey R.

description:
Happy days for all of us who love Frances, but had a hard time getting in.  Chef Melissa Perello has opened a sister restaurant, Octavia, at long last.  The new place is on the site of the recently closed Baker and Banker but has been given a remodel.  The room is light and airy, tables are well-spaced, and there is an open kitchen so it is possible to see the magic as it is getting prepared.  And the new place has that most essential of all things, Chef Perello.  Simply put, she has a deft touch with food; her plates are all well-considered and come together beautifully.

I started with a small plate of chilled squid ink noodles with bottarga, lemon oil and green garlic.  I can't say how many times squid ink noodles have disappointed, generally because the taste of squid ink just wasn't there. Here, the noodles tasted of squid ink and the dish was complex and assertive with the addition of the other components.  Lovely food.

Next, a gift from the chef: morel mushrooms over toast.  Here is a quick review: Yum and thank you chef.

A salad of little gems with blue cheese, grilled red onion, ramps and buttermilk was complex although the taste of the little gems was a bit overwhelmed by everything else.  I think the onions were a bit much for the greens.

Finally, a main of halibut with bintje potatoes, ramps and green garlic fumet was perfection.  Halibut is so easy to ruin, but here the seafood was perfectly cooked but not overcooked.  The potatoes were a revelation and the broth in which the seafood was nestled brought everything together.

I would be remiss if I failed to mention that the pricing for this wonderful meal was modest.  A bargain meal in San Francisco.
author: David D.

description:
I have to say the entire experience, from the moment I stepped inside, was a complete delight. I've been a huge fan of Frances, and somehow Chef Melissa Perello has managed to surpass all expectations with Octavia.

The restaurant was full when we arrived, and yet, while "busy," the energy was far from frenetic or stressful --I would describe it as more of an upbeat, harmonious vibe, which I later attributed to the incredible way the staff just worked together; like so well, that I needed to note that. I also learned, from talking with our waiter, that Chef Perello's own style in the kitchen seems to be rather zen, which made complete sense as the atmosphere in the dining area as well as the food preparation and presentation was, to me, just flawless.

As for the food itself... I'm running out of amazing adjectives here; I was just dumbfounded. The flavors and textures were so amazingly well thought-out... and clever! 
My friend and I tried quite a few dishes. The beef tongue in marrow broth (and anyone turned off by eating tongue will thank me if they get over it just once to try this dish) was so tender you could cut into it with a spoon. The "soubise" was a frothy, creamy onion soup with maitaki mushrooms and a "pistachio pesto", and I don't think I've ever had a more delightful soup. The "deviled egg" (in quotes because it's not the conventional deviled egg) was a perfectly done, peeled, soft-boiled egg with chile relish and spices --and while I'm not much for spicy, the flavors Chef Perello chose just worked so well together.

Yet after all that, the highlight for me was my quail entrée, with morel mushrooms and spinach. I'm getting a little teary-eyed because I loved this so much! My friend ordered the halibut, and that too was extremely well-prepared.

The one downside to the evening was our own doing: we left literally no room for dessert. As it was my birthday, someone on staff decided that would not do, and we were brought out two chocolate biscuits topped with sea salt, and it was just perfection.

The decor was a simple country rustic, borrowing from what I knew from Frances, but perhaps up a notch. I absolutely loved everything about Octavia, and would go here again in a heartbeat.
author: Gregor K.

description:
Awesome all around.  For a restaurant that recently opened, they've got their stuff together.  

The top part of the menu are the small bites - for 2 people, we ordered about 4 small dishes and it was plenty and we split the ribeye which was a huge portion and was cooked so nicely.  everything was yummy and delicious.  We did the carafe of the house wine both in white and red and they were both very good for house wine.
author: Mr. C.

description: Yes and Yes!  Fantastic "Devilled Eggs," oustanding overall, and staff so friendly and not rushed to leave your table.  Mega relaxed and absolutely a recommendation.
author: Matt P.

description: This place was DE-LICIOUS. I was amazed by all the different flavors each dish had. We tried the deviled egg and the halibut for our starters and they were fantastic. Granted, we never got the bread we were promised until our mains had come....but I'll give the server passing it out a pass since I probably didn't need anymore food anyways! For our mains, we tried the salmon and the duck. Both incredible! I can be hit or miss with duck but I'm glad I read the reviews and gave it a shot because it was out of this world (and a lot of meat, too! I couldn't finish it!). The chocolate souffle for dessert was the perfect ending to the perfect meal. Go check this place out, you wont regret it!
author: Caroline R.

description: Octavia is a welcome addition to the neighborhood.  The food is reasonably priced, inventive, and healthy without compromising flavor.  We had the Oysters, Brokaw Avocado Salad, Kale Salad, Mushrooms "A La Grecque", Onion Soubise (perfection!), and the Halibut.  The level of service is impressive, and the atmosphere is relaxed and inviting.   Getting a reservation might be challenging at this point but they do save a few tables for walk-ins.
author: Rachel G.

description: The food was fantastic and very reasonably priced. The chefs really paid attention to the textural and temperature variety of the food - of particular note was the snapper. Crispy skin, cleansing lean meat, which came with a succotash. The server was fantastic. She knew the food preparation styles and the ingredients very well. I initially had thought the deviled egg was cooked sous vide but it turns out it was only soft boiled (and peeled extra carefully). Our server was also very friendly to us and the surrounding tables. Everyone seemed to have a fantastic time speaking with her. The only area of improvement would be the environment. It felt casual and had the feeling of a bazaar. I did appreciate the wooden furniture and brown tones. Sound level was on the semi-loud side for a restaurant. I am biased towards more of a fine-dining environment, because my hearing is sensitive, lower than the average person by 15-20 decibels.
author: Sean G.

description:
My friend from Southern California and I really enjoyed our very first visit at Octavia. 
When the restaurant opened, the staff greeted us with open arms and led us to our table. 
The chefs were awaiting us as well from the beautifully designed open kitchen. 
The staff recommended that we order all at once, because the chef wants our meal to be perfect. 
The food selections and pairings were astounding. 
I fully recommend this restaurant for anyone, who wants to experience a chef's presentation when you walk into the door!
author: Mitch L.

description:
We had a wonderful meal at Octavia last week, sampling dishes from every part of the menu.  While not typically a fan of eggplant, our server spoke very highly of the miso eggplant dish, and it was excellent (or was it eggcelent?).  We also had the hallibut crudo.  The eggplant was very comforting and warm, and the hallibut was incredibly refreshing.  We couldn't pick a "favorite" becuase they were both so delicious!  

We then shared the tonnarelli pasta and the corn chowder soup.  Again, both were executed wonderfully.  The tonnarelli was just the right amount of food for an "in between" course.  The soup was a lot of food!  I have a feeling I will crave it on any cold day--it was comforting and well executed.  

For the main course, we had ricotta dumplings and the ribeye.  Again, both were great, but both were larger than we anticipated!  The ribeye was probably the most disappointing part of the entire meal, but only because it was a good steak that didn't stand out among all of the other dishes.  

We ended with the chocolate tart, which our server insisted that we have.  I am glad he did!  It was really delicious.  

Overall, the entire experience was great.  The food was wonderful, the ambiance was warm, and the service was fantastic.
author: Whitney B.

description: Outstanding atmosphere, food is incredible, super amazing tender steak. Missing a full bar
author: Paulo F.

description: Went to Octavia with a friend who had been wanting to go to this restaurant for over 2 years. The food is absolute superb! We ordered  the deviled egg, squid noodle, and calamari which is perfectly proportioned so you don't feel overwhelmed or guilty if ordered too much. They were all equally delicious! Next came the squash salad and corn chowder. I have to say though, the chicken con fi is the super star of the menu. It is perfectly seasoned, well flavored, and (most importantly) moist. Dessert was also equally good. We had the angel food cake which (although the portions are small) is the perfect dish to finish off such an excellent meal. Staff were attentive and respectful which were an added bonus to such a wonderful gem.
author: Lanai L.

description: I just found my new favorite restaurant in San Francisco. From food to decor, everything is done thoughtfully, without being too fussy. We particularly liked the "deviled egg" and warm bintje potatoes, the salmon and the panade. But I suspect we would have been equally happy with pretty much anything on the menu based on the dishes I saw being placed on surrounding tables.
author: Morris R.

description: Beautiful ambiance, terrific wine list. Solid food.
author: Maggie M.

description:
Great restaurant with great food. 
Have been here a number of times and it never disappoints. They keep a number of tables for walkins and as its not in a bust part of town there isn't too long a wait.
author: Jon B.

description: The food is good, though I do think it is a little over priced.  The bread served with dinner is outstanding, I wish the sold it.
author: Andrew F.

description: Went there on a date there. Great food, and ambiance!  The waitress was darling as well! I will definitely go back :).
author: Tara J.

description: We had a mixed experience, although the best parts were very special dishes. While they push the deviled egg, we did not see much more than a soft boiled egg dipped in chili flakes. The Smoked Trout with potatoes and onions was excellent. Salads were also good and bad - the Kale salad was overdressed and came with a lot of cheese but the Papradelle was great. For mains, we did the Filet and the Duck and got the same as the other courses: the filet was a little tough but the duck was absolutely superb - almost worth a visit by itself. Lastly we did the honey crumble and it was the worst of all the dishes we tried - very dry. Service was excellent.
author: Ash R.

description:
loved the composed, heartwarming interior.  

however, 2015 christmas eve prix fixe menu was below my expectation from a reputable, award winning chef. 

happy to pay top dollar for top nosh but the bill reflected more pretension than quality in my opinion.
author: Aniqa C.

description:
My fiancé and I dIned at Octavia Monday night early enough where we could snag a reservation. We were excited to try the food, I've heard so much about the unique dishes, but unfortunately were unimpressed by a few. 

Here are the highlights:
-The duck, in my opinion was the best thing we tried, and probably the best thing on the menu. For $32 it's great bang for your buck it also includes portions of sausage. The chef cooks the duck exceptionally at medium rare. 
-The smoked trout was excellent, it's a very large portion for two people, and the balance of light and refreshing to hearty is perfect. The crème fraîche is a nice touch, I actually used the leftover cream for my bread!
-pappardelle is made of fresh pasta and quite light

Here are misses:
-To start, our appetizer the "deviled egg" was literally made up of a soft poached egg on a plate dipped in chili powder. It was pretty underwhelming and the flavor was exactly that... just Chili powder.
-kale salad is way too acidic
-crumb Apple dessert was a really terrible play on a smore, very dry.
author: Kaego R.

description: Amazing food with unique tastes that's unlike any other food in San Francisco. Highly recommended to anyone  interested. Our experience was even better since we were greeted, seated, welcomed by the manager. He even went a step further and explained the food and culture of this amazing restaurant. Can't wait to go back.
author: Ellie T.

description: The calamari was unreal. Great service and awesome unpretentious decor. (bonus points for not rushing people through their meal so you can turn the table). Would definitely recommend it if you're looking for a wonderful meal to celebrate a special occasion.
author: Marcel C.

description: Solid 3 star but I don't think it deserves a Michelin star rating.  Menu does not seem that interesting and nothing really stuck out during the evening.  In fact the duck leg was way too salty for my taste.  Service also was average.  The wait person seemed abrupt.  Overall I had higher expectations for a Michelin star restaurant.
author: Fong K.

description: We started off with the deviled egg which was nothing like other deviled eggs. The flavor was perfectly balanced. Then next I had a pasta with pesto sauce. Finally I had a steak cooked medium rare. It had so much flavor. This restaurant is always full so make reservations ahead of time. This is definitely a restaurant you don't want to miss.
author: Paul D.

description: Overall, I enjoyed my dinner here. For appetizers, we ordered the squid ink noodles and deviled eggs since they seemed to be popular. These two were actually my least favorite dishes. The egg was too spicy and the noodles had an off putting taste. We also got the cauliflower salad which I really enjoyed and the little gems, which my friend really liked. I normally dislike sourdough, but the bread here is delicious! For entrees, I would recommend the duck breast. I was really full after all the food, but I still ordered the chocolate souffle tart and it was really good!
author: Amanda R.

description:
I wish I could give this more than 3 stars...but honestly, our dinner last night was pretty lackluster. 

My favorite (and the only dish I would order again):
LITTLE GEMS, Fuyu Persimmon, Sunchoke, Toasted Walnut Soubise, Pecorino

Just okay...
Roasted CAULIFLOWER Salad, Gremolata, Medjool Date, Toasted Almond
"DEVILED EGG," Fresno Chile Relish, Marash Pepper & Spice
Warm Chocolate Soufflé TART - tasty, but a little overdone I thought

Did not like:
Yellowfin TUNA Conserva, Rapini Pesto, Potatoes & Crispy Shallots
Sonoma DUCK BREAST, Roasted Turnips, Pickled Raisin, Kale & Toasted Farro

The service wasn't anything special either. BUT - the space was beautiful, and I'm really hoping it was just an off-menu for us. I would just much rather go to Frances at this point.
author: K. D.

description: Easily one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. As a ceramic artist, I love their support to the pottery community. Every dish is served on a homemade ceramic plate. But most importantly, the food is delicious and the servers are attentive. I've been twice already and plan to become a frequent guest at Octavia in the future.
author: columbia s.

description:
Alright. I really want to love Octavia, but unfortunately the restaurant is mediocre. I wonder how it became a Michelin one star. The food is not impressive, nor is the service. The devil's egg is merely a soft boiled egg with a lot of salt and chili pepper on top. The squid ink pasta is far from tasty. I think all other squid ink pasta I had were better. The duck breast and steak are simply too salty. The highlights of our meal may be the oyster and the dessert (I had the delicious blueberry profiteroles). 

The wine list is not impressive either. With so many New American restaurants in SF, many of which are way better, Octavia should work very hard to keep up.
author: X L.

description:
My boyfriend and I had reservations, and arrived 15 minutes early. We were promptly seated and almost immediately greeted by our server. She was very helpful in answering any questions with the menu. 

We ordered the corn soup, hot potato salad, and King Salmon. The corn soup was fantastic, the hot potato salad was good, and we both enjoyed the king salmon, however mine was a little too rare and didn't come out very warm. 

The main reason for 4 stars rather 5 is because of the service. Comparing to other Michelin 1 star restaurants I've visited, a) I've had to refill my own drink, b) the plates sat at the table for a few minutes before being taken away, c) service was slower and our waitress didn't check in as frequently. 

However, Octavia was still a wonderful experience and I would consider coming here again.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Excellent and definitely worth checking out!

It didn't feel quite as intimate as I had hoped due to how packed the tables are.
author: Sean F.

description: I absolutely love this place. The food was so tasteful, beautifully presented and service very good. Great place for a date.
author: Talka L.

description: I remember having enjoyed the meal at Frances, but was not impressed by Octavia. I did not understand the hype with the deviled egg, and chilled squid ink noodles, which is #9 on Big Eat 2016. The spring greens with burrata, kale, and grilled asparagus needed something bright to balance off the green taste. Malfatti, the ricotta dumplings, were good but nothing to write home about. The petit filet, though perfectly cooked medium rare, was oversalted. Dessert sort of saved the disappointing meal. The wildflower honey crumb pudding came with apple slices, honey toffee, and crème fraîche, adding a tad of sour and sweetness to it.
author: Aldo H.

description:
I have been wanting to go to Octavia for a while, I am so happy I went!  I was only able to get reservations for 5:30, reservations are a must! Book well in advance. We were seated immediately with a reservation. 

Order your entire course together as soon as you make a decision, it took a little longer than average for the last entrée to come out.  Octavia is my favorite meal here in SF so far. Food is well-seasoned and portion size is more than enough. 

Drinks were ok.  We had the House Cocktail.  It was mellow and simple.  They only have vermouth cocktails.  I would stick with wine, which was stellar and reasonably priced.
 
Overall, amazing dinner and experience; I would definitely go back! Come hungry.
author: Steve A.

description: Great environment. Great experience. Great food. We ordered a little bit of each part of the menu-- the deviled egg, the beef tartare, the little gem lettuce, smoky corn chowder, and the channel islands yellowtail. For dessert-- the toasted angel food cake and the warm chocolate souffle tart. Exceptional food and service. I highly recommend it if you're in the area.
author: Andy G.

description: Good food, good ambiance, interesting location. We had a nice meal, but nothing was so amazing that we would come back. Great service.
author: christine c.

description: Had an exceptional meal. Very similarly to Frances, which is a plus. Fantastic but a bit pricey wine list. Somewhat unusual in San Francisco, also excellent desserts.
author: Thomas C.

description: This place was phenomenal! I took my best friend here for her birthday after hearing such good things. We had the chilled ink noodles and they did not disappoint. But our server was really good about letting us know that the top portion of the menu is basically like a tasting menu and the portion size is a few bites per person. We also got the fresh greens and burrata salad that was just so good. The dressing was a great balance with the cheese and mixed greens and the shaved asparagus was a nice touch. The sweet onion soup was by far my favorite! The flavors in that tiny little bowl of soup were so unbelievable. And it was the perfect amount of creaminess. We also got the halibut main course to split and the fish pretty much cut like butter. Highly recommend this place. It is a must try!
author: Carly G.

description: I loved Octavia. I found the food creative but not overblown which can be the case in the SF food scene. The appetizers were wonderful. We had the  oysters and deviled eggs, followed by the asparagus and potato salad, which was amazing. We followed with the spring greens, and for our mains the salmon and the duck. Every dish was spot on. The menu worked really well together which you wouldn't necessarily think at a glance. The atmosphere is comfortable, sophisticated yet casual. The service was great, perfect really. Octavia is my new favorite place to enjoy a really really good meal. I can't wait to go back!
author: Jafer P.

description:
Been here twice and both times was left moderately unsatisfied. The restaurant focuses too much on presentation over the actual food. The scallops looked beautiful and were very fresh, but the sear wasn't done well. It's good if you've never had squid ink before for the "thrill" effect, but the execution is so-so. 

The deviled eggs are definitely worth ordering.
author: Kong S.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for our 2 year anniversary in July and it was wonderful! I hear that getting reservations is really difficult nowadays and I actually wasn't able to get one either when I went in July, but they DO take a limited number of walk ins. We showed up on a Tuesday evening ~30 min after they opened and were seated in about 3 minutes. The food was incredible!
Free bread- yummy and fresh!
Corn soup- tasted like butter + corn turned into a delicious soup. Basically it was heaven in a bowl. Went really well with the bread.
Romano beans- a little disappointed with the small portion but it was oh so good! And it was topped with tasty little fried onion bits and we devoured the dish.
King salmon- this portion was HUGE! I was pleasantly surprised by the size of that fish haha. I couldn't eat it all (which is surprising, given how much I eat) and had to take some home for later. Flavors were great. I don't usually care for capers but the sauce was excellent.
Tortellini- my boyfriend ordered this one. It was pretty good but not exactly anything to write home about. I think he was kind of jealous of my fish.
Cocktails- I can't remember what we ordered but he got one of their whiskey ones and I don't remember mine... I think it was a little too strong so I wasn't a huge fan but it was still worth a try. Their drink *book* is nuts. Sooo many options!

I want to try eating here again before this place becomes the next Chez Panisse and I can't get in ever!
author: Dana B.

description: Absolutely divine!  From the cocktails to the apps to entrees this place was incredible.
author: Richa T.

description:
Great food.  We started with some salads, had the risotto and rib-eye and finished with the chocolate souffle.  All excellent, no complaints.  However, I was disappointed that the menu appears to be exactly the same as Frances.  I'd like to see some differentiation, then we'd have an excuse to visit both more often.

The seating is too cramped.  This causes it to be too noisy and you're in the middle of other peoples' conversations.  Even worse, we were stuck between two other two tops and the servers had a hard time waiting on us.  The service was also a bit slow (maybe due to the cramped issue), even getting some bread took forever.

Rearrange the tables or delete a few seats and be more original with the menu and you'll move up to 5 star status.  As it is now, we both agreed that we'd rather eat at Frances even though we live much closer to Octavia.
author: Holger B.

description: Good stuff! Food is very flavorful. Amazing collection of vermouths!
author: Ankan S.

description: Octavia is true San Francisco dinning, that reminds me why I love SF. The food appears colorful and easy, yet the taste of each dish has it's own story. The place feels both private and public. The sevice sets a standard at the highest level for any returant in SF. Again the service mirrors the food by being both familar and "togeather". Team work was happening from the moment I walked in till I left with a happy tummy.
author: Paul M.

description: Delicious. Quaint corner with limited seating. Pricey but a worthy spend if you are up for it. Amazing desserts. Great wine selection.
author: Luca T.

description: Have come in here a couple of times by myself or with husband for a quick snack and glass before our 6pm apt across the street. Nice menu and by the glass options. Some aps more hits than others. Came in today to an almost empty restaurant and without a look of recognition or even a hint of a smile to matre'd tells me he is fully booked and had only a few tables reserved for walk ins. Ummm that's what I am... I told him I've come in here before and that I was planning on a quick bite and would be on my way in about twenty. He tells me he's sorry. Flat faced. So in my opinion a feeding establishment should be accommodating within reason, inviting and friendly in addition to good food. If you fail the first three the last is pretty much moot.
author: Kriszti D.

description: This was the best meal I've had in quite a while!  We got oysters and the deviled egg to start.  both were fantastic, the deviled egg had a nice spicy kick!  Next we got the trout and the kale salad.  The trout and cream cheese was so rich and creamy, when eaten with the potatoes it was absolutely perfect.  The kale salad had one of the best dressings I've ever had.  For our main dishes, we got the duck and the ricotta dumplings.  I'd been wanting the ricotta dumplings ever since seeing them on the menu and they were everything I'd hoped for.  They were simple, yet delicious.  The duck was perfectly done and wonderfully tender.  Overall, everything we had tasted amazing.  Every item seemed like something that I would get if I went to dinner at the chef's house.  They were not in your face or trying to impress you, just amazing dishes cooked to perfection.  Thank you so much Octavia!
author: Austin R.

description: There was 4 of us for dinner.  We were greatly anticipating our dinner amid all the "hype" of the restaurant.  The atmosphere is comfy, beautiful stoneware dishes and good service.  We ordered their" handmade bread"@ $8 per serving along with other appetizers to start with.  We received 3 slices of bread and a small heel.  When I asked the waiter if we could have another slice of bread for there were 4 of us, he informed us we would have to place another order to receive the additional bread . Thus was the beginning of the end of our visit there. The food was well sourced, cooked well but for these prices $$$ incredibly BLAND AND BORING.  We had the pork chop, halibut steamed well but just sat in a pool of hoisin sauce.  I did not find the food different or interesting , rather it is much like most of these new restaurants .  They're all the same.  Overdone, overpriced and over hyped.just because you're spending bucks doesn't translate to over the top food. Screw the top 100. Eating out should not be a pretentious event.  I'm saving my $$$ for those restaurants that knock my socks off and sticking with the tried and true authentic restaurants that provide good food, good service, welcoming atmosphere.  That is why these restaurants, have returning customers.
author: Stephanie M.

description: Officially my new "last meal on earth": beef tongue from Octavia.
author: Tori S.

description: I've been a fan of Frances so I decided to finally try Octavia and the experience was disappointing.  All the staff seemed too busy to pay attention to their patrons and were rather unfriendly.  My husband and I use to dine at Baker & Banker frequently before they closed.  What had set Baker & Banker aside from other restaurants was that the owners would always make an effort to stop by and greet every table. The atmosphere always felt warm  versus Octavia seemed cold and pretentious.  Our server never once checked in to ask how we liked the dishes.  No one offered to take our coats when we sat down and no one said bye or thanked us for dining there even though we left a nice tip despite the poor service and mediocre food quality.  One would consider coming back to give it another chance but why bother when there are plenty of actual good restaurants in the city that do live up to their reputation.
author: Lisa W.

description:
i came here for dinner last night w/ my friend and it was great.  i had been to the same space for both quince and baker and banker, and it is now unrecognizable!  the restaurants before were darker and fancier, and it is now super light and airy w/ an open kitchen.  love the new space!

for food, we tried a bunch of stuff.  we couldn't decide, so we had our server help us out.  we ended up w/ the chilled squid ink noodles, marinated mushrooms w/ grilled bread, hamachi crudo, corn soup, and the ricotta dumplings.  i am usually not into ricotta dumplings, but we saw our neighbor eating it, and it looked great, so we got it.  omg, it was so delicious!  it was definitely on the heavier side, so sharing the dish w/ my friend was perfect.

for dessert, we got the summer berry eton mess, which was the perfect way to end the evening.  can't wait to go back!
author: Helen T.

description: The devil egg was really tasty but the rest of the dishes were not all that memorable, and couple things were kinda salty. It was not up to my expectation.
author: Shannon J.

description:
The best dinner we have had in San Francisco.  The food was excellent, and the service attentive but not fawning.  We were seated promptly with our reservation at 8:30.  The noise level was high, but improved as the evening went on and some tables were cleared. 

Highly recommend the duck breast, the kale salad, squid ink noodles, and the chocolate soufflé.  It wasn't really a soufflé, but really delicious.

We brought our own wine, had been a gift for a special occasion, and the waiter did a nice job of opening and pouring it for us.

Overall, a very special dining experience.
author: Linda W.

description: Elegant, refined, warm. Terrific wine list. Outstanding service from Dylan. An awesome restaurant in a space that has a legacy of awesome restaurants. Well done.
author: Mango P.

description: Really enjoyed the experience! Reviews are so up and down so we were really hopeful. Had 5 plates: squid ink pasta; skate wing; collard greens; butterbean soup; and pasta dish. All smaller plates - no entrees. Other than skate it was all vegetarian but didn't even notice the lack of protein. It was very delicious! The skate and collard greens were well done California style but had strong southern notes. Service isn't 100% as the entire restaurant was filled, so you can't expect non-stop attention. Melissa was working pass on Sunday! Good stuff! Would go again in a different season once hype settles. $100 for 2 - including 2 drinks
author: PK R.

description: I've dined here twice and have loved every bite of the multiple dishes I've shared with my table. The hot bread is a wonderful touch and difficult to say no to on the third round.
author: Vicki L.

description:
I'd give 5 stars for the food and service but am deducting a star for the crazy uncomfortable chairs and the bathroom situation.

Food & Service:

The food was absolutely delicious and I appreciated the innovative farm to table approach. It's just as good as Frances, which I also love, and the portions are huge. The chilled tomato soup with garlicky croutons and burrata was so refreshing and tasted of summer, yet it was hearty enough to feel like a substantial appetizer. I loved how the server poured the soup over the croutons so that they retained some crispiness and texture. I also tried the tonarelli (pasta) appetizer which was cooked perfectly al dente and also featured tomatoes and saffron - amazing. Everyone at our table loved their entrees as well - the grits with corn, ricotta and trumpet mushrooms were so decadent and cheesy and delicious and the blistered padron peppers cut the creaminess with some spice. Salmon was cooked to perfection as well. For dessert we shared the nectarine and angel food cake (heaven) and the chocolate tart w/salted caramel ice cream which disappeared almost as soon as it hit the table (yum). We were so stuffed! 

Our waiter was incredibly attentive and well versed on all of the dishes on the menu and steered us in the right direction when we had questions about which dishes to go with. It was the perfect balance of attentiveness but also leaving us alone enough to chat without constant interruption. The meal was paced in a relaxed way so that we didn't feel rushed and I really appreciated the fact that we could linger and talk, which is what fine dining is all about. It's a pet peeve of mine when restaurants try to turn tables too quickly and Octavia did a great job making us feel taken care of. The bread was great, I do wish it had been offered before we ordered our appetizers rather than during/after we finished them, but other than that everything from food/service perspective was pretty perfect.

Other: 
I don't think I've ever complained about a restaurant chair before but the chairs here are crazy uncomfortable. They are so shallow they might as well have been designed for a child. Even the person who was 5'2" in our group felt like the chair was ending in a really uncomfortable position, so I can't imagine how a guy who is over 6 feet would feel in these. It appeared that the back row of tables had better chairs (wicker ones that looked deeper) but the black ones in the front of the house were ridiculous. I perched on my seat like I was falling forward the entire night and no one in our group could put their feet flat on the ground as it was too uncomfortable on the legs.

Also, there is only 1 bathroom stall for restaurant patrons and staff to share. Ugh. It is also placed right by the kitchen in a teeny tiny corner so you have to stand in the way of the servers in an awkward line while you wait and there was always a line because 1 bathroom is simply not enough for 50 people. This is not something I associate with fine dining and does not echo the level of service or quality of food - which were both outstanding - at the restaurant.
author: Britt M.

description:
Tonight, we ventured to Octavia for my husband's birthday dinner. The food was good but probably not to die for. We enjoyed the deviled egg, the pasta, and the profiteroles. The bread was also fresh and served warm. The pricing is ok except that dishes were pretty small. My hubby tends to eat less than most dudes so portion was alright. We had great service. Very accommodating. My hubby is a light drinker and asked if he could do half glass of two types of wines. He had a little wine pairing of his own! The food came around promptly and the waiters and waitresses replaced settings like 4-5 times. 

I think it would be fun to come to Octavia with a very small group of friends 3-5 and then try all their dishes. The menu is small and I feel like it is meant to be tapas or shared. Will need to come back with my gal pals for a girls night!
author: Antoinette L.

description: Top spots in SF. Pasta here reigned supreme for me. Red wine menu is robust and really a delight.
author: Sloane T.

description: Delicious food, I wish we could have ordered everything. Love the house red wine! Favorites: oyster, roasted cauliflower, linguine with chanterelles, and duck breast. Great service as well. Overall, the true highlights of each dish are revealed in the seasoning and sauces. Even better than Frances- you must go!
author: Rachel K.

description: Simple but elegant design for both the food and the decor. The ricotta dumplings were light but flavorful, the deviled eggs were not traditional deviled eggs and runny which I liked, the saffron tonnarelli was well seasoned, and the salmon was good though not as unique as the other two dishes.
author: Xtina W.

description:
Very nice dinner.  The deviled egg, squid noodles, and saffron pasta were all very nice.  The seed bread they served was excellent and wonderfully moist inside.  The entrees (salmon and rib eye, respectively) were good, but perhaps continue two somewhat unfortunate dinning trends.  Often, kitchens seem a little more conservative on the main than the smaller dishes, and that was the case here.  Secondly, my wife's rib eye was at least twice the size of my salmon, which is another typical and unfortunate restaurant trend.  Who are the people who think that 4 or perhaps 6 ounces of salmon is a portion?  Clearly, the same people don't expect 4 ounce portions of steak!  This is nothing unique to Octavia, but I was particularly struck at the persistence of this trend in the dinning scene.  

Sorry for the digression, but dessert was also very good, we found a nice red wine, and the house vermouth cocktail was surprisingly good given that it was only vermouth and Octavia lacks any liquor.

So, absolutely a very good place and one that I would return to, and probably priced about right considering food and atmosphere.
author: Richard P.

description: Everything was perfect!  Loved the food and wine!  Great atmosphere, had an awesome time.
author: Vincent C.

description:
Excellent - the restaurant was a little warm for us on a Saturday night, reservation at 9:30. Ordered several small starters as well as a pasta and a dry aged ribeye. Wine program had a number of affordable selections and prices by the glass were reasonable as well. Server allowed us a taste of a wine which was good, but we preferred something else, and that wasn't a problem.

After I ordered, the table next to us was delivered their ribeye and they raved about it for 20 minutes. Once our ribeye arrived, we found it exceptional as well. We asked, and were told it was dry aged for 50 days. Delicious. 

Desserts were solid and excellent coffee service. A little too much time between courses but that was probably some of our impatience to receive the next course.

Will return often.
author: Eric L.

description: Having recently returned from Paris and a couple meals at one of our favorites there - Septime- we were taken back there a little at Octavia w/ it's warm rustic atmosphere and bright, fresh, deep, and layered dishes.  Courteous, pleasant, knowledgable, and professional service.  Egg right on and a must.  In house bread artisinal. Radicchio/beet salad w/ citrus exceptional.  Roasted squash and chicory salad complex w/ persimmons and a celery root puree at base.  Cauliflower soup w/ date bead croutons-yum. Carbonara w/ porcinis - yum again.  Pork loin w/ brussels and apple sauce - comfort food extraordinaire.  Nice wine list rich in French and Itals.  Buckwheat bread pudding a savory delight.
author: Tim G.

description: great spot for date .. low lit , nice atmosphere .. and great food !! stand out dish was the squid ink noodles with some kind of citrus sauce on them ... service was a little slow , but they were really busy
author: Micah W.

description: I used to think Frances was the best restaurant in SF...but Octavia takes top honors for me.  Had the chilled squid ink noodles (which I never would have ordered, but someone at the table insisted) and the asparagus salad appetizers and was blown away by both.  How do they get so much flavor into apparently simple dishes?  Also, the beef filet (on a bed of farro and slivers of cabbage and broccoli) was perfectly cooked, and a surprisingly ample serving.  (Not that the food needed it, but this restaurant is considerate enough of its diners to provide a small bowl of salt...an increasingly rare touch.)  The bread is extraordinary, as is the salted butter.  I'm not a dessert person, and thought the desserts were ok (but that's me). Can't wait to go back.
author: Keith J.

description: Service is weird and awkward, food is ok. All three of us ordered a glass of sparkling wine and the waitress gave my friend a tasting. When said she didn't need a tasting of a glass of sparkling wine the waitress insisted that we all have a taste before she would pour the glass. Strange. Atmosphere feels more like a diner and most of the waitstaff seemed panicked and inexperienced. (Save for the bus boys/girls who seemed better than our waitress.) I'd give Octavia a big Meh.
author: Meeeeeee M.

description: We had such high expectations for Octavia, it came highly recommended by friends and we booked it on a special night in the city. We were in town to see the Nutcracker and booked an early reservation so that we would have time to enjoy dinner. We told our waiter that we had a show to catch and he assured us that we had plenty of time. We ordered wine and appetizers quickly followed by our main courses. The wine came out immediately and that's where is started to go downhill. We waited a good 20+ minutes for our appetizers, all while tables around us seemed to get their orders on time. We told our waiter we were concerned about timing for our main course, but he again assured us we would be fine. 20+ minutes later we had to go and told the manager that we had to go. Long story short, our meal arrived as we were leaving, there were no apologies or acknowledgement. Octavia is very charming and appears to have great food, but we were extremely disappointed in what we hoped would be a very special meal.
author: Natasha S.

description: My husband and I recently dined here and I really liked the overall feel of the interior. It was bustling with diners, the host was really friendly, and after being advised on my food sensitivities, the waiter was helpful. The food that came out was simple yet thoughtfully prepared. The quality of the produce alone provided amazing flavor - for example the tomatoes and mushrooms may have been the best I have ever tasted. Portions of the mains are generous. We really enjoyed our date night here and would recommend to friends for a lovely neighbor dinner.
author: Sarah H.

description: Had a reservation for 7pm Saturday night we arrived a little early and were seated within minutes . What a great ambience and decor just love the look ! Ok now to the food - we basically got 3 of the small plates which are about two or 3 bites if you share with someone else we got the black ink pasta , asparagus and artichoke to start wow what bursts of flavor and god that's delicious and of course with the divine Josey baker bread you can't go wrong. Then we chose a vegetable entree and the tasty salt cod pasta both delicious and just the right amount of seasoning. For dessert we had the warm chocolate something with salted caramel ice cream and strawberries with panna cotta - heavenly !! Drinks seem a little pricey but overall a  great experience, excellent food and definitely a new restaurant favorite for me ! Ps price was reasonable too
author: lyn m.

description: It was definitely a five star dinner for me!! Starting from the bread, which was amazing !!! My friends and I Shared the chilled squid ink noodles, it was a great way to start our meal, followed by the beef tongue in a bone marrow broth which just melted in our mouths, we also tried the corn soup, simple and delicious, you could really taste the sweetness of the corn,  from the entree section we had the rib eye, perfectly cooked, perfectly seasoned just the way a steak should be. And to finish we had the nectarine  float  which was definitely one of the best floats I've had! The lavender added an amazing touch! And the wildflower honey crumb pudding, perfect way to end a delicious dinner. Service was very attentive and on top of every detail.
author: Mario T.

description:
We happened upon Octavia and were delighted with our experience. The ambience, the wine and especially the cuisine.  We had a bunch of small plates, oysters, the squid ink pasta, paccheri and cod, beef tongue, soubise and mushrooms, and for dessert the stand outs were the panna cotta and the chocolate soufflé and ice-cream.  The lovely people next to us had the halibut and squab and they were very enthusiastic in their appraisal.  The chef, in a word, is excellent.

The service was exceptional - our waiter, rodolfo, was wonderful as were all the rest of the staff.
author: joanne r.

description: A fantastic dining experience in line with the high expectations that San Francisco foodies have. We went there for our anniversary dinner. Great decor, blending SF charm and modern chic. A really good wine selection that will satisfy the most sophisticated of taste. The menu and food was creative and diverse. All of our appetizers were perfectly constructed, with complex flavors and textures.  The entrees were equally as good and of special note the pork was perhaps the most amazing I've ever had (this coming from a pork connoisseur). Of special note I'd like to personally thank Gina, she really made our dining experience extraordinary. From making us feeling very welcome, to her professionalism and suggestions on food. She rocks! Good job Octavia, for delivering at the highest standards.
author: C F.

description: Octavia was one of the most incredible dining experience my family and I have ever had! The food was fresh, innovative, and delicious, the decor was stunning, and the service was impeccable. We visited San Francisco on vacation, and this was one of the highlights of our trip. If it was possible, I would live in Octavia. The restaurant is really special but also comfortable - makes me wish I lived in town so I could go again. Go to Octavia!
author: Anna C.

description: Appetizers were good but entrees very average (we had the beef and the mushroom Panade - with basically 90% of bread with cheese and cream). Disappointment. The wine list is good.
author: Laurence F.

description: Wow! Walked in for a lovely surprise! The food is fresh, innovative and absolutely delicious. The atmosphere is comfortable, the service - fantastic and from start to finish the food is delightful.  From presentation to execution it's clear that everyone at this establishment takes great pride in creating a superb experience.
author: Anna P.

description:
For a Michelin-rated restaurant at this price point, Octavia was very disappointing.  Here's a quick summary:

- The roasted cauliflower salad was delicious and things were off to a great start
- The turnip greens salad was interesting.  It's not something we would order again but I could see it being an acquired taste.
- The gulf snapper was very good; however, as a $30+ entree I was expecting something more memorable.  The filet was relatively small, and it's not a dish I would go back for, especially not at this price. 
- The duck breast is where things took a turn for the worst.  Our server told us the chef recommended medium rare.  The meat was so chewy, it was almost inedible.  My guest barely touched it, and I swallowed a piece after chewing for 2 minutes.  We asked for a to-go bag (more on this below).  Our waiter should have asked if everything was ok, but he didn't.
- For dessert, we ordered their "specialty,"  the warm Chocolate Soufflé TART.  I'm sure it's good when it isn't burnt-- it was so dry and hard it was difficult to cut with a fork.  We told our server and he removed it from our bill.  He seemed surprised. 
- After we paid, we were not given our to-go bag with duck and had to seek out someone near the kitchen to find it for us.  The next night, I cooked the duck on a cast-iron skillet and it was much better and actually chewable.

Overall, a very disappointing experience.  A restaurant like this needs to be amazing every night.  They shouldn't make mistakes like serving a burnt dessert.  And whoever is recommending the duck at medium rare must have really sharp teeth.
author: Andrew E.

description: We've been waiting to try Octavia for a while, and we were disappointed overall. We had a rough start there: The hostess had us stand in a corner of the room for 20 minutes because tables kept being given away to couples that came 10-15 minutes later for their reservations, while we were on time. We were pretty frustrated by the time we sat down. We ordered the porcini panade and chicken confit as entrees and were not disappointed: great flavors, beautiful presentation. We were, however, underwhelmed with the deviled egg (what's all the hype??), the safron fettucini, and the beef tartare. We were excited to try a non-traditional dessert - the honey crumb cake - but were ultimately unsatisfied, because the mildly-sweetened cake was lost in the sea of cream. I must mentioned that having the open kitchen was a bonus - it was a joy to watch the kitchen staff work and they truly are masters. However, if we need to take out-of-towners for a stellar meal, Octavia will not be our first choice.
author: Convict T.

description: They have great foot, great service, great everything. It was one of my best meals. It did have a price to it but it was definitely worth it.
author: Ana R.

description: Well the not-so-service person really summed up Octavia for us this eve when he greeted expectant patrons with a scolding finger and bellowing:"No, No, and NO!" Apparently when the restaurant claims to "reserve tables for walk-ins", they mean that they have 2 - and you should be lucky to get one after standing in line and waiting when the doors open at 5PM apparently. NO thank you.
author: CM B.

description: Excellent food. Favorites: halibut crudo and tomato soup. Deviled egg is spicy and rich. Bread baker is a phenom! Rib eye is large enough to share.
author: nathalie n.

description:
