i love frances.

naturally, i was excited to try octavia and we lucked out on a table for two right when they opened at 5pm on a friday.

started with 3 oysters in fennel mignonette. very plump and fresh. great way to start the meal.

second, the grilled asparagus. thick stalks of asparagus in warm miso brown butter with shallots and herbs. the asparagus still had some crunch to it, which i love. so delicious.

the "deviled egg." a soft-boiled egg dredged in a few types of chilies. definitely spicy. would be good with a piece of levain, maybe, to soak up the runny yolk.

beef tongue. wow. i was expecting this one to be tough, but it couldn't have been more tender. (maybe beef tongue is always tender? what do i know.) flaked off at the slightest prod from my fork. the marrow broth and charred broccoli were perfect together.

we wanted to end our meal on a lighter note, so we finished with the pot of mushrooms with levain and the romaine hearts. both were fantastic.

i'll definitely be back.
author: Shawn C.

description: while i loved Baker & Banker (it's last occupancy) for it's brunch and bakery, i'm loving Octavia even more! i went when it was still relatively new and if there's anything i vividly remember it's the squid ink pasta. there was a slight tartness to it paired with a creamy sauce dressed over perfectly cooked fresh pasta. it was so good that we ordered a second one. a lot of the other food was really good too but if i could've ordered a heaping bowl of the pasta as my meal, i would have. the space is dim and warm.
author: Regina C.

description:
Just go, it's worth it.

Highlights:
Pork Chop
Dumplings
Devil Egg
Bread
author: Andrew K.

description: Long wait to get a reservation, no problem. Long wait to get service, no problem. Food tasting mediocre at best with a price tag of $120/person? Unacceptable. Not a value eater folks, will gladly pay that and more - but if a place is serving meat that is bland and dishes that sound artsy on paper but don't taste that good, it is what it is. You can find better.
author: Leo S.

description: All around excellent! Warm unpretentious decor, wonderful food and perfect service. I had the "spring menu": spring vegetable sale with burrata and pea and lemon risotto. Absolutely delicious! The risotto was out of this world, perfectly prepared with a delicate balance of flavors. My friend had the onion soup and the petit filet, and loved it too. We shared the chocolate souffle tart which was very good though not better than other restaurants. A special shout out for the bread which is to die for! Perfect texture, perfect crust, delicious and the butter is amazing too. I would come back just for the bread! I can't wait to eat here again.
author: rebecca p.

description: Amazing experience. Made a reservation to come back at the end of my meal. Spring onion soup was the best soup I've ever had. Heavenly. Service was a bit inattentive, but not terribly so. The steak was enormous.
author: Ross R.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed everything about this restaurant! Had a 5PM reservation and wanted to never leave..

Firstly, our server Kim was amazing in every way possible. 

Tried the following dishes - and all were excellent:

DEVILED EGG (warning spicy hot)
Mushrooms "A LA GRECQUE"
HALIBUT Crudo
White CORN SOUP
GEM Lettuce Salad
King SALMON and
and various wines, too 

Even with so many good places to eat in SF - this one is a real standout representing greatness - in food and service and ambiance.

Will definitely be back.

Kudos!
author: B H.

description: Not my style of eating and restaurant, but the food all by itself was very good. This would be a gem if this was just an ordinary under the radar restaurant serving new American food. But because there is a lot of hype of food sourcing and chef pedigree, it is very expensive and the servings are quite small. Would only be a regular if the prices were in half. And there is nothing super special to be a "special occasion" place.
author: Dylan Y.

description: My family and I were excited to try Octavia last night, but unfortunately, did not leave impressed. The service was excellent, the decor very comfortable, but the food was just o.k.. I am a chef and receiving a Michelin Star is a big deal in my mind. This means the food needs to be the best of the best and it just wasn't. We started with some oysters which were fine, but not special. Then, we had a few of the signature dishes- "deviled" egg and cold squid ink noodles. The egg was o.k., but lacked salt and was over-seasoned with both dry and one-note chilies on the bottom. The Squid Ink noodles were interesting, but probably would be more enjoyable at room temperature than chilled.  The Chanterelle mushroom soup was probably the strongest dish, but had the odd addition of artichoke hearts instead of sauteed mushrooms in the bottom. I think even charred spring onions or carmelized shallots would have been better. The duck breast was also quite good. Just to be thorough, we also had the pasta with duck confit, the red trout, the honey crumble and the orange float which was interesting. The other odd part was the presence of citrus in so many dishes. I realize it is seasonal, but with such a limited menu, you would expect less of certain types of ingredients. Finally, let me just say that the technical skills and presentation were excellent, but the flavors were not quite as exciting as I would from a Michelin rated restaurant.
author: dan s.

description: My sweetie and I had a fantastic first experience here for my birthday dinner. The atmosphere and decor is lovely, service was great, each dish was balanced and exceptional, the wine recommendations bore out well. We particularly enjoyed the deviled egg, and the squid ink noodles. The whole experience was romantic and delicious. Definitely will return for future special occasions.
author: Roxanne C.

description:
The food is delicious. The service is excellent. Our group had a combination of starters and entrees and nothing was disappointing. The beef tongue despite my wariness was so tasty and I really enjoyed the smoked mussels and potatoes.  
We shared all the desserts and they were all amazing. My favorite was the poppy seed angel cake with blueberry sorbet but they were all so good it was a hard choice.
author: Kat F.

description: Amazing. Probably the best food I've had in SF. Went there last night for my wife's birthday. Portions not too big, crab was delicious, halibut was perfect. Looking forward to going back again.
author: Ian V.

description: Octavia has become one of my favorite restaurants in SF. It's not located in a happening neighborhood. Located at the old Banker and Baker location on a residential corner in Lower Pac Heights, there won't be as many people walking by to check it out and put their name down, such as Rich Table in Hayes Valley. But their restaurant does fill up. Back to why the restaurant is one of my favorites, it boils down to the food. Location is not ideal, ambience is nice but a tad chilly on a cold day but the food is exceptional. While the menu is seasonal and changes on a regular basis, they do have staples and one of their staple dishes is the chilled squid ink noodles. Super refreshing with the amount of citrus they use. I also had the cauliflower appetizer which was scrumptious. The pasta dish was my least favorite of everything, but still really good! Lastly, I shared the duck and steak entrees which were my favorites. My date and I assumed the meat was sous vide then grilled since it was so tender so we asked the waitress to confirm our hypothesis. Wrong, no sous vide, just plain old fashion grilling by the owner chef. Damn, that was good.
author: Kai C.

description: We went here for a bday party at the chef's table, which is located in the downstairs kitchen. We were in the way of the runners at some points, which I'm sure was really annoying, but they all just went with it and were very accommodating. Our server was great too. The food was all very good - the squid ink pasta and halibut were standouts. So very good. The strawberry short cake-like desert was also quite delicious. For the combination of good food and great service, I will definitely be back. And for a small celebration (max 12 guests), their chef's table is definitely a venue to consider.
author: Missy S.

description: Enjoyed our anniversary dinner at this cute neighborhood place from the owner of Frances. We've eaten at Frances and had high expectations for her new restaurant. We weren't disappointed. Parking on street was moderately easy to find on a Tues night and the nearby J-town garage was our backup. We were warmly greeted upon entering and shown to our table right away. Service was friendly and attentive. We ordered the mixed green salad with buratta, smoked trout, duck, ricotta dumplings, angel food cake, and crumb pudding. Everything was delicious with the duck being the standout dish of the night. Dessert came with candles to celebrate our anniversary. Such a nice touch!
author: tina l.

description: The food is very delicious. It says the reservation needs 2 weeks in advance! fortunately my friends and I got reservation long time ago. No waiting is needed.
author: Newlife 2.

description: Having had a mediocre dining experience at a much lauded restaurant the night before, I was hoping Octavia would live up to its hype, and holy crap, did it. Every course was such an enjoyable experience and the natural style Pinot noir we tried was a perfect complement (not too smack-you-in-the-face barnyardy). The squid ink noodles with bottarga was unbelievably delicious and savory. Just a heads up, the appetizers are on the smaller side, but that just means you can try more things. We had the deviled egg (one each), the squid noodles, the greens, and the malfatti ricotta dumplings (malfatti means misshapen, not "badly made" as I had translated it, these dumplings are the OPPOSITE of badly made. They are extremely well made. I don't speak Italian SHUSH.) and that was plenty for two people. That didn't stop us from getting dessert though, thank god, because the rocky road eton mess was so alarmingly delicious I seriously regretted choosing to share it. There wasn't a single misstep throughout the meal, except for maybe when a waiter asked if I would like more bread, and having not finished my first piece I declined, and then she cleared our bread plates and swept away with my last piece of bread, and I shed a small tear, but lbr I probably didn't need it anyway. Oh, and the price of everything, even with a bottle of wine was totally reasonable. I'm gonna try to go back asap. A+!
author: Claire T.

description: I am not sure what the fuss is about.  The food was only ok.  The deviled eggs were soft and warm however the seasonings and spices were not very complimentary.  The quail was rather bland.  The rib eye was average as was the service and the space.  With so many great choices in SF to spend your money I would go somewhere else.
author: Ed V.

description: Flawlessly executed classics in modern interpretation. Quality is even across the board. Impeccable service. One star down for poor lighting. Actually I would have given 4.5 but it is not possible. Make sure to make reservations as the place fills up fast.
author: Eugene K.

description: Just awesome.  Just awesome.  Everything was beyond amazing.  If vegetables tasted like this all of the time, I'd be a vegetarian.  The grits, mushrooms & pepper dish was incredible.
author: B R.

description: very kind staff and nice open space.  Slow service at times.  Had three shared apps including the soup (delicious curry squash), squash blossom salad and my favorite was a sumer bean salad.  Had the salmon and the salmon was cooked great but the medley was hard flavors to love.  The dessert we just ordered wrong - The lavender meringue.  Left half of it over and just couldn't get into liking it.  I think the others would have been good.
author: around town e.

description: We celebrated our 25 year anniversary at Octavia's this week and it did not disappoint. We shared many of the small plates and starters and were impressed by how each one was creative, balanced and delicious. We especially enjoyed the "deviled egg" which is like a beyond perfect soft boiled egg with amazing seasonings and spices. I've never tasted an egg like this before, and would go back just to have it again. Other standouts were the calamari and also the lemony squid ink pasta. The wine list is impressive and international with a heavy emphasis in excellent french wines. There was also a great selection of wines by the glass as well. We enjoyed a Premier Cru Chablis as well as the house Pinot Noir cuvee. The ambiance at Octavia is warm and inviting and the service is spot on. Octavia is quite new and just opened 7 months ago.  Give it a try.. you'll be so glad you did!!
author: Karen S.

description: Had a lovely dinner here this past weekend. Called at 6pm on Saturday to see if they had any cancelled reservations, and miraculously, one had just opened up. Standout dish was the squash and burrata. The vibe is cozy and perfect for a date night.
author: Heather K.

description: I heard great reviews about Octavia, so my friends and I decided to try this place. I have always been fond of Melissa Perello's food back in the day at Charles Nob Hill, which most of foodies think should come back. Melissa's sister restaurant Frances in SF is quite good as well, but CNH was pretty hard to beat. We started off at Octavia with Morro Bay oyster's which were quite salty and just OK. The Deviled Egg was very touch notch and served on the soft boiled side with a nice flavor of pepper & spice. We didn't really care for the Beef Tongue and Summer Tomatoes. We noticed that Octavia likes to use a lot of cilantro, dill, and tomatoes in their dishes which were not a big fan of considering the dishes that were served.The Calamari salad was pasty and not what we expected. The Red Lentil & Kuri Squash soup was excellent and well prepared. The saffron Tonnarelli pasta was good, but then again tomatoes were in the dish. Hold the tomatoes and add rabbit or another gamey animal to the pasta dish. We finished off with the Pork Chop and Polenta dishes and both were excellent. We passed on dessert considering how much we shared. I would add padded seats and pillows to sit on considering the seating was a bit uncomfortable. I would highly recommend getting valet parking for us folks traveling long distances, and street parking was quite difficult to find. Back in the Baker and Banker days there was valet which was a nice convenience. Overall, there was some hit and misses on the dishes that can improve over time. The staff was very attentive. I would definitely be back at some point, but not anytime soon until I hear of some improvements. For right now stick with Melissa's sister restaurant Frances which is a bit better.
author: Mark L.

description: Nice location. We asked for and got the table in the corner with a nice view of the surrounding residential neighborhood. Sunday night, but restaurant was packed. Good service, waiter knowledgeable and with nice style. Only a few dishes on the menu. We had beef tongue and pasta dish for appetizer, beef tongue was particularly good. Quail and veggie dish for main course were also very good. Beer selection is limited and a bit odd.
author: lothar d.

description: What a surprise!  I think Melissa has outdone Francis.  Everything we had was excellent.  The beef tongue melts in your mouth.  The green beans were prefectly cooked.  The highlight of the entire meal was the corn chowder.  Both my wife and I thought it was the best corn soup we have ever tried.  We had the salomon entre which I wasn't crazt about.  Not that it wasnt good, because it was perfectly cooked.  It's just that it is something you can prepare at home without too much fuss.  The service was spot on.  Our server was previously at Quince and then at Francis for 5 years and was asked to move to Octavia.  Melissa was wise to pull vetran staff from Francis to open this restaruant.  Their professionalism shows well for a new venture.  For dessert we had the chocolate souffle with caramel which was very good.  Their wine list is very nice and quite extensive including dessert wines.  This is a super replacement for Baker and Banker and should become even more successful as time passes. The decor is very pleasant and gave a nice feeling of calmness.  I would highly recommed this restaruant.
author: Michael B.

description: overrated. The dishes LOOK as fancy as interior design. Some of the cuisines are freaking salted!
author: Jasmine S.

description: What a phenomenal place! We loved everything we ordered, and only wished we had bigger stomachs to eat everything on the menu. Our favorites were the beef tongue and almond puff with basil ice cream! The beef tongue melted in my mouth and the basil ice cream was so refreshing! The wait staff was very attentive and paid close attention to everything. My only compliant was the wait time for the main entree. It took more than 30 mins for the entree to come after everything else was perfectly on the spot.
author: Avril C.

description: Love the variety of fresh, local ingredients, all prepared with expert, delicate care.  I'm in love with any of Chef Perello's fresh pasta dishes, soups, and unique treats (like the beef tongue, yum!).  But, I was BLOWN away with the Ribeye!  And I rarely save room for desert, but that soufflé is incredible.  Will be back soon, and often!
author: Dale L.

description: The food was good. The squid ink and beef tongue were very good. The lamb was ok. The desserts were great. I liked the atmosphere and will be back to try the other items on the menu. Very cute decor and service was good.
author: M. F.
